DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) (EXEMPTION OF COUNCIL ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 16 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill was introduced into the Senate last year by my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald and it was passed by the Senate on 28 October. This bill was designed to correct an anomaly in the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. It seems remarkable that nearly two years later the government still has not corrected this anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the honourable member for Wannon continues I remind honourable members in the House that, under standing order 58, they must take their seats when they are in the chamber. Either take your seats or leave.

—As I say, it seems remarkable that nearly two years after the government introduced this legislation it still has not corrected this anomaly. It seems remarkable that no credit is being given to the opposition for drawing this to the government's attention and it seems remarkable that, given the government's response to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which acknowledged the problem, there still has been no action. One would hope that the reason for this delay is not that the government wants to discourage people offering to give voluntary or semi-voluntary service through becoming involved in their local councils.

PARA.TAB: The basis of this bill is quite simple. It is, as I say, designed to correct an anomaly in the Superannuation Guarantee Act 1992. That act requires that the superannuation levy be paid for elected councillors and aldermen who receive allowances. This results in councillors and aldermen then not complying with the definition of an eligible person in section 82AA(2) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That means that they cannot claim a tax deduction for any personal contribution they may make to their own superannuation fund. Only eligible persons can claim deductions for private superannuation and, under the definition, persons are not eligible if 10 per cent or more of their income comes from a source which provides that they have employer funded superannuation support. This means that councillors and aldermen cannot claim in their income tax returns a deduction of up to $3,000 plus 75 per cent of any amount above that for their own personal superannuation contributions if they have qualified for the council superannuation.

To give the House an example, a councillor who receives a council allowance of $6,000 a year and who is self-employed with an assessable income of $50,000 a year would not be entitled to claim any private superannuation contributions as a tax deduction because the council would be paying the princely sum of $300 a year in compulsory superannuation. In other words, that person is heavily penalised. Even though the majority of that person's income is from his or her own sources, because that person happens to receive from the council an allowance which attracted a $300 superannuation contribution, the major contributions that that person makes for his or her own superannuation would no longer be tax deductible. It means that the government is, in effect, penalising those who seek to serve the community as local government representatives, for which they generally gain very little remuneration. Of course, councils lose out because they have to pay the additional compulsory superannuation contributions.

It is interesting to note that the former minister for local government the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) claimed that, as far as local government is concerned, the new superannuation contributions will apply only to Brisbane city councillors who are in receipt of salaries. That obviously was the government's intention, but unfortunately the effect has gone much wider. In reality there are many councillors who are not full time in their job as a councillor, whose main source of income comes from their own business activities, and who have lost the ability to deduct private superannuation contributions from their income tax. In other words, they are being disadvantaged because of their community service.

This bill sets out to remove the anomaly where local government councillors receive only limited allowances in exercising their duties from the superannuation guarantee legislation. It is interesting to note that the bill has the total support of the Municipal Association of Victoria and the Local Government Association of Queensland. Clearly, councillors and aldermen whose substantive form of employment or work is not with a council of which they are members and whose payment reflects this reality cannot, in all seriousness, be considered as employees of that council. Yet section 221A(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act specifically excludes payments by way of remuneration or allowances to a member of a local governing body from the meaning of salary or wages under the PAYE tax system. In other words, the Income Tax Assessment Act does not treat allowances or remuneration for councillors as salaries or wages, but the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act does. The basis of this amendment is to remove that anomaly.

Clearly, the government knows that there is a problem and it has acknowledged that there is a problem. In fact, in July 1992, some 19 months ago, the former minister for local government the honourable member for Calare wrote to all local councils and, in part, said:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Local Government elected members are concerned the new superannuation arrangements will only apply to councillors who are in receipt of salaries.

Unfortunately, the legislation did not reflect this, it was not clear enough and allowances have now been considered as salaries for the purposes of this superannuation act. The government did try to overcome the problem by changing the word `payments' to `remuneration' in the definition of `salaries and wages' in the act. But that did not work because the Australian Taxation Office deemed that local government councillors are in the employ of the council and allowances paid to councillors are salaries or wages for the purposes of this superannuation act.

PARA.TAB: This is not good enough and this is why we are bringing forward this amendment. The government promised to do something about the problem when it gained support from the Australian Democrats in getting the original superannuation legislation through in 1992. It still has not done anything about this problem. In fact, when the bill passed through the Senate late last year, Senator Ray said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the general attitude of the government is that it would rather have those matters covered in superannuation legislation that we produce.

In other words, the government was not happy that the opposition should put forward a simple amendment to change the legislation to remove this anomaly. The government wants to bring in its own legislation. The problem is that we are still waiting.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of arrogance.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Indi points out, there is a touch of arrogance there and it is to be regretted. Nearly two years later, the government still has not produced its own legislation. The government does have a clear responsibility here, one which it has acknowledged but has still managed to renege on. It is a great disappointment to those who are involved in local government to see that the government has been so tardy at best in attacking this problem.

PARA.TAB: Given that the government has acknowledged that a problem exists, given that the government does not have any legislation of its own and given the strong support from organisations such as the MAV and the Local Government Association of Queensland, I would have thought the very least that the government could do is support this motion that has been put forward by the opposition. Clearly it addresses the problems and answers the concerns, and I think it deserves bipartisan support.

Since the bill has already been passed in the Senate and since it clearly has the basic support of the government, I now challenge the government to show that it is big enough to put this to a vote in this House. This would recognise the very constructive role the opposition is playing in this matter, it would recognise the importance of private members business and, most importantly, it would quickly correct an anomaly that is most unfair to local government through a technical fault in a bill that the government introduced in 1992. So I would urge all honourable members to support this motion, and I challenge the government to put it to a vote so as to correct this anomaly once and for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I have a general sympathy with the motion put forward by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). On the face of it, it would appear that we do have an anomaly with the existing superannuation guarantee legislation as it applies to people in receipt of allowances in their roles as local government councillors and that the consequence of this anomaly is that people in that situation are at risk of losing their superannuation tax concession should they happen to be self-employed and contributing to their own superannuation as private individuals in that way.

PARA.TAB: I should indicate to the honourable member for Wannon, and it is obviously a matter of opinion as to the timing of these issues, that the government is in fact about to address the issue. It has been in the process of going through a detailed examination of the situation very recently, and I am hopeful that the matter will be addressed in the immediate future.

It is worth pointing out that in this legislation there are some complexities involved which the honourable member did not mention. The way that allowances are paid and structured tends to vary across different areas of local government. For example, there are some complexities with the way certain allowances relating to travel and the like are dealt with. It is not necessarily quite as simple as the honourable member presented in his contribution this afternoon. But I would generally accept that the point that is made and contained within the legislation put forward by the Senate is in fact correct.

However, I would like to ventilate a couple of broader issues that I think this matter gives rise to and that are worthy of comment and consideration. The first point that comes to mind, and I think it is one honourable members may well want to contemplate, is that one of the reasons this has become a particular problem in local government is that a disproportionate number of people who are self-employed are involved in local government. In itself that is not necessarily a bad thing, but I think it illustrates that a problem does exist with local government.

Certainly in my state, Victoria, and I suspect elsewhere in Australia, a very substantial proportion of the community is effectively prevented from becoming local councillors and from participating in local government because of the nature of their employment. We would all know, and there are honourable members here who formerly were local councillors and can attest to the fact, that if one wants to be an effective local councillor in this day and age it is almost impossible to be a full-time employee in the work force at the same time. Therefore, we find that people who are self-employed, unemployed or working part time tend to dominate in local councils and that ordinary workers, whatever level of the work force they are at, find it very difficult to participate in local government.

I suspect this is one of the reasons it is a problem: we actually have a lot of people in local government who are self-employed. I raise this as an issue to be thought about because clearly many of us would have reservations about full-time, paid councillors and the like, particularly in council areas with 10,000 people. It would be a bit absurd to have paid councillors at that level. But this is a problem for our democratic structures at local government level; many people are in effect prevented from participating.

Secondly, an issue that deserves consideration is the fact that the superannuation tax concession as currently structured effectively favours higher income earners. In the broader picture of tax reform it needs to be kept in mind that the effective beneficiaries of that tax concession are higher income earners.

Thirdly, and finally, I want to talk in some detail about the question that has occupied my mind in the superannuation context for quite some time—I urge honourable members to give consideration to it also—and that is that our current occupational superannuation structure is inadequate. It is a major improvement on what we had in 1983. A much larger proportion of the community now has access to superannuation than was the case in 1983. It has been a very substantial step forward from when this government first took office when roughly 45 per cent of the work force had access to superannuation. Overwhelmingly, the better-off parts of the work force were covered by superannuation and people such as the workers whom I as a union official used to represent, by and large, did not have it.

There has been a major improvement, but the vehicle that has been used has had its deficiencies. Because it has been through award based superannuation—for pragmatic reasons it has been adopted as a vehicle to spread superannuation across the work force—we now have a number of anomalies. The one that has been referred to today is just one of those. I would like to refer to a few others because I am a supporter of a national superannuation scheme. I believe that the current arrangements we have should be seen as a stepping stone to a more comprehensive and more equitable superannuation scheme.

I remind honourable members that in 1975 the Hancock inquiry recommended a comprehensive national superannuation scheme along the lines of schemes that exist in some other countries in the OECD. Unfortunately, for various reasons, this scheme was rejected in the Senate and became one of the widely touted 21 bills that were advertised around the place. I cannot quite recollect the phrase, but I think it was something like Labor's 21 bills that will enslave Australia or imprison Australia. I still have the booklet at home. It is quite an extraordinary document.

According to the opposition of the day and the current opposition, in 1975 we were on the verge of a totalitarian state in this country and that part of this totalitarian plot was going to be a national superannuation scheme. I urge the opposition to give more mature consideration to these issues. I think it would find that some of the anomalies, such as the one it raised today, in the current arrangements would be cured by moving to a national superannuation scheme—not necessarily precisely on the same basis as the Hancock inquiry recommended. We have probably learnt a few things since then that we could accommodate in a new national superannuation scheme.

I suggest that the following deficiencies in the existing arrangements could and would be remedied by moving to a more comprehensive scheme. It is obviously inequitable. If one works part time or one is intermittently in the work force, as many women are, or one is a casual, obviously less in contributions will be made on one's behalf. Obviously, it is better for higher income earners, because superannuation is on a percentage basis, so their superannuation will end up reflecting their level of income when they are in the work force. Those people are also most likely to have built up private assets to rely on in retirement anyway as a result of their higher income status while earning.

It is administratively complex. It does not cover people who are self-employed. It does not cover people who are employed but not covered by any awards other than through the superannuation guarantee scheme. As a result, there are different categories of people in different arrangements all around the place. The government is still grappling with the small contributions problem where, because people are casual or intermittent workers, their contributions get eaten up in administrative charges in the funds that they are in.

There is a serious problem with lack of membership control. As a former union official, I do not believe in the current structure of half employers and half union representatives. I believe that the trustees should simply be elected by the members of the fund and that neither employers nor union representatives should have any automatic right to be trustees of the individual funds. If a union is good enough to represent its members in that sphere, then, as happened in one instance with my union, an official will be elected by the members of that fund into that sort of position.

There is also a lack of options for members in determining where investment goes. In this country the key economic decisions are being made by bodies like National Mutual and AMP on behalf of people like me who have money in occupational superannuation funds such as CARE, of which I am a member, which is run by AMP.

I have no say as to how the economic power of my little bit of that superannuation fund is actually wielded by AMP. Equally, I have no ability to say, `Look, I'd like my money to be invested in Australia, even if that means there might be a slightly lower than optimum return', or, `No, I don't want my money invested in particular types of investment because I am ethically opposed to those types of investments'. So there is a clear lack of ability for customer choice in those cases.

There are a number of other problems. Litigation of total and permanent disablement claims is a serious problem that needs to be examined. Although the government has done the right thing in setting up a tribunal to deal with superannuation problems, unfortunately, it has left this area outside the scope of the tribunal. It is still within the scope of state supreme courts, which makes it practically impossible for people to get effective justice in this area.

We are dealing with a complex area. I certainly have no problem with the fact that the honourable member for Wannon has raised this issue today. But I urge opposition members to look at this question more broadly, to recognise that we need to have a system in this country that provides full superannuation for everybody, and to do it in another way. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Amendment Bill 1993 has been brought forward by the shadow minister for local government, Senator Ian Macdonald, and is ably supported by my colleague the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I join him in this regard. This is an issue which is very important to my area. I have had strenuous representations from many local government bodies on this issue. The shire of Strathfieldsaye, the shire of Newstead, the town of St Arnaud, the city of Maryborough, the rural city of Marong, the shire of Maldon, the shire of Korong, the shire of Kara Kara, the borough of Eaglehawk, the shire of Huntly, the shire of Bet Bet, the shire of Tullaroop, and the Municipal Association of Victoria have all made representations to me on this matter which is affecting local government.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to a statement put out by the former minister for local government the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) on 2 July 1992. The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Local Government, David Simmons, said today
Opposition claims that councils would be required to make superannuation contributions on allowances paid to all elected members were incorrect.

We now find that the government has been tardy in correcting this anomaly. The claim made by the honourable member for Calare—and I believe that he is a genuine and honourable man—was made so at the time in the correct way, but regrettably, the government has not supported him in correcting this anomaly. His statement of 2 July 1992 continued:
"As far as Local Government is concerned, the new superannuation contributions will apply only to Brisbane City councillors who are in receipt of salaries," he said.

All the councils in my area have written to me to highlight the anomaly that exists and the fact that we are in effect penalising those who seek to serve the community as local government representatives. They really gain very little in remuneration. Most of these people serve purely in an honorary sense. They are at the beck and call of their local government ratepayers and they spend an enormous amount of time in fulfilling the needs of local government throughout their municipalities.

PARA.TAB: Much of their time, of course, is devoted to going out and inspecting problems and issues which arise in their own riding or municipality. They are always out of pocket. One can hardly call the small allowance they receive adequate remuneration for the tasks they perform. The councils also miss out in this regard because they have to carry the extra costs of the compulsory superannuation contributions. So the ratepayers are affected as well because of the council having to pick up the costs that are incurred as a result of those contributions.

In the administration of some superannuation funds, because the amount of remuneration is small and the contributions are also small, when the money goes into that fund the charges that are levied against the fund often exceed the benefit. So year after year the costs of disposing of the responsibilities of the superannuation fund mount up and the benefits at the end of it all are virtually nil.

When the then minister for local government the honourable member for Calare responded to the opposition's concerns about this, he was quite incorrect in saying that the only local government area that it would apply to would be the Brisbane city councillors who are paid some form of salary. He did not properly investigate the impact this would have on local government throughout Australia. We now find that local government is being penalised as a result of the government's inaction on this particular matter. That has been the motivation for Senator Ian Macdonald bringing forward the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Amendment Bill 1993.

Most councillors—I can speak with some experience having observed the councillors in my own electorate over many years—in reality, are not in the job full time. They work as part-time people in the council. Nevertheless, they devote an enormous amount of time to it, many of them spending every night out at meetings on behalf of ratepayers and countless weekends out on inspections. Their main source of income is their own business activities or employment. As a result, they have lost the ability to deduct private superannuation contributions. They are being disadvantaged for their voluntary service to the community. Volunteer service is one thing we should never lose in Australia.

There are two great organisations that I can speak of in Victoria. The first is local government, with the thousands of hours that those involved give voluntarily to the community, and the other is the Country Fire Authority, which has about 125,000 members who perform volunteer firefighting services in the state of Victoria. I liken the community service of local government very much to the activities of those firefighting services. Those volunteers fit in their training, dedication and service to the community in their spare time. Local government is identical to this because people involved there are providing a service to the ratepayers and the tiny amount of allowance they receive really could hardly be classified as remuneration. I think this is where this bill really seeks to correct that anomaly and put it back into a proper context.

All local government councillors that I know, particularly in rural areas, would be many hundreds of dollars out of pocket—probably more by the time they run a motor vehicle and do all of the jobs they are required to do in local government and be representative on a whole range of committees looking after the community's interests. To lose their ability to deduct private superannuation contributions because their main source of income is some other private activity or business activity imposes a double penalty on them. They really are very disadvantaged.

The bill that has been brought forward by Senator Ian Macdonald does have the total support of the Municipal Association of Victoria. It made very strenuous representations to me, as did all of my local councils, to have this anomaly corrected. I also understand that the Local Government Association of Queensland is strongly in support of this motion. Councillors and aldermen whose substantive form of employment or work is not with a council of which they are members and whose payment reflects this reality cannot be considered as employees.

If we go back to the original statement of the minister at the time, we will see that he really summed up the situation. It was not the intention of that minister to in fact take all councillors into that great net and for the legislation to affect their superannuation contributions. The honourable member made it quite clear in his statement of 2 July 1992 that he believed that that should apply to only the Brisbane city councillors. I strongly support the bill that has been brought forward by the shadow minister, Senator Macdonald. I wish to support the comments on this bill made by the honourable member for Wannon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the intent of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Amendment Bill, as I welcome the intention of the shadow minister for local government and the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Ian Macdonald. Most importantly, I welcome the intervention of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) in his capacity as the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services. His intervention in this matter will certainly produce results in terms of a review of the decision within the government. I am informed by the minister's office that a letter has been forwarded to each of the local government associations around the country, stating the concern that the Deputy Prime Minister has about this issue, how that concern is being reflected across the government backbench and how a review will be under way within the office of the Treasurer (Mr Willis).

PARA.TAB: I think this makes a very important point about the role of elected people in local government. Coming from a local government background, one thing I have learnt is that we should always declare our interest in these things. So I am very mindful of the fact that I am the only member of this parliament who still serves in an elected capacity in local government. I will be serving as the Mayor of Liverpool and a councillor in that local government area until the end of 1994. I am well aware of the great interest and concern throughout local government in New South Wales about this issue.

That concern is irrespective of location of the councils or the political composition of those councils, but it does make the point about the importance of local government in our federal system of government. In a meeting of the heads of government in Hobart last Friday, federalism was under review. Of course, local government did not achieve a great deal of attention or scrutiny in that process. But, through this legislation, we can at least say something in our federal system about the role of the elected person.

I am of the opinion that the Australian Taxation Office should not classify allowances as taxable income. I am also of the opinion that it should not classify elected people in local government as employees for the purposes of the superannuation guarantee levy. We need to encourage a cross-section of our community to take a role in local government. As my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) pointed out, if we made a survey of each of the local government authorities around Australia, we would find collectively and in most individual cases disproportionate representation of men, of older people, of those from an English-speaking background and also of those who have business interests.

If we are to foster a genuinely representative cross-section in local government throughout the country, we need to make sure that local government is seen to be an attractive activity for people who have an interest in their local democracies. Of course, that extends to the conditions that relate to allowances and their taxation treatment by this government. It is a disincentive for certain groups of people to become involved in local government when these disadvantages are raised regarding any private superannuation arrangements they hold in their regular place of employment.

Another point concerns the expenses that flow to councils. This is, quite substantially, an extra burden on the administration and costs of every local government authority in the country. We need to be mindful of the way in which local government has been squeezed for finances by federal and state governments for many decades and how this measure, when reviewed by the government, can assist in easing the burden of financial cost for local government authorities.

I welcome the government review. I am sure that, following the representations that have been made by government members, it will lead to better consideration of these issues in making local government an attractive activity for people who have an interest at the local level and will make sure that council costs, through administration and the payments through to the superannuation levy, are kept to an absolute minimum.

I think most members of this House would have some awareness of the great sacrifices made by elected people in local government. I am always reminded of a story in my own local government authority of a councillor who was rung on Christmas Day about a pothole. He was howled down by the irate ratepayer who could not understand why the council would not take any action on Christmas Day on the problem he was experiencing in his street. With local government it is much more than a cliche that elected people are very close to the public; they are so close that the issues of local government administration can even infringe on holy days, such as Christmas Day.

We need to have good regard for the efforts of those people serving across the country to make sure that local government is both efficient and responsive to community needs. If we can do that through making local government an attractive activity, then I think we do a great service not only to the federal system of government in Australia but also to the wellbeing and effectiveness of local government authorities in this nation.

This government also has under review the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986. I welcome again the intervention of the Deputy Prime Minister in this regard as it recognises the role played by local government. Each year 809 councils across Australia spend combined resources of close to $10 billion. That is a very significant amount of money, both in the effectiveness of the services they deliver and making sure that ratepayers receive value for money.

This government, quite sensibly, is dovetailing those issues against the review of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986. I urge all honourable members to take an interest in the discussion paper that has been produced by the government as part of the Australian urban and regional development review and the way in which we need to have close scrutiny of the operations of the grants commissions in our states.

The discussion paper points out that two models of horizontal equalisation are being followed: one by Western Australia and Queensland and the other by New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and, to a lesser extent, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. In the latter group an increasing share of funds has been allocated since 1986-87 to councils with increasing populations. In Queensland and Western Australia, funds have gone increasingly to councils with declining and stable populations. An analysis of the grant distribution was also conducted on the basis of the ABS index of relative socioeconomic disadvantage. In most states an increasing share of financial assistance grants have been going to councils with the highest socioeconomic disadvantage.

As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker—and this is of great concern—the investigation has shown that in the state of Victoria the highest share of grants from the Grants Commission goes to the least disadvantaged councils. We can no longer tolerate a situation where federal funding is being distributed by state grant commissions through totally different criteria and with totally different outcomes across the nation. I look forward to the way in which the Deputy Prime Minister's review will produce a much more equitable outcome, reflecting the need to have uniformity in these local government arrangements across Australia.

Finally, having welcomed the intent of this legislation—and I am sure the government review will be productive—I would just state my surprise at the fashion in which this legislation has come before the parliament. It is not inappropriate legislation, it is not incorrect or inaccurate legislation, but it is surprising because it has come from the opposition. There is now a wide appreciation in the parliament of how the opposition has given up on any constructive contribution to the wellbeing of the nation and to the administration of government at a federal level. Its sole focus is going to be on personalities, on questioning the legitimacy of this government and going back to the time-honoured methods of conservative parties—that is, engaging in muckraking of the sort that I am sure we will see in question time this afternoon.

It is of great concern that the opposition has given up on any constructive contribution, although on the government side we look forward to the way in which this will, again, focus the weak leadership of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and his total unsuitability for the populist style now being pioneered. This could well be the opposition's final positive contribution on the question of local government and the superannuation levy. It is hoped that honourable members opposite restore a genuine interest in a positive contribution to government and make sure that we see more of these measures coming through instead of the sort of populist, muckraking tactics that the opposition now seems concerned about, more than any positive contribution they can make to the parliament and the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure today to speak on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) (Exemption of Council Allowances) Amendment Bill 1993. I thought it was somewhat contradictory for the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) to give the opposition a bit of a serve, and then at the end of his speech to give some compliments. At the same time as he was criticising us for playing the man, he did save some pretty solid comments for the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

PARA.TAB: The fact of life is that this legislation has been handled tardily by the government, and discriminates against local government. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) have outlined this matter very clearly. I, of course, support and congratulate the shadow minister in the other place for the effort put up. Discussions this morning with the Local Government Association of South Australia showed that its members were quite clearly aggravated by the government's neglect.

The honourable member opposite talked about the Australian Taxation Office. This is not a matter for the tax office but a matter for the parliament. How long are we going to hide behind the tax office? It is summed up quite clearly by the Local Government Association of South Australia in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: The Association strongly objects to Local Government allowances being interpreted as `salary or wages' to attract the Superannuation Guarantee Charge or in any other circumstances.

As an aside, I was a little curious with the honourable member for Werriwa's comment that he was still in local government, the mayor of his particular electorate. My advice before the last election was that, being an elected representative claiming profit under the Crown, I had to resign. I hope the honourable member is not in dereliction of some statute.

PARA.TAB: The real issue here is whether the parliament wants to recognise local government. When speaking about that, we can have all the flowery phrases we like—and we get so eloquent in this place—but it has taken us at least two years after the minister has said that no one would be affected, and after the government has said it will introduce legislation. If that is not showing contempt for local government, what else is? The report on the review of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act was previously mentioned by the honourable member, quoting some tables and making reference to some issues raised.

There is also reference to efficiency. If ever there was something that clouded and was a simple little example of the inefficiencies which the federal government applied to local government, surely this is it. It is a rather patronising, arrogant attitude from this level of government towards that other sphere of government. I find it totally unacceptable, having spent nearly six years in local government. Due to the fact that I was a candidate for this place, I could not continue. That was of some regret to me—apparently the previous member who spoke found a way around that. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled The community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program—a review of a report on an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Canberra Times suggested that the report I have just tabled was going to be a whitewash. At the time I did not respond to the article in the Canberra Times because to have done so not only would have been a breach of the rules of this place but also would have prejudiced the committee's deliberations. Now that the report is tabled, I can make it quite clear that the report is a balanced and judicious statement that is very critical of the way in which the Minister for the Environment, Sport and the Territories (Mrs Kelly) administered the program. The report goes as far as the evidence allows and as far as is required by the committee. In so doing, it is anything but a whitewash. The journalists responsible need to be more perceptive in their assessment of parliamentary language.

PARA.TAB: This report is the outcome of the committee's review of a report from the Auditor-General. In its review of the audit report, the committee has concentrated on the key issues raised by the Auditor-General. Before discussing the report, I would like to lay to rest some of the false claims that have been made about the committee and the inquiry. It has been suggested that the report was referred to the committee in an attempt to either bury it or to smother it with the weight of the numbers of the government majority on the committee. Clearly this was not the case. The Auditor-General's report was referred to the committee in the same way that we have had other audit reports referred; that is, simply because it related to activities which are amongst the issues covered by the committee.

We set out to deal with it in the way that we have dealt with the others. There is nothing extraordinary or unusual about that. In fact, I consider that it is very necessary for such reports to be referred to committees to ensure accountability in the administration of government programs. As far as the numbers and composition of the committee is concerned, I can only point out that this was determined in the usual way after the last election, long before the audit report was tabled. The only change of membership that has occurred since the committee was appointed has been that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) has replaced the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles).

Finally, the opposition claims in its dissenting report that the inquiry was less than thorough. This is simply unreasonable. It was only at the last minute that the opposition called for additional witnesses to appear. We heard evidence from more witnesses than would normally have been heard in such an inquiry, including all the main actors such as the minister and the departmental head. All the central issues were extensively canvassed. More detail would have added nothing important to the outcome.

I now turn to the report. The committee has examined the audit report and the matters raised by the Auditor-General with a view to ensuring that the accountability requirements of the House are satisfied and that both the department and the minister are responding fully to the Auditor-General's findings. The Auditor-General had two main concerns: the departmental administration of the program and the public accountability of the minister and her staff for their decisions.

In relation to the first matter, the committee was initially concerned that the department was not inclined to accept that it had to make a serious response to the audit findings. This was disturbing for two reasons. Firstly, the department's administration had been seriously deficient and it clearly could have learnt a great deal from the audit. Secondly, although all the decisions about allocating the funds had been made, there was still a great deal to be done to finalise payments.

As our review progressed, the secretary to the department made it clear that the department's response to the audit recommendations was not as glib as it first appeared. The committee has been told that the audit recommendations are now being taken seriously, that they are accepted and that they are being implemented.

It has been agreed with the minister that, should a new funding round be introduced, substantially different and improved procedures will apply and more resources will be applied to administration. This will increase the administrative overheads of the program, which in the past has been run at very low administrative cost. It is accepted by the department that some increase in these costs is necessary.In any future administration, the department will have the benefit of a best practice guide for the administration of grants, which the Australian National Audit Office is developing.

As I mentioned, the Auditor-General was concerned about the public accountability of the minister for her administrative decisions. This issue also became a major focus of our inquiry. The Auditor-General addressed other questions of bias and incompetence but, as he stressed, these cannot be answered without reliable evidence and the minister's failure to keep adequate records means that there is no such documentary evidence.

There are inferences and indirect suggestions of bias in the allocation of grants. In fact, the inference of bias is very strong, but it is still only an inference. It is quite possible that those electorates which received the largest amounts of grants may have been the most in need. We can go no further than the Auditor-General in this and in other questions, and therefore we keep coming back to the question of accountability.

The Auditor-General proposed that, as a minimum, public accountability require that administrative processes should be fair and open, that decisions should be based on principle and supported by documented reasons, and that those involved in making decisions should be accountable for those decisions. In relation to the minister's administration of the sports facilities program, the committee concluded that she did not approach the minimum standard in relation to supporting her decisions with documented reasons, that her record keeping was seriously inadequate and that her administration was deficient.

We have recommended a series of measures that will, if adopted, make the administration of the program more transparent, particularly in relation to the decisions about which projects are to be funded. Our recommendations will make it much easier for the minister to make decisions and to document her reasons. Specifically, we recommend that, first, before any new round of funding is commenced, the department undertake an analysis of the need for cultural, recreation and sporting facilities to provide a reasonable basis for the allocation of funds to proposed projects.

Second, we recommend that in all future grants programs the department provide a schedule of applications that evaluates the proposed projects and contains recommendations to guide the minister's decisions. Third, we recommend that the grant application form be redesigned to provide information that will allow the department to numerically rate proposed projects against each other and that the criteria be weighted so that an overall rating can be calculated for each application.

Fourth, we recommend that the numerical ratings against the individual criteria, and the overall rating, be included in schedules of applications provided to the minister, and that the minister consider these ratings when making decisions about which applications to fund. Fifth, where additional information is obtained and the ratings are amended by the minister, the schedules should be annotated and the additional information added to the file.

If the measures we have recommended had been in place the minister would not now have any difficulty in proving that her decisions were justified and the Auditor would have found a very obvious audit trail. She would not now be facing the criticisms that have been levelled at her if she had properly documented the reasons for her decisions.

The committee noted that there were no significant suggestions of fraud or misappropriation arising from the Auditor-General's report. The minister's actions were not illegal. Although her administration was clearly deficient, the committee does not recommend to the House that the minister be censured.

It probably is the most damning report that has been brought down about a minister in modern times. PARA.TAB: The inquiry conducted by the committee was less than a thorough public examination of the issues raised in the Auditor-General's report. Only two witnesses were called. The Auditor-General laid down clear standards that need to be met in the administration of a program. It is true that the committee's majority report acknowledges that the minister's administration has been deficient. But we believe that, on the evidence, it would be reasonable to add the word `incompetent'. We are completely satisfied that the Auditor-General is correct in his assertion that there are insufficient records to support the minister's actions and statements regarding the program or to justify the selections that have been made.

It is clear from a minute written by Ms Dal Bon that the department was also concerned about the administration of the program and was anxious to protect itself from potential accusations of maladministration. It is particularly a matter of concern that Ms Dal Bon believed that the poor system of management of this program had `been handed down from on high'. Indeed, it is difficult to escape the conclusion that the minister avoided taking action to improve the accountability in this program so that the decision making process could not then be easily scrutinised.

The minister has acknowledged the poor standard of administration in the past and has promised to adopt better standards in the future. But she cannot be absolved from her past culpability merely by promising to do better in the future. The Auditor-General said in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally accepted in modern government that ministers are responsible for matters for which they have a personal involvement or where they fail to correct systemic failure within the portfolio of which they are aware.

In this instance, the minister is responsible for the failings within her department. But she adopted a hands-on approach to this program. She was personally involved in the selection process. She must, therefore, be held responsible for the inadequacies and gross deficiencies outlined in the Auditor-General's report.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories should resign. If she fails to do so, the parliament should demonstrate its commitment to the proper standards of management and accountability by calling on her to resign. It will not be sufficient in an incident like this for her merely to be moved to another portfolio. She has demonstrated an inability to manage a department and must resign altogether, unless this House and this government are going to accept that newer and lower standards should apply.

Another matter of considerable concern to the signatories to the dissenting report is the question of political bias. The Auditor-General, in our view, was unnecessarily circumspect in merely saying that claims of bias could not be put to rest. In my clear view, and in the view of my fellow coalition members of the committee, adequate evidence is now on the public record to demonstrate beyond reasonable doubt that this program was administered in a way that was politically partisan.

We have listed 20 separate reasons why that claim can be substantiated. One may argue that each one of them in itself is not conclusive proof, but when all 20 are added together it is impossible to come to any reasonable conclusion other than that this particular program was used and refined as part of the government's marginal seat election strategy, and that the grants were used to seek electoral advantage. There is another issue of considerable concern. Most observers believe that a strengthened House of Representatives committee system would greatly enhance this parliament. Instead of strengthening the House of Representatives committees, this has weakened the system, and sensitive issues are likely to be increasingly directed to Senate committees, where government majorities are not so readily able to dominate, irrespective of the facts.

This has been a difficult inquiry for the committee, and no doubt there has been some considerable rancour on occasions. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House notes with concern the urgent need to provide security and certainty for older Australians planning for their retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, I know that you and other members of this House appreciate that the elderly citizens who come to our offices have worries and concerns about their retirement and what they are going to do for the future. I know that all political parties are very concerned about this and, in their own ways, are trying to make sure that these people as they come to retirement age in increasing numbers can have certainty that their reasonable to good standard of living will be maintained. This is not only a problem in Australia but a problem right throughout the Western world. That band of the population is becoming older on the back of a decreasing birth rate, amongst other things.

The federal government, in its move to do something about providing retirement incomes, has brought in the superannuation guarantee levy. I know that it has made a gallant attempt to try to make sure that people in their retirement do have security. But, unfortunately, from my experience in my electorate, I know there are a number of problems with the guarantee levy. The information being received from some of the superannuation experts is highlighting the biggest problem. A good article in the Age of 22 March in part says:

SPEECH.PARA: For anyone aged 25 or more, the SGC will not be enough for them to comfortably retire on. Some actuaries go so far as to suggest that the average worker should be putting away at least 16 per cent of their salary each year for some 40 years just to maintain their present living standards in retirement.

That says a great deal. If this superannuation guarantee levy is kept in place, it will mean that no-one, particularly someone my age or younger, can really be secure in the knowledge that when they retire they will have enough to retire on. So people are going to have to look elsewhere to try to boost that funding.

PARA.TAB: One problem is that there does not seem to be any incentive today for people to put away for their retirement. When people on independent incomes get to the age of retirement they find that everything seems to work against them. They have to pay for this and they have to pay for something else. They are certainly not living to the same standard as other people. People are asking the question more and more: is it worth while for me to try to save for myself in retirement or should I just allow the government to do it for me and run the risk? Certainly in our democracy there is no way that we should see aged people disadvantaged, although the way we are going at the moment we could very well come to the situation where, no matter what we would like to do, we just will not be able to afford to care for those people who really need assistance in their old age.

The current superannuation law is complex and confusing. I think it is up to the federal government to reinvestigate the superannuation guarantee levy, have a look at the whole situation and come up with something that is much more simple. It seems to me that, as time goes by, for people planning for their retirement, it is like playing a game of football where the rules or the goalposts keep changing: they are not quite sure where they are going or what they are doing. I think it is very important for those people, as they approach old age, to know what they are really up for.

We really do not use our aged people as a valuable asset, if I could use that expression, enough. This is the International Year of the Family and we have been talking about the problems we are facing in Australia such as the family breakdown, which is caused by a number of things. Perhaps it is too easy now for partners to walk away from each other. Governments seem to support people in families that are breaking up. This is particularly so in some cultural groups where, in the extended family, the grandparents have a major role to play. I think that is very important.

I think some newspaper offices have a filing system in which the Chandler-Bogle affair is at the front, then there are the sharks and then there is the Donald Mackay affair and so on.
