So, having just bought the shares, he now finds that he can no longer collect his pension.

It is interesting to note that the committee was unanimous in its findings that the government's costings were invalid in that particular investigation. The proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses was not fair and equitable. Treatment of the various types of pensioner and veteran investments under the relevant income and assets test was inequitable. The piecemeal application of a measure of this type will create more inequity than it will save. As I said before, this certainly has had an effect on many pensioners and it will have an effect on many more. But what concerns me is the worry and concern of these pensioners when they come into my office. It is important that the government make sure that the feelings of the pensioners are taken care of, because the last thing we want to do is cause them to worry about their future.

Finally, I think it is about time that we once again looked into the matter of health care for pensioners. Before the last election, the coalition had a policy whereby pensioners could have access to private health facilities. I think that was very important. How often do we have people approaching us and saying, `I've been waiting to have a hip replacement for 18 months and I'm in terrible pain. I can't get into a public hospital.'? That is another area which we have to look at, as far as our aged people and our pensioners are concerned. We have to try to work out some way that we can free up the health system so that these people who need to have elective surgery can get into those institutions, have that surgery and get themselves out of the tremendous pain that they must be feeling.

It is with a great deal of pleasure that I speak on this matter. I could speak for hours on the matter of our elderly citizens. There is so much that can be said, but more importantly so much that has to be done. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion is seconded and I reserve my right to speak.

—I welcome the motion by the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) which concerns the government's provisions for older Australians. I welcome this motion because it provides the opportunity to outline some of the initiatives which the government has put in place in the last few years and to emphasise the priorities which this government gives to aged care.

PARA.TAB: When speaking of older Australians, we are covering a wide range of citizens of this country. One could ask, `Who is an older Australian?'. The Older Women Network starts its membership at the age of 50. The Association of Independent Retirees comprises people sometimes even younger who have taken retirement packages in their late 40s right through to persons in their 60s and 70s.

We must also acknowledge that many older Australians live long and fulfilling lives, and are well able to look after themselves and give back a great deal to the community. On the other hand, many older Australians spend the last few years of their lives in aged hostels and nursing homes. Australia has an excellent reputation throughout the world for the standard of its aged care. Having said this, I acknowledge that some of our nursing homes fall below the standards which we would desire, but the government is doing much to encourage improvement and rebuilding through its funding programs.

The words `security' and `certainty' seem to be paramount in the honourable member's motion. They can often be interpreted as not wanting change. My experience of the older people I have met in my electorate is quite different. For example, many older women who find themselves alone in their later years prove to be extremely adventurous, taking on new careers, training programs and voluntary work. Many of these women are also active in political life. A recent example is the action taken by two elderly women in my electorate who, in protest at the closing of a local bank, chained themselves to its doors. For many of these women their lives in the past have been centred on caring for a husband and children. When they are freed of these burdens, many of them blossom into areas they have not hitherto considered.

However, I realise that the honourable member's motion relates mainly to financial security and certainty, and the government has certainly not been wanting in this regard. Superannuation is something which has not been universal in the past and has often been the domain of the rich. I commend the government for ensuring that in future all working Australians will be covered by superannuation in their retirement. I am glad that the honourable member for Riverina agrees that this is a good policy. I share his concerns about the current administration of the program, particularly in relation to some of the funds. I, too, have had people coming to see me about the dreadful situation where they have been at a job for a short time and have found that all their contributions have gone in administration. But I am sure the government has taken note of that and that this issue will be further considered.

For those who have the benefits of superannuation when they retire, there are a number of choices. Many people place their superannuation into managed investments. The government has acknowledged that, due to low interest rates, the return on these investments has dropped for many people. For this reason, last year the government made the income and assets limits for independent retirees more flexible, thus enabling more people to be eligible for part pensions. One of the most significant changes in this policy is the provision to all recipients of part pensions, regardless of how small those pensions are, of full fringe benefits such as concessions on rates, electricity, telephone, transport, motor vehicle registration and pharmaceutical benefits. Most of these fringe benefits were available from April 1993.

The seniors health card, shortly to be introduced, will be available to all people of pensionable age whose taxable incomes are below the pension cut-off point but who have not previously been eligible because of the assets test. This will entitle low income non-pensioners to purchase pharmaceuticals and hearing aids at the same concessional rate as pensioners. For those who remain in their homes of long standing but wish to carry out maintenance or improvements, the home equity conversion loans scheme provides an opportunity for loans which will not have to be repaid until the owners permanently vacate their home. I know of many older people in my electorate who have gladly taken up this offer. Another new initiative by this government is the introduction of the dental health program, which provides emergency services and some basic and preventive care to holders of health care cards.

As I previously mentioned, Australia has a fine record in the field of aged care. The home and community care program, HACC, which was introduced in the mid-1980s, provides care for older people in their own homes, thus alleviating or postponing the time when admission to a nursing home may be necessary. In the 1993-94 budget there was an increase in the number of community aged care packages, which provide hostel level care in people's own homes. The increase has been from five to 7.5 packages per 1,000 people aged 70 or more. Further funding has been provided to establish grants to help community organisations which provide aged care to disadvantaged communities. The budget is also providing through the aged care programs respite care for those who are being cared for at home by relatives or other carers. What did the opposition plan in its much vaunted Fightback package for these older Australians? It planned to impose a 15 per cent GST on all the essentials of their lives: rates, electricity, gas, water, clothes and fares. So much for certainty and security.

All of these government initiatives which I have mentioned have been designed to improve financial security and access to services to older Australians. They build on major retirement income reforms of the past few years and are part of the continuing process of adapting the delivery of services and income support to best meet the needs and the capacities of a community as a whole. However, the government has recognised that the ways in which eligibility for pensions and other benefits is assessed is often complex, particularly in relation to income and assets tests. For this reason, the government has commissioned an independent review of pension income and assets tests which will fully examine both the policies and processes undertaken by the government.

Last week I and some of my colleagues met the consultant who will be leading the team which is undertaking this review.I feel sure that its examination of the situation will be thorough and the outcomes will be positive. I have encouraged older people in my electorate to present submissions to the review. I certainly call on other members to do likewise. The consultants will be carrying out forums and contact groups with older people from a wide variety of communities. I think it will be very good for them to hear directly from those people instead of or in addition to representations made by local members.

Devising policies which will suit all older Australians is an almost impossible task. As I have mentioned previously, people within these age categories find themselves in a wide range of situations and activities. I have several constituents well into their 80s who are keen to revolutionise many aspects of the way government works and to change particular policies. They could hardly be regarded as little old ladies and men sitting back in rocking chairs needing a blanket for security.

My encounters with women in the Older Women Network certainly bear out this situation. Many of these women are embarking on new adventures of travel and careers and fulfilling the ambitions which were never allowed them in the past. As an older woman myself, I had no qualms about taking on a new career as a member of parliament at an age when many people are retiring.

TALK.START.PARA: —And an excellent member of parliament.

—Thank you. I think the prime lesson we as members of parliament all need to learn is to listen to those people in our electorates, to listen to their opinions and what they consider to be their needs. We will not always be able to please all of them, but only by listening will we be able to respond effectively. This government will continue its commitment to caring for older Australians in need and requiring a contribution from those who are not. This is equitable, it requires change and I make no apology for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are all aware, older Australians are the fastest growing sector of the population and planning for their economic and social future is critical. Such consideration should include early retirement, long-term unemployment, our deficient health system, the ad hoc approach to superannuation and the disgraceful treatment of those who attempt to provide for themselves. Numerous reports indicate that Australia must do something now. Ageing Australians have no confidence in their security as they face the future. Major reform is needed.

PARA.TAB: EPAC's latest report Australia's ageing society predicts that the number of aged people will rise from 1.9 million in 1991 to more than five million by the year 2051 when more than one person in five will be over the age of 65. There will be a sixfold increase in people aged 80 or over, from 373,000 to more than two million by 2051. According to one of the report's authors Ross Clare, this means that the proportion of the over-80s will jump from 2.2 per cent in 1991 up to eight per cent in 2051. Understandably, it is this age group which calls upon a disproportionate amount of resources via the public purse. The report also said that by 2051 part pensions will be needed to provide for about 75 per cent of the aged who will not be able to rely on adequate superannuation pay-outs.

The EPAC report also raised serious implications for health care with total health care spending likely to increase from $29 billion in 1991 to $126 billion by 2051, with more than half of this spent on the elderly. Elderly Australians recognise that their health deteriorates with age. They are the ones who seek affordable private health insurance so that they can feel secure in the knowledge that they can have their choice of doctor and hospital in their time of need. Currently, they are faced with increasing premiums, but if they opt out they join public hospital queues. The so-called Richardson reforms currently under discussion do not address their problems.

It is all too easy when assessing health policy to see these people as statistics. In my own electorate I speak to pensioners and other financially disadvantaged older people who do without what many would call the necessities of life so that they can maintain private health insurance. For them, health care is then predictable.

Australians are poor savers. To ensure that adequate funds are set aside for retirement requires a major cultural shift in attitude. However, the aged should not be seen as a burden on society. The total wealth of those retirees over 55 has been estimated at more than $200 billion. The elderly also provide significant financial and child-care assistance to their families and the bulk of care services to their fellow aged. Elderly wives and husbands make up 40 and 33 per cent respectively of the carer population, while daughters and sons represent only 15 and five per cent.

A 1982 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure stressed the need to redress the funding imbalance whereby institutional care was more heavily used than community based care. This resulted in the establishment of the HACC program in 1985. HACC aims to provide a range of integrated services allowing the frail aged to live in their own homes.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, of which I am a member, has been conducting a public inquiry into HACC programs. A discussion paper has been released which raises many critical issues impacting upon our growing elderly population in their retirement. It says that it is clear there is a perception among consumers and providers of HACC services that some significant deficiencies remain in the integration and identity of the program and that these deficiencies limit the accessibility and effectiveness of HACC. It goes on to say that the committee has heard consistently that demand for HACC services far exceeds supply and that the gap is increasingly due to continued reductions in the rate of growth of HACC funding.

If the HACC program, along with other programs providing assistance to the aged, is to be in a position to respond to the changes ahead over the next 50 or 60 years, some sensible planning must take place. The paper highlights issues such as the availability of volunteer carers, the movement of traditional carers into the work force, the level of involvement which should be expected from the aged in caring for spouses and relatives, the appropriateness of shifting the balance of care to the community and the level of financial responsibility the aged should take for themselves.

The age pension is seen as the cornerstone of independence in the retirement of older Australians, but there is now universal acknowledgment that it is cost prohibitive to provide a pension to all retirees regardless of income and assets. The long-term objective is for retirement income to ease the burden on age pension payments, which means that Australians must be encouraged to save and plan for their retirement. But this government sends all the wrong messages. The recent decision to treat unrealised capital gains on shares as pension income is the worst example of this. This unfair legislation implemented last September has discriminated against those elderly people who have displayed the necessary virtues of thrift, virtue and enterprise and planned for their retirement. The Australian Stock Exchange has described the legislation as flawed in principle, flawed in application and discriminatory against investment in listed shares.

Along with its changed treatment of managed investments, the bottom line is that part pensioners are given a conflicting message: squander your savings and sell your assets and then you will qualify for a pension. Counting rises in share values as income has caused untold uncertainty and financial hardship for thousands of independent retirees and part pensioners around Australia. Those who plan and seek independent retirement should not be penalised or disadvantaged as disincentives will push people into welfare dependency.

Discrimination does exist. Single pensioners pay no tax up to a threshold of $10,600 while those funding their own retirement pay no tax up to a threshold of $5,400. The FitzGerald report on national savings talked about the need to boost private savings in Australia. This requires clear policy direction about superannuation. The EPAC report suggested that a superannuation guarantee charge may not suit the least industrially powerful—women, self-employed and those who work on a casual basis—as it is geared only to those fortunate to have a typical male working life.

Furthermore, there is a growing queue of around 300,000 long-term unemployed, with the gulf widening between the haves and the have-nots. What happens to the unemployed in their 50s with another two or three decades to live who are cast into early retirement and forced to live on their savings? What happens to women who spend fewer years than men in the work force and often have casual or part-time employment? They see their superannuation nest egg being eroded by superannuation fees.

Retirement income policy objectives need to be rethought. What about the Commonwealth government's own huge unfunded superannuation commitment to government employees which totals over $8 billion or $2,200 for every Australian? The FitzGerald report makes it clear that a large percentage of Australian baby boomers will not be prepared for retirement and this will place extra pressure on Australia's social security program. Our ageing population seeks predictability and security. For them, the rules keep changing.
A 55-year-old recently widowed woman from Clearview in my electorate writes with anger of her current situation. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been placed on Job-Search, thus facing five years of searching for employment (two jobs and one visit per fortnight to DSS). The irony of my situation is that when I married in 1964, I was obliged to leave my Federal Government job as married women were not employed by the Government at that time. Now, having brought up a family and cared for my husband during his years of illness, I am obliged to go out and seek work at 55 years of age. Yes, I am angry. $30 million appears to have been given away with abandon to minor sports clubs across Australia, while women like myself whose husbands have recently died must now face the continuing humiliation of having to apply for work when they know they have little hope and we must do this until we are sixty years of age.

Elderly Australians could be excused for thinking that this present government, which has used taxpayers' money as ALP campaign slushfunds, is more intent on its own political survival than their security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to speak on the motion—the need to provide security and certainty for older Australians. Because of the case of someone who quite recently has tested our own government services—not me, I might add, but through my family circumstances—I can only say that there are many services out there for people in need. Australia is recognised as one of the few countries in the world that has a non-insurance based pension system. That particular aspect of our system is brought into question very often.

PARA.TAB: We all know—and we are delighted—that women in particular in our community have access to superannuation, longer-term employment, permanent employment, equal pay and all the other changes which have come about in the last 30 years and which have enabled them to provide better for their older years. However, these changes have come too late for many women currently in the pension system. Despite that, we have seen a continuing rise in the numbers of those on the pension. While nobody suggests that the pension brings wealth or whatever, many people I talk to tell me that it provides the kind of income support which they never dreamed of when their husbands were working.

Many senior citizens have the ability to access senior citizens clubs, pensioner leagues and various other groups and have become one of the largest consumer groups. They are now being targeted for travel, social life and other things. A travel industry has been developed for senior citizens, which enables them to travel around Australia. Many moteliers, bus companies and other parts of the tourist industry are focusing entirely on that older group of people. They have some financial security and are in a position to have leisure time. When people on the other side talk about the need for security and certainty, it is necessary to look very carefully at the kinds of payments which are available—the kinds of payments the aged and veterans pensions bring, and some of the other payments which have been made over the years to our war widows and to the elderly in our community.

Health care is another area that brings certainty to the ageing community. In Medicare, Australia indisputably has one of the best health care systems in the world. For very many of our senior citizens the access to Medicare means that there is no financial outlay and there is no question of being treated. With the development of the public health sector and demands on that, while I recognise that there are some waiting times for elective surgery, when people have strokes or serious heart conditions or cancer or whatever, they are taken into the system and provided with the whole range of services that are part of our Medicare system. Indeed, a recognition of the demand for the health card has come through much of the lobbying that was done by the senior citizens' groups and pensioner leagues over that time.

As we know, from 1 July 1994, the Commonwealth seniors health card will give non-pensioner retirees access to the same Commonwealth health benefits that pensioners now get through their pensioner concession card. Holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card will get listed pharmaceuticals at the concessional price, cheaper rates on hearing aides and access to a two-phase dental service under the new Commonwealth dental health scheme. The card will benefit retired people who would qualify for an age pension under income test rules but who do not receive a pension because the values of their assets exceeds the assets test limit. The card will also benefit people who are entitled to get a small age pension but who choose not to claim it for personal reasons. Concessions offered under the seniors card are less generous than the full range available to pensioners in recognition of the higher level of assets owned by non-pensioner retirees. This initiative is a recognition that one of the major concerns for people in their later years is the whole question of health.
Medicare as a system is prized and the health care system is prized. The whole issue of the health care card and access to doctors and pharmaceuticals is crucially important.

Perhaps not quite so well known, but also part of Medicare, is the funding that goes to public hospitals to provide that level of support for people in their own homes, be it through the community liaison home visits or through some of the programs for carers. Much of that is funded by the hospitals and home care service through our Medicare system. That enables people to leave hospital and go home but to have a level of care that ensures that they have a certain amount of independence. As well as that, they also have a better opportunity of recovering, if not to full health, certainly to a situation whereby they can manage in their own homes. All of us know that the research points very clearly to the fact that people who are ill and who return to their own homes will recover considerably more quickly because they find things familiar, they are in better surroundings and they are less distressed by the foreignness and alienness that sometimes comes from being in hospitals, no matter how caring and how wonderful the staff really are.

One of the other major programs which receive funding is the home and community care program which very many people have access to. It provides an enormous amount of certainty. While it has been suggested that there are perhaps holes in that program, all of us would recognise that there is always a need to do more. We need to acknowledge the thousands and thousands of people who are provided for and the carers who receive respite under the home and community care program.

In looking at the question of security and certainty for older Australians, we need to look at the way in which they are valued and recognised within our community. Sometimes we spend a lot of time on the negatives rather than the positives. The volunteer work which is done—which often goes unrecognised—means that the expertise of many of our senior citizens is being passed on. In this regard I mention particularly a number of programs that are running in schools, including the adopt a granny or grandfather program

SPEECH.PARA: and the listening to reading program. Enormous numbers of senior citizens are involved. Some devote as little as an hour a week, many devote considerably more time as they become immersed and enmeshed in the life of the children whom they are assisting.

PARA.TAB: For children who do not have grandparents or older people close to them, the program means that they have different kinds of role models and that they have access to people to whom they normally would not have had access. Senior citizens themselves are making a very valuable contribution and providing a kind of security and certainty in their own community because they recognise that there are dozens of other people who care for them and care about them.

We have already heard one honourable member talk about the whole issue of nursing homes and the charter of rights which goes with it. I think it is very important for those people who are in nursing homes or in residential care to be assured that their rights as individuals are guaranteed and protected and for us, as a government and as a community, to recognise that. That will also provide security and certainty because they can expect to be treated in a particular way. The nursing home standards also provide that security and certainty by ensuring that these people will be treated and that their care will be of a very high quality.

We have also heard about some of the other programs that are running in our community. The Older Women Network has huge numbers of women throughout Australia networking together, supporting each other and participating in a whole range of other activities such as discussing health issues and the way in which they can best be addressed for individuals and for groups in the community, providing the kind of cultural life and times which they bring to our wider community, and simply supporting each other and providing the support which all those organisations provide. TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to rise in the House today to support the motion so ably moved by my colleague the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). This House, and indeed the parliament of Australia, has a moral obligation to ensure security and certainty for older Australians, for those planning their retirement and for those who have already entered their retirement years. The honourable member was correct in saying that there is an urgent need to address this issue. We are all aware that the Australian population is ageing. We are also aware of the need to provide security in terms of accommodation, support and, I might add, fair treatment under the social security system.

PARA.TAB: We have a moral obligation to provide support to our older population, not only because they have a right to be cared for in a compassionate society but also because we owe them for their decades of service, effort and sacrifice which have helped to mould Australia and which have provided, in my opinion, the best living environment in the world. I remind my colleagues on both sides of the House of the debt that this nation owes the Australian men and women who fought with pride under our national flag—the national flag that the Labor government is seeking to scrap. Those people fought to protect our security, freedom and way of life. Quite frankly, it is an outrageous tragedy that many of these people today feel shunned, ignored and forgotten by the Labor government.

Recently I conducted a survey of aged care facilities in the electorate of Fisher, the fastest growing electorate in Australia. Sadly, I was not surprised at the results. Some nursing homes and hostels have acute waiting lists—that is, urgent cases—of more than 40 people with many more listed as non-urgent. For instance, the Caboolture RSL War Veterans Home has almost as many people on its waiting list as it has beds. Major problems also exist on Bribie Island, in the city of Caloundra and throughout the rest of the electorate. The Caboolture War Veterans Home has both nursing home and hostel facilities available. About one-third of hostel residents require nursing home care, but they cannot be transferred as there are no beds available.

These homes throughout Australia provide quality care for our aged population, but they are fighting an uphill battle against staffing and funding cuts. Nursing home officials express concern about the increasing pressure being placed on the public hospital system as a result of their limited resources. Of course, honourable members would know about the absolutely disgraceful situation existing at the moment where many of our retired people, many of our pensioners, are in public hospital waiting queues. In my area the queues for some elective surgery are as long as four years. I have spoken to specialists who tell me that people are dying on those waiting lists as they wait for so-called elective surgery which in many cases is necessary to correct excruciating medical conditions.

The coalition had as part of its policy prior to the March election last year making private health cover deductible to enable people to take out that cover and reduce public hospital waiting lists. This would have meant that public hospital facilities would have been available to those Australians who needed them, those pensioners who needed them, and people would not have had to wait, as they presently do, for up to four years to get into a public hospital. The government stands condemned for ignoring those retired people, those pensioners, who are presently treated so shabbily. If we do not act now to provide for Australians planning for their retirement, this situation will simply worsen.

The coalition has repeatedly called for more nursing home beds throughout the country, increased home care resources for our elderly and more community based facilities for our ageing population. Our ageing population has received from the government something entirely different. They have suffered, they continue to suffer, and their plight remains ignored. Those older Australians who planned for their retirement by accumulating shares or investments—that is, who saved for their future—have done so only to discover that this Labor government treats unrealised capital gains on shares and investments as income, and therefore many are not entitled to a full, or even a part, pension.

The financial plight of many of these people is now desperate. I would like, in the remaining seconds available to me, to call upon this government not to look upon retired people as people who can be shunned, people who can be ignored, or people who are to be treated with monumental contempt, but to look at the contribution that Australia owes to those retired people, the contribution that Australia owes to pensioners, and make sure that they in fact get much better treatment than the government has subjected them to over the last 11 years. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining in this debate on retirement incomes I indicate my support for the motion, but I do so in the knowledge that there has been absolutely no evidence whatsoever of any policy position having been put by opposition members in their contributions. They all outlined negative comments with regard to the government's performance for older Australians and the planning of retirement incomes, but they have absolutely no policy substance themselves. They have lots of criticisms about what they believe the Australian government should be doing and how dreadful they claim we are being with regard to our treatment of older Australians, but they cannot tell us what they would do. I note also that they failed to remind people about some of the other very negative and nasty things that were in their policy platform going into the last election: the way in which they would have cut some $10 billion off social security payments to all Australians, including older Australians, which would have done a great deal to harm future prospects for older Australians.

PARA.TAB: We have to get a bit of balance in this debate. We have heard contributions already this afternoon from the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm), who outlined in their excellent addresses some of the very positive contributions that the government has made to planning retirement incomes and to planning a well-balanced and age-targeted retirement policy. I acknowledge that there have been problems with some of the policy agendas that have been put in place, particularly with regard to the managed investments and shares question. There have been some consequences of those actions that have led to calls of unfairness, and that matter needs to be reviewed. The government has responded to that by establishing a comprehensive review into the pensioner income and assets test. We have appointed a firm of consultants, who will be going through and looking at all elements of incomes and assets test and will be consulting widely throughout Australia to get as comprehensive a picture as possible of what should be happening, what the current position is, how it is impacting on people, and how to make the income and assets tests fairer, simpler and more equitable so that all Australians are treated equally.

That comprehensive program will run through till about September. It is anticipated that the report will be completed by the end of September. It is at that stage we can start asking the opposition what its position might be in the planning of retirement incomes because apparently, at this stage, it has no policy whatsoever and cannot enlighten this House as to how it would care for older Australians. I believe that that is the crucial question here. We have a government that has made major achievements in planning for older Australians.

—It may be a cliche that those who are ignorant of history are destined to repeat it, but it is nevertheless true. I issue a warning to the Australian public and, in particular, to the coalition parties: Senator Evans's threats to change the proportional voting system of the Senate in order to eliminate minority parties have frightening echoes from history. In 1933 the Nazis were frustrated at not having control of the German parliament. They talked other right-wing parties into joining with them to form a majority to expel the communists. The reduction of seats then gave the Nazis a clear majority and, as they say, the rest is history.

PARA.TAB: At the time Germany had proportional voting, much the same as the Australian Senate, in which the public's wishes are reflected in the number of seats. In contrast, the single-member electorates used by this House have always resulted in massive distortions of the public's will. If Germany had had our single-member electorate system, the Nazis would have won virtually all seats in 1933.

Senator Evans should be condemned in the strongest possible terms for his blatant threats to subvert democracy to achieve minority control of the Senate. It is almost unbelievable that a senior government member would publicly parade such arrogance. He has no place as a minister of this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noticed with interest in today's newspaper that there was a call by the new president of Young Labor that the socialist objectives be removed from the planks of the ALP.
—Have they got some success at last?

—It begs some interesting questions. What does it really mean? Does it mean that the ALP is going to be the only democratic socialist party in the world without a socialist objective—which does not believe in socialism? That is highly unlikely, of course. What does it mean for all those true believers, who in the past have toiled ceaselessly towards their socialist objective and who are now going to find that the party they have worked for—

PARA.TAB: Mr Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moreton, I think you are a bit past Young Labor.

—They are going to find that their party now reneges on the central plank of its objectives. After all, what is a democratic socialist party for, other than to introduce socialism? I see that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) is in the House. Does her new labelling system mean that the ALP will now be labelled `free from any socialist flavour'? Is it consistent with other types of movements or changes the ALP has introduced? For instance, the Australian Defence Force is the only defence force in the world that would have to seek an environmental impact statement before firing a shot in anger. This is the only government in the world that has a policy of restricting Christmas carols for children in government subsidised child-care centres. This call from Young Labor is like everything else—a bit more window-dressing, trying to pull the wool over the eyes of the unfortunate voters out there to convince them that the ALP is no longer socialist. (Time expired)

On 26 March all local government authorities go to the polls in Queensland. A vital election will be fought in the city of Brisbane. I can assure all members of the House that the excellent Labor administration, led by Lord Mayor Jim Soorley, will be returned with an increased majority. Although we talk in this House about the Liberals having real leadership problems, with four or five contenders seeking the top position, in the Brisbane City Council the Liberal opposition does not have a leader at all. One would not even know who he was. No-one knows who he is. He has made no policy positions known. TALK.START.PARA: —Some honourable members might have noticed in yesterday's Herald-Sun a report stating that the Macquarie Dictionary monitors Hansard to see what words in current day usage of the language it might incorporate. I believe that Macquarie Dictionary should look very closely at a couple of things. First of all, it should consider the reference made last Tuesday by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly), in answer to a question from me, when she started talking about `Medigate'—a new word. We have not found out exactly what it means yet, but the word has been introduced.

PARA.TAB: I went to a dinner meeting in my electorate on Saturday night and I was handed this little story by a lady from my electorate who said, `Are you aware that board'—with big heavy underlining of `that board'—`is no longer a whiteboard but a Kellyboard'. She added, `This is according to my seven-year-old granddaughter'. It seems that clearly this word has now been taken on amongst the younger generation. When we have seven-year-olds referring to whiteboards as `Kellyboards', we clearly have a new word to put in the Australian language. I hope those going through the Hansard, looking for new words to put in the Macquarie Dictionary, might consider looking at those two words.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aftermath of the shocking, inhumane and torturing murder of Ebony Simpson of Bargo has shown how little emphasis has been given to the rights of victims of such crimes and their families. It is not just the bereavement. The aftermath means mental anguish with all the rehashing of tragedy and terror for the bereaved family.

PARA.TAB: The accused has support and advice, but what of the victims? They must live through the ongoing pain without adequate consideration and support. I appeal to state and federal Attorneys-General and to justice and community service ministers to initiate action to assist the victims of crime and the families of victims. I seek dignity for them. The innocent have suffered enough from the deranged, from terrorisers and from thugs. Ebony Simpson's mother has spoken to me of her own experiences. They are beyond those that reasonable people should have to bear.

The Simpsons would like to leave this terrible event behind them, just as other victims and families of victims of assault, abuse, rape and murder would. Our system of justice will not allow that. It ought to allow justice for all—the victims as well as the accused. We should not ignore those who are innocent, who have been hurt and who desperately need community support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pick up where the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) and I left off last week in relation to industry policy. It seems that we both want sophisticated intervention into economic activity. Where we might disagree is on the definition of `sophisticated intervention'. Intervention, for example, as practised by the French, may have a role in protecting that part of the economy we call culture. If we had done this in the 1950s, the average baby boomer might have grown up with an independent mind—not one fashioned by the dominance of US trade. Our actors might also have been able to find regular work.

PARA.TAB: What imports will we replace? What products will the government purchase? What is the role of government purchasing in industry development? Those are exactly the questions which should be debated. Surprisingly, it was the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) who mounted the stump to plead the case against rampant free trade.

The honourable member for Melbourne argues that the 1980s were characterised by a move away from a hitherto unsophisticated approach to industry development. Professor Frank Stillwell wryly reminds us that the decade has been characterised by the transfer of wealth from labour to capital and the channelling of that wealth into speculation, luxury consumption and overseas borrowing rather than into the expansion and modernisation of Australian industry. Debunking the mythology surrounding GATT and instituting interventionist policies derived from a combination of social, cultural and economic imperatives is the task at hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aftermath of the reign of Johannes Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland as detailed in the Fitzgerald inquiry reveals the great need for governments to separate themselves from administration, the obvious application of the separation of power. In Victoria at the present moment, we have a Liberal Party government applying the Fightback principles to government and we now find that appointments are being made by the executive. There is no longer any perceived need to advertise; there is no longer a perceived need to put forth a selection criteria for the position so that people can understand what sort of a job is going to be taken.

PARA.TAB: We have the same event occurring which occurred in Queensland under Johannes Bjelke-Petersen. We have Premier Johannes Kennett, quite frankly, emulating those dreadful events which occurred in Queensland. It is time that the Liberal Party of Australia got down to Victoria and advised Johannes Kennett that there is indeed something called the separation of power and that the premier should not be seen to be involving himself in the business affairs of people who are involved in government. The premier should not be having secret meetings with his mates who are bidding for public contracts. The premier should be appointing people on a public selection criteria, not snooping in the cabinet and putting people in the post without advertising those positions publicly and enabling people to apply. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This weekend in my electorate Jim Whiting, a pharmacist in the village of Berwick, brought to my attention that pharmacists are now paying 21 1/2 per cent sales tax on labels that go on prescription pharmaceuticals. We heard a lot of rot during the last election campaign about taxes on milk, baby bottles and bread but we did not hear about the insidious, sneaky wholesale sales taxes imposed by this illegitimate Labor government, did we?

PARA.TAB: Everything it touched it wanted to tax—and spend. The left wing of the Labor Party keeps talking about the jobs levy. It is nothing but a tax—a tax on working Australians to pay for inappropriate programs that will not provide one job for Australians. We are now paying tax on pharmaceuticals. Those Australians who are pensioners, retired, have young children or families in the middle ground of Australia are all paying 21 1/2 per cent sales tax on the labels that go on the drugs that are necessary to help keep them well.

It is unquestionably this Labor government that sneaks around the corner and brings in sneaky taxes—not up-front, not to be seen, not straight forward so that the Australian public knows what it is paying. It hides the taxes and puts taxes on everything where they are not visible and sustainable. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members are no doubt horrified, as I am, at the continued butchery of the English language. Recently, newspapers throughout the country published a story about a group of Queensland parents which is attempting to ban the use of the Macquarie Thesaurus.

PARA.TAB: The reason is that synonyms for a word such as `mother', according to the Macquarie editors, include: bad person, bad thing, creator, monastic, old people, parent, procreator, care for, reproduce. Synonyms for `dry' include: bone dry, dry as a bird's . . . , as well as a degrading reference to nuns.

The Catholic Church has called for the publishers of the Macquarie Thesaurus to remove obscene and unnecessary descriptions from further editions. But publishers have defended their decision on the grounds that they are part of the Australian colloquial language. One Catholic nun was quoted as saying that the Macquarie Dictionary has published colloquial, vulgar and indecent language since its first edition in 1981 and said the reference to nuns in the thesaurus was a reflection of the sick society in which we live.

I seriously question the use of such a reference book in our schools. The dictionary, which describes the word `mother' in the way that I have said, can hardly be referred to as a suitable reference guide. Honourable members would also be aware that the Macquarie Dictionary, the dictionary of Australian English, is the preferred reference for Hansard reporters and that this dictionary replaced the Oxford Dictionary some time ago.

The marked difference between the two styles has been brought to my attention recently, particularly in terms of spelling. For example, the spelling of `amok' is no longer a-m-o-k, but a weird new mutation: a-m-u-c-k.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have today received the following letter from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) offering her resignation from her portfolio. It says this:

SPEECH.PARA: My dear Prime Minister,

I am writing to you regarding the debate over the community, cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. As I have consistently stated, I have not misled the parliament and there has been no impropriety, fraud or corruption associated with this program.

However, the massive parliamentary and media focus on this issue is diverting national attention from issues critical to the future development of Australia, including major issues within my own portfolio. I believe that if this speculation were to continue it would only harm the federal government, and I do not wish to see damage done to the government.

I have had the privilege to serve as a minister for almost seven years. I have therefore decided to offer you my resignation from the portfolio of Environment, Sport and Territories and as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women.

It is with deep regret that I will be recommending to the Governor-General that Mrs Kelly's resignation be accepted. Mrs Kelly has been a most valuable member of the ministry for almost seven years. She has given great service to the government and to her country in the portfolios she has occupied. By her example and by her efforts on their behalf, she has done much to increase opportunities and serve the interests of Australian women.

PARA.TAB: The minister has offered her resignation because she believes that the charges laid against her by the opposition and in the media are causing an unacceptable distraction from the government's policy agenda and harm to the government. I want to emphasise that Mrs Kelly's resignation does not constitute acceptance of the claims of corruption, fraud or other improprieties which have been made against her by the opposition and in the media; nor does it justify the barrage of personal abuse and misrepresentation to which she has been subjected.

However, the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts finds evidence of inadequacy in the administrative procedures relating to the distribution of funds in the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program, though it confirms there has been no suggestion of fraud. It is for the reason it states that I have accepted Mrs Kelly's resignation. I will make a statement on ministerial arrangements later today.

TALK.START.PARA: —On indulgence, Mr Speaker: it is clearly about time that this decision has been taken. There has been an overwhelming case made against the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) on the grounds of incompetence—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!

—And on the grounds that she misled the parliament on three separate occasions as early ago as late November. The matter does not stop here. A lot of other people are involved in this sports rorts affair and cover-up. We will persist with our call for a full independent inquiry that goes to the bottom of this sordid affair because, where some $30 million worth of taxpayers money has been in effect used as a slush fund as part of the re-election campaign of the ALP to buy votes in key marginal seats, the people of Australia deserve and will get, as far as we are concerned, a full explanation as to how this occurred and who was involved.

PARA.TAB: To our mind, we have to doubt that the minister acted alone. Clearly, she had the full support of her senior ministerial colleagues, the full support of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and probably the full support of the cabinet. I therefore emphasise that it is absolutely essential that we have a full independent inquiry into this matter so, once and for all, the people of Australia are given a complete explanation as to how that slush fund was set up and administered and they can have some assurance that it will not happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on your indulgence: the strength and veracity of the claims of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) have to be tested against the $30 million he proposed without analysis for a university in the state of Queensland—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!
—Therefore, cheap political points can only be made when the person making them is clean of the very sin that he charges Mrs Kelly with.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Former Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given that it has now been five weeks since the honourable member for Maribyrnong resigned from his ministry and a week since the conclusion of the Australian Federal Police investigation into the Griffiths affair, why is the Prime Minister stalling on the establishment of an independent inquiry into the Griffiths affair?

—It is not a matter of stalling. Mr Griffiths actually asked me for the inquiry. He has been in the interim cleared by the police of any wrongdoing, but a person associated with his office is subject currently to police investigation and we were taking some advice from the Australian Federal Police about the progress of that inquiry.

PARA.TAB: For my part, I do not see any problem in proceeding with an inquiry of the kind which Mr Griffiths sought—that is, one which examines his political conduct—and at the appropriate time, when I am sure that I do not think police investigations will be compromised, I will so announce it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister please inform the House of the outcome of Friday's meeting of the Council of Australian Governments and the significance of the decisions reached at that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday the premiers, chief ministers and I reached an historic agreement that will open up the non-traded sector of the Australian economy to the same sorts of competitive pressures that our manufacturing, traded services, mining and agricultural industries have been facing for some time.

PARA.TAB: The reforms that will flow from the agreement we reached on competition policy will bring lower prices for consumers, a faster rate of economic growth, more jobs and more exports. Lots of dark rooms of protection and privilege in the economy will be opened up. Just as we have seen competition with telecommunications result in a dramatic reduction in STD charges and dramatically lower domestic airfares, Australians can expect to benefit from cheaper electricity and lower legal fees.

The Council of Australian Governments agreed to the principles of competition outlined in the Hilmer report. It agreed to merge the Trade Practices Commission with the Prices Surveillance Authority to form the new Australian Competition Commission. Governments will commence work immediately on the new legislation, which will be considered at the next COAG meeting in August. The council's working group on micro-economic reform has been asked to report in August on detailed proposals for reform to the maritime sector and to the legal profession.

In Hobart the premiers, chief ministers and I also endorsed a strategic framework for the efficient and sustainable reform of Australia's water industry; agreed to implement free and fair trade in natural gas by 1 July 1996—this complements the scheduled introduction of a national competitive electricity market from 1 July 1995—made further progress on the implementation of the national competitive electricity market; agreed that Commonwealth roles and responsibilities should be the main item for the agenda of the next meeting; endorsed the recommendations of the working group on Asian languages and cultures so that the comprehensive Asian languages and cultures program for schools could be implemented from 1995; with the exception of Western Australia, agreed to introduce legislation to establish the National Environment Protection Council, which will make environment protection measures in the areas of air, water, noise, hazardous waste, motor vehicle emissions and recycling; and established a working group of officials to report to the next meeting on further ways of adopting a national approach to violence against women. This was a very significant achievement and there was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, make a statement on it.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.

—That is all right about making a statement. We are making a statement now. We are telling people that all of the foreboding and all of the damning of this process, which you said would lead to confrontation and division and nothing, has produced a change of the kind which as a coalition you could not have dreamt of. All of these organisations which have been left for years—electricity, water, competitive influences in these great government business enterprises—were there right through the nearly 30 years, or 20-odd years, of coalition government in this country—30 years bar three years. It was all there waiting for someone else to do.

PARA.TAB: Let me just repeat to the opposition and to the House some of the things which were said about this change in the weekend press. The Weekend Australian said:

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement on competition policy at yesterday's Council of Australian Governments meeting was a decisive step in securing a more efficient economy. It is a breakthrough for micro-economic reform and deregulation of the economy. Governments, business and ordinary consumers will all gain.
In the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr Kitney said:

Paul Keating has pulled off a remarkable victory for the federation. By giving a little to get a lot he has started a process which may transform much of our daily lives. The premiers went to Hobart breathing fire; they left telling a very different story.
The same paper—under the heading `States back PM's reform plan'—refers to it as a `landmark agreement'. Alan Wood in the Australian says:
Another important step towards an open competitive economy with the endorsement of the principles of competition policy set out in the Hilmer committee's report.
The Canberra Times said:
The federal and state governments have taken a major step towards free trade by agreeing to make government enterprise across Australia face competition.
In the Australian Financial Review, Mr Burton says:

In one day the country's political leaders agreed to new business rules which will do more to integrate Australia's regulated state based industries into one national market than nearly a century of section 92 free trade constitutional cases.

And so it goes. It was a very significant meeting and, despite the views of the pundits—and I might say, of course, the wishes of the federal opposition—it turned out for the people of Australia to be a very positive one. The Commonwealth now with the states will work on legislation coming up for the August meeting of the Council of Australian Governments to see a national competition commission emerge with the joining of the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority, in a change which should have been made 20 years ago. As always in this country, it has been left to a Labor government to turn the place into a proper but sensible and decent market economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Many in this House welcome official statements which indicate the government's commitment to the achievement of a sovereign, independent Australia. The Prime Minister himself has consistently accused the coalition of tugging the forelock on such matters. In this context, why did the Prime Minister allow the foreign minister to flag the imposition of visa conditions on any proposed visit by Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams which shows duplicity on the issue of violence in Northern Ireland and simply mirrors the confrontationist approach of the British government? Furthermore, how does he respond to those who argue that the government's position on East Timor, like its position on Gerry Adams, shows a distinct lack of independence?

—I cannot see the draw between Australia's sovereignty of its future and any actions which Senator Evans might take about any individuals. We had a similar debate not long ago about an English professor of history who has views about the holocaust which we thought, in the interests of the Australian community, would serve no purpose whatsoever in the face of a very large Jewish community here. Many who had suffered at the hands of the government of Adolf Hitler, who were interred in concentration camps, and who had lost their families and loved ones would be confronted by somebody telling them that it did not exist and it did not happen. Governments have got to make those decisions, and Senator Evans has made a similar decision here.
—Is the Treasurer aware of claims that the government is not proceeding rapidly enough on micro-economic reform? Can he advise the House of the basis of those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen various opposition statements alleging that the recent EPAC report Economic Effects of Microeconomic Reform is an indictment of the government. For instance, the honourable member for Forrest put out a press statement headed `EPAC Report Highlights Government Failure'; the honourable member for Mayo predictably put out a press statement headed `EPAC Report Torpedoes Keating', and so on. Such statements are total nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The EPAC report attempts to calculate the macro-economic benefits of further micro-economic reform, that is, the benefits to increased gross domestic product, employment, real wages, per capita incomes and so on. In so doing it notes that Australia's micro-economic reform performance has already produced quite significant economic benefits. For instance, on page vii it states:

ANSWER.PARA: Considerable progress on microeconomic reform has been made in Australia over the past decade.
On page xii it states:

Structural reform has been in progress in Australia since the mid-1980s and, in many instances, reforms have been in advance of those in many other OECD economies. In consequence, Australia is well-placed to take major advantage of Asian dynamism and the onset of broader international economic recovery to enhance real income and job growth.

Clearly, the authors of this report think that what has happened to this stage has been good. The report goes on to say that we need to do more. Other countries are doing more, they are getting into this area, we need to do more; we agree absolutely with that.

PARA.TAB: But it is totally wrong to then assert, as the opposition does, that the additional reforms that this report goes on to look at and measure in terms of macro-economic benefits are additional to the government's program. In fact, pretty well all of them are the government's program. What the honourable member for Forrest obviously does not have any understanding about whatever is that this report models the macro-economic effect of implementing the government's micro-economic reform program. It does it sector by sector. If the honourable member bothered to read the report, he would see that that is the case. Let me take him through some of it.

What it talks about in terms of future reduction in tariffs is the government's program for tariff reductions as set out to the year 2000. In the case of shipping, it looks at reform of coastal shipping under the government's program through SIRA, the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. In relation to liner shipping, it looks at the abolition of part X of the Trade Practices Act. That is what Hilmer has reported should be abolished. We have got another report from Brazil which says not to abolish it. The government will consider its decision on that shortly.

In stevedoring the report models further gains through the current reform in the sea-land interface; I emphasise the word `current'. It refers to furthering the operations of port authorities; that gets caught up in the Hilmer discussions with the states last Friday that the Prime Minister was just discussing. Then it talks about the further efficiency of the operators which comes from the introduction of enterprise employment which we introduced. We changed the system from what it was for most of the century to a system based on enterprise employment which we have introduced and which drives efficiency.

On rail it models the process of putting rail freight on an international best practice productivity level, plus the movement to full cost recovery. That is what the National Rail Corporation is all about. It is set up on that basis. Plus, we have added three-quarters of a billion dollars in infrastructure development to assist it. So those opposite should not tell us that the model in the report is not our reform on rail. On telecommunications the report says that despite important gains to date there is more to come, and it acknowledges that the government's phased increases in competition will achieve major productivity reform. So again it is substantially our program which is talked about.

On the manufacturing sector, which should have particular relevance to the honourable member for Forrest, the report points out that the major factors driving productivity improvement are tariff reductions, our tariff reductions, plus workplace reform—which is certainly our program—plus education and training reform. All of that is in the government's agenda.

On electricity, gas and water the report says that more needs to be done, but it lies mainly with the states. We are driving the states through the COAG meeting on Friday—getting the states on side with Hilmer, which means that their electricity, gas and water authorities are open to competition and that drives efficiency improvement and increased productivity. The report says that there is nothing more to do on domestic aviation, we have basically done it all. On the CAA, it models the government's program for reform. On international aviation, it says that there may be some further changes that need to be made based on reports a few years old and it acknowledges that the government has made changes since which substantially implement that.

The report says that more needs to be done on public administration. We agree with that. It acknowledges that there have been big changes since the 1980s. We agree with that. For instance, we have now introduced agency bargaining, which will have a considerable productivity promotion effect on the Public Service.

In summary, far from demonstrating the government's failure, if one accepts the author's calculations, this report by EPAC enables us to measure in some way the benefits to flow to the Australian economy from the government's program of micro-economic reform. It shows that over the decade to 2001 we will be looking at a GDP improvement of from 12.7 per cent to 15.4 per cent and above what it would have been without that program—12 to 15 per cent—at unemployment reduced to just over five per cent by the year 2000, compared with over seven per cent without that reform program, and at real wages about seven per cent higher than they otherwise would have been. So, far from being a condemnation, this is a very good publication which demonstrates to the Australian people that the government's program of micro-economic reform is very much to their benefit and which gives some basis on which one can absolutely measure that.

But that does not mean that states rights are more important than children's rights and it does not mean that the literacy needs of young Australians miraculously change at state borders. That is why I am particularly pleased to welcome the participation of a majority of states in the review process. It is also why I deplore the Victorian government's decision not to cooperate with Dr Hill.

PARA.TAB: One can only wonder how big an Australian Sir Robert Menzies would have considered the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hayward. There is no reason at all for this to be a political matter because the right to literacy is not about politics at all; it is about ensuring that young Australians have access to the best possible educational experience. I am delighted that the review is under way, and I am sure that all Australians committed to educational excellence will support its objectives.

PETITION.TITLE: Bears: China
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears for these purposes to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the report "Human Rights and Mental Illness" released by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:

PARA.TAB: (i) Seriously consider and act upon the contents and recommendations of the report "Human Rights and Mental Illness" released by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin.
(ii) Provide an immediate, substantial and sustained increase in funding for mental health services in Australia.
(iii) Take strong and consistent action throughout Australia to stop the abuse of the human rights of the mentally ill.
(iv) Take strong and consistent action throughout Australia to stop discrimination against the mentally ill.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: 1. We believe that our current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of our Nation's history.
2. Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: a. There be no change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag
b. Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.We are opposed to the childcare guidelines issued by the National Childcare Accreditation Council and the Keating Government, and

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
We are concerned the Federal Government's proposed changes to the Postal Corporations Act will result in:

PARA.TAB: closure of post offices
increased postal charges
a lower standard of service in remote and rural areas
loss of jobs in Australia Post

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in The Australian Federal Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
1.Even as Communism disintegrating elsewhere around the globe, Vietnam's 72 million people still suffer under communist totalitarianism.

2.Although there have been some moves towards economic development by the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam in recent years, they have not led towards political liberation or improved human right records. People are imprisoned or kept under house-arrest without charge or trial for the peaceful expression of their beliefs and alternative points of view. Among them are Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, Patriarch of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam and Thich Quang Do, Thich Tri Sleu, Thich Tue Si, Thich Tri Tuu, Thich Hai Tinh, Thich Hai Tang, Thich Khong Tanh. Recently Assistant Archbishop Nguyen Van Thuan has not been allowed to return to Vietnam after his overseas tour. Other political prisoners and prisoners of conscience include Dr Nguyen Dan Que, a member of Amnesty International, Dr Doan Viet Hoat a former Assistant Vice-Chancellor of the Van Hanh University.

3.Especially the Hanoi government has arrested on 17/11/93 Mr Nguyen Dinh Huy, Dr Pham Tuong, the leaders of the Movement to Unite People and Build Democracy inside Vietnam because of their plan to organise the International Conference to develop Vietnam in Saigon. Some other members of the organisation were also arrested such as Mr Bui Kim Dinh, Mr Tran Quang Liem, Mr Nguyen Tan Tri coming to Vietnam from the United States. This is further evidence of human rights violation and communist totalitarianism. Such treatment represents a systematic attack of international standards of human rights solemnly recognised in the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights and in the Constitution of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.
Your petitioners respectfully request the House of Representatives to:
1.Urge the Hanoi government to take action to facilitate the release of all religious leaders, political prisoners and prisoners of conscience, in particular those mentioned above.
2.Urge the Hanoi government to allow all religions to independently practice and organise their religious affairs in Vietnam.

3.Call on the Australian government to press the Hanoi government to respect human rights and civil rights in Vietnam, and to take these factors into account in its consideration of the provision of economic assistance.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
(1)Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
(2)Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

(3)Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
(4)Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Off-Road Diesel Fuel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. 2. We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3. This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landcare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House that great efforts are being made to attain sustainable land use through landcare. At the present level of activity it will take in the order of 100 years to achieve a stable landscape Australia wide (based on an accepted level of necessary vegetation cover).

Whereas environmental degradation on private land in Australia needs substantial expenditure to arrest and reverse trends such as increasing salinity brought about by traditional practices of land utilisation. Such expenditure requires encouragement and some degree of support from the general population and tax payer.

We request that assistance such as tax deductibility in the order of 150 per cent on approved landcare expenditures be granted. We believe this would result in a massive re-direction of available funds towards landcare and subsequent improved sustainable land use, living standards and taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: GRIEVANCE DEBATEEx-servicemenAustralian Merchant MarinersIncome and Assets Test ReviewHomeless Youth
