SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I want to say that I am particularly concerned that hundreds of Australian ex-servicemen, who served in the Korean theatre of war, have received no recognition from the Department of Defence. A committee has been appointed to review Defence awards. I encourage the government, when the committee's report is received, to make provision for acknowledging the service of these men.

PARA.TAB: One of my constituents served on HMAS Shoalhaven during the Korean conflict in 1954-55 on 21-day patrols on five separate occasions off the west coast of Korea. This was during the Armistice period, was classed as active duty and was recognised by the RSL. But the Department of Defence never issued a service or defence medal. I believe that recognition is deserved. It is unfair that ex-servicemen are not recognised, and I ask the government to take action.

In a similar way, I draw attention to the situation regarding Australian merchant mariners who served in World War II. I note that on 18 November last year this House considered a motion, which states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) war-time mariners should be given access to the same benefits under the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 as those who served in the armed forces;
I have taken this matter up with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) who advised me as follows:

On 13 August 1993 I announced that there would be an independent review of the veterans compensation pensions system. I asked for benefits for Australian mariners to be included in the terms of reference of the review.

That review committee is due to report in March this year. I urge the government to take action, once that report is received, to extend benefits to Australian merchant mariners. I also note that the minister has said that this `would have to be considered in a budgetary context with regard to other priorities, commitments and available funds'. I hope that available funds will be found to provide justice for merchant mariners who served Australia during World War II.

PARA.TAB: I am also concerned about the Bayldon community centre in my electorate of Cowper which is providing a valuable service to the community. It has been forced to close or at least withdraw some of its valuable services because of lack of funding. It was opened two years ago under the wing of the Coffs Harbour neighbourhood centre and has been serving the suburbs of Bayldon and Toormina and also includes a department of housing estate and an imminent new subdivision to cope with 4,000 people.

The services provided have given help on legal, accountancy, tax matters, low cost typing, photocopying, assistance with job applications and emergency help and referrals—all of which are extremely valuable services for people who need help. During the past 12 months 5,000 people have been helped by this particular community's service. Its funding, which originally was under DEET's jobskills program—the jobs eligibility program—will expire at the end of this month; in other words, today. The recession funds, which came through the Coffs Harbour centre, were funded by the department of community services, but now there are no more funds. I believe it is essential that this service is able to continue and provide services for all those who are so desperately in need of help.

I am still concerned about the government's treatment of shares and the assets and income tests of pensioners, which I believe to be unfair and unjust and which involve a great deal of inequity. I acknowledge that the review of income and assets tests for social security pensioners, service pensioners and other retirees is under way at present. I encourage any member of the Australian public who is concerned about these assets and income tests to make a submission to that inquiry. Those submissions should be addressed to the Manager, Income and Assets Test Review Secretariat, Department of Social Security, PO Box 7788, Canberra Mail Centre, 2610. It is a vital question which is of importance to a great many elderly Australian people. I hope they make submissions and get the right answers coming through to improve their lot.

I am also very concerned about youth homelessness, in which there has been an enormous growth in five years. In June 1987, 942 had registered for youth homeless assistance. In 1993, just five years later, it had leapt to 10,485. That figure must be of concern to every member of this parliament and to all Australians. In some cases, I have no doubt that the Department of Social Security has actively encouraged young people to leave home. We have heard stories of young people saying, `I've had a row with mum' and the departmental officer saying, `Here's the homeless youth allowance form'. This has happened in my electorate in the last two weeks, and I do not think it is appropriate.

The youth homeless allowance is a valuable safety net and, where there is abuse of children—whether it is sexual, physical, mental or emotional—it is essential that that net is there. How widespread the encouragement from departmental officers is needs to be established and to what extent it acts as a deterrent to reconciliation of the child with the family. Therefore, like my colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), I am particularly pleased that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs is conducting an inquiry. I encourage people with experience or knowledge of incidents where the Department of Social Security's handling has not been as good as it should be to make submissions to the committee at Parliament House, Canberra. The closing date for those submissions is 15 March, so there is not a great deal of time left.

Looking at the question of families within Australia, particularly within my electorate, I am concerned about the very pressing need for an adequate and permanent Family Court counselling service in the Coffs Harbour region. There is much social dislocation, a very low average income, and the closest Family Court counselling service is 3 1/2 hours away by public transport. Circuit counselling can only do court ordered counselling, and is unable to deal with the vast numbers of voluntary referrals. Sometimes there is a six-week delay between circuits and, therefore, there can be a delay of months before counselling is available for someone who needs it. Disputes escalate which, with the aid of counselling, could perhaps be solved. They end up becoming fully fledged trials. This is a waste of resources. It is unnecessarily stressful for the children, let alone for the husband and wife who are involved in the problem.

Early crisis intervention by a counselling service can actively reduce the number of marriages which are breaking up. The area is now servicing 200,000 people and funds are desperately needed for permanent counselling for the Family Law Court. Almost all custody and access trials have proceeded past three years. Many could be avoided if skilled counselling were available. Early resolution could result in enormous savings and in less heartbreak. Above all, this would be much better for children. I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) for more funding to be provided to establish a Coffs Harbour subregistry and for additional resources for counselling, as recommended by the Senate inquiry into certain aspects of the Family Law Act.

Finally, I want to speak about the impact of fringe benefits tax on the families of clergy right around Australia. Many families of the clergy in my electorate have come to see me. They are losing the family allowance supplement because of the value of free housing provided by the church. The Anglican Diocese of Grafton has provided me with a significant amount of information, but it affects clergy of other denominations too. I am concerned that the deeming provisions on the value of housing have caused significant hardship to the clergy and their families.

Housing is a major benefit and a condition of employment for members of the clergy. They are provided rent-free accommodation. That accommodation is not used just for the family—it is used as an office for meetings, for counselling and for other parish related functions. It is certainly not just a family house. Clergy stipends are undoubtedly low, particularly when compared with the salary levels of other professionals. The clergy depend on the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The wife of one clergyman wrote to me as follows:
Incomes of clergymen are not commensurate with other professionals . . . Their families appreciate and need the FAS to make ends meet—

SPEECH.PARA: Another letter states:

The house we live in is totally paid for and owned by the parish . . . On the other hand we will never be able to buy a house as we do not have the funds to do so. We have $1600 in a special account for emergencies—eg. operation for child next year, and that is a sum total of our savings. This will never get us a deposit let alone pay off a home.

I note, too, that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) has advised that the department will be monitoring the effects of the inclusion of the value of employer provided benefits, and this needs to be done. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today to express my concern for the people of Victoria. I speak for the majority of them who are having inflicted upon them the destruction of a lifestyle built over many years. The Premier of Victoria and his tamed and trained cabinet are steadily turning Victoria into the Queensland of Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, a state of looking after your mates, corruption and intimidation.

PARA.TAB: If we start at the top and look at the members of the Premier's own government, we find that none of them can speak to certain television programs. None of them can speak on certain programs on the radio or to the newspapers. This muzzling of his own government members has spread throughout the Public Service. No public servant can speak freely. Teachers are intimidated. Public servants in unions are also affected. This rule by fear is starting to permeate the whole of the work force and this is just what the Liberals want.

After they have muzzled the Public Service, they next start on the judiciary and those in a position where they can assist the disadvantaged. Take, for example, the attack on the public prosecutor in Victoria—someone who has had the guts to take on the Police Association, John Elliott and the like. Then there is the sacking of the Equal Opportunity Commissioner, a person who fought for the disadvantaged, for migrants and for the mentally disabled. The people she protected will be left at the mercy of the members of the Kennett government, and we know what a merciful lot they are.

I have pointed out briefly how the Liberal government of Victoria has started to intimidate from the top the people of Victoria. But what annoys me more is the disregard for the majority of the people. I will give just one example of what has happened in my area. The Frankston Standard of 21 February 1994—just last week—reported:
Elvie Brown was devastated when she was told her group's funding had been cut . . . it mightn't have sounded much, but losing $4000 meant the group would struggle to stay afloat.
As president of the Frankston Multiple Sclerosis Self Help Group and herself a long time MS suffer, Mrs Brown fears people do not realise just how vital the money was to the group.
"The fact is that without that money a lot of people, myself included, are going to struggle to attend group meetings," she said.
"Everything we have worked so long and hard for is now at risk."
She said a large portion of the money was used to hire taxis to transport members to meetings.
"The group is more than 30 members strong, but many of these are virtually incapacitated and unable to transport themselves," she said.
"We have people from as far down as Mt Martha coming to our meetings. Now they aren't going to be able to come," she said.
"We are so upset about this, so upset."
The MS Self Help Group, which is not affiliated with the MS Society, was formed in 1985 after a public meeting in Seaford.
Mrs Brown said it filled an important area of need on the peninsula.
"At that time there was nothing for suffers or carers of MS," she said.
MS is a `cruel disease' which hits at the central nervous system.
"It basically short circuits messages from your brain. The messages don't arrive when they're meant to," she said. "It can deteriorate quickly, slowly or just stay the same—it depends on each person.
"Sometimes you get feeling back in a certain area—you never know from one day to the next.
"Some people are totally bedridden, others are totally paralysed. Some go blind. I've been blind twice and, luckily, got my sight back. There is no cure and they do not know the cause."

SPEECH.PARA: That shows the degree of meanness of the Liberals and it is being imposed on many groups like this all over Victoria. The Liberals have cut $4,000 from this group, money that these people use to come together to discuss their problems, money that was used for self-help. It would enable these people to get together once a month to compare notes and to talk about their problems. The Victorian Liberal government is a truly mean government.

PARA.TAB: Not only have the Liberals savaged the infrastructure put in place to assist those in need but also they will have a go at anyone who does not subscribe to their basic theories of putting profits before people or simply, `Up you, Jack, I'm all right'. I do not believe that what they are practising is acceptable. It is un-Australian. If they want to preach the policies of greed, they should be up-front about it instead of hiding behind a mask of social conscience. Their meanness knows no bounds.

Farmers who were recently devastated by floods have got nothing. They have had their schools closed, their trains taken and their councils closed. Pensioners have had their free travel during Seniors Week removed. How could anyone do that? Jeffrey Kennett did it. Pensioners have also had a $100 poll tax enforced. Electricity, gas, rates, registration, insurance, et cetera have all been dramatically increased by the Kennett Liberal government. It has cruelly not used Commonwealth funding worth $6.1 million. That money is sitting unused. Over 6,400 Victorians could miss out on vital hospital treatment, many elderly with painful complaints like needing hip replacements. They are suffering while the Kennett Liberal government tries to force more money from the Commonwealth. It is bargaining with the pain and suffering of the people of Victoria.

Victoria's public transport system is going downhill at an alarming rate. A recent report said that in 1993 tram use had declined by nine per cent; public transport buses, six per cent; and trains, nine per cent. This is just what the Liberals want. The Liberal government has done this by subsidising private bus operators, increasing public transport fares, altering timetables and frequencies of trains. It wants to hand it all over to the private bus operators who openly supported its election campaign.

Kids have had their schools closed. Kindergarten fees have increased by 200 per cent. Class sizes have increased. There have been no teachers. TALK.START.PARA: —I today wish to grieve about the media and how it has betrayed women in politics. But I cannot let go the comments made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who just preceded me in the debate. He has used the coward's castle for speculation and innuendo and brought into this House the story of the tragic death of Penny Easton. Why has he, with such moral indignation, stood before the parliament now? Why did he not do it four years ago? It has taken four years to bring his indignation to boiling point. Is it only because of an imminent by-election in the seat of Western Australia?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. If the honourable member for Prospect checks the Hansard, she will find that I made the same speech at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I say that the only thing that has inflamed him to come forward with moral indignation is the by-election.

PARA.TAB: My grievance today is about the way that the media trivialises women in politics. I suppose that after hearing the honourable member for O'Connor I really cannot blame the media at times. Such trivialisation is particularly evident to anyone who has been reading the papers recently following the announcement of ex-senator Bronwyn Bishop that she will contest a lower house seat and, more so, since the Western Australian opposition leader and former Western Australian Premier Dr Carmen Lawrence made an announcement about her intention to enter federal politics.

Before I go any further, it is pertinent that I place on the record my sincere regret at what I believe has been a trial by the media regarding the work of the ex-Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). I condemn the opposition for what has happened. I want to be one of the first to say that I particularly enjoyed working with the minister. I have always admired her as a person of character and strong conviction. She is a person who got on with the job that was asked of her, and she did it to the best of her ability. On behalf of many people in the electorates at large across Australia, I particularly appreciate the wonderful sporting grants that have helped in those areas.

I return to how I believe the media has trivialised women politicians at times. My main objections have related to comparisons of women politicians and their attributes and suggestions that they pit woman against woman rather than that they are political opponents. Members of the media have continually used trite headlines to describe women politicians and their actions. We have continually read about how women overlook their vital and worthwhile roles in so many spheres. It all comes from the media.

We all read about the prediction that the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) would set the world on fire when he entered this parliament. The question to ask is: where is he now? The same media members glorified speculative investors such as Bond and Skase. In other words, at times the media overlooks substance for a bit of flim-flam.

I refer particularly to the headlines that we have all seen when we have read the papers. Recently, some of those headlines have included `Ladies in waiting' to describe Carmen Lawrence and Bronwyn Bishop, and `Lawrence lured from the west by PM', as though someone of Dr Lawrence's capabilities and calibre cannot even make up her own mind. Another headline read `Lawrence puts home on market'. How banal! Do any members of the opposition get the same types of headlines? One of the worst headlines read `Will the real Lawrence please stand up?'.

One description of Bronwyn Bishop was `The most dreadful weapon known to male politics'. That does not even bear comment, yet it was a headline in one of our national newspapers. But the very worst headline was `Carmen's love child', which scored a cover page billing on a recent New Idea. It was outrageous.Dr Lawrence has very impressive credentials. Her academic record and work experience would run rings around the average Australian. Yet this was how the media portrayed her. Even sections of the media acknowledge their own fixations with comparing Carmen Lawrence and Bronwyn Bishop. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 5 February this year stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in Australia's political system there continues to be a fascination with this still peculiar creature—
its words, not mine—
the female politician.

That editorial went on to question whether the media would have bothered to compare Dr Lawrence and ex-senator Bishop had they been the popular Western Australian cricketer Geoff Marsh and the New South Wales Liberal Party President, Peter King, respectively. That same editorial also notes that the media did not bother to compare the two recently retired politicians, John Dawkins and Jim Carlton.

PARA.TAB: For some substance, why does the media not ask Dr Lawrence serious questions, such as her plans in the federal arena? Perhaps some serious comments could be sought on federal issues and policies and how she might implement ideas from the state sphere in the federal parliament. The same questions could perhaps also be asked of ex-Senator Bishop. Perhaps there could then be less media concentration on the negative attributes of these people and more focus on the positive contributions that they could make to this parliament.

In part of my grievance today, I would also like to quote—it really bears out what I am saying—the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) entitled `Women, power and the 21st century'. In a conference last year, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Equal representation of women and men strengthens the legitimacy of our decision making process. More than that, it strengthens our capacity to make the right decisions.

We need Joan Kirner and Carmen Lawrence—and many more like them—in the national parliament. We need them in the debates on economic and social policy, on unemployment, the workplace, trade, foreign affairs, arts, Mabo.
I am pleased to say that the managing director of ANOP Research Services and former ALP pollster, Rod Cameron, said recently:
A woman with experience in bringing up a family is now worth an extra percentage point on polling day compared with a male candidate.

How true that is. That is because voters continue to recognise that women's experience in so many spheres ensures that they are multiskilled and that they are certainly able to tackle problems from a very wide range of perspectives.

PARA.TAB: I am also pleased to see a recent poll survey from the Office of the Status of Women entitled `Juggling time'. It shows that, on average, women, whether they be in the paid work force or not, do over 36 hours a week of unpaid work. It is fairly well acknowledged that if people who perform unpaid work—traditionally women—withdrew their labour, our so-called capitalist system would collapse.

Women are moving into small business and are being very successful. One important study noted that, if current trends continue, by the mid-1990s women will outnumber males as both proprietors and employers in small business.

Women are 53 per cent of voters, but make up only 14.5 per cent of the members of Australian parliaments. At the Commonwealth level, women make up only 8.8 per cent of members of the House of Representatives and over 21 per cent of the Senate. One would think that, even with those figures, the media would be more supportive of the role of women and women in politics. It might then encourage more women to participate rather than be deterred.

In the limited time I have left, I would like to quote some figures. They show that women own or control substantial shareholdings. About 43 per cent of private shareholders and at least 50 per cent of beneficiaries of institutional funds are women. But only around three per cent of members of company boards are women.

Research by Media Insight indicates that women in Australia now control an annual expenditure of $90.2 billion in household outlays. People may be also interested to know that one of the most successful publications of the Office of the Status of Women is the Media complaints brochure. With little publicity, over 56,000 copies have been requested from the office over the last two years.

Women are now abandoning newspapers, where they are virtually invisible, and are shifting to magazines, despite the tight economy. The gross annual circulation of the major women's magazines grew by 10 per cent between 1987 and 1992. The First Assistant Secretary of the Office of the Status of Women, Ann Sherry, has argued that women must now be heads of state. Why not? Ms Sherry has also suggested that Australia's first president should be installed by the year 2000 and should be female. `Why not, again?', says Ms Sherry.

Women are no longer rare in political life or, as many honourable members will know, as heads of major organisations and lobbyists. Women are also increasingly, and rightly, demanding consumers. Women rightly wield power and are affecting political and corporate agendas. Dr Lawrence recently said:

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of support for me comes from women who feel quite determined to change the face of Australian politics.
The media should be mindful of the fact that women in politics are here to stay.

PARA.TAB: The Australian electorate is serious about having more women representatives. The media has a responsibility to report our activities and achievements accurately. Carmen Lawrence recently compared being in politics to being in a marriage or having a family when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Politics is about negotiation. Some do it with a big stick and some do it in a more civilised fashion, in life as in art.

Women are negotiators and communicators. Therefore, women have a true place in parliament. We look forward to reports of substance from the media about the new face of women in politics. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my speech in the grievance debate today to the issue of the Federal Airports Corporation and, in particular, the implementation in 1988 of control of the nation's airports by the Federal Airports Corporation. The FAC was directed to introduce business management practices aimed at making each airport profitable in a self-sufficient manner. To that end, I have a number of concerns not only about Moorabbin airport in my electorate but also about a number of others around the country. Mr David Stack, the Moorabbin airport manager, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Airports are more than just a centre for aircraft . . . They are people places and they provide hundreds of jobs and host scores of businesses, many not directly related to aviation.

I have no problems with his overall aims for the development of the airport, but I am concerned at some of the commercial developments that are being established at airports such as Moorabbin. I am particularly concerned about the way in which a development—called a leisure park but it really is a large market—is being established at that airport.

PARA.TAB: There will be some 650 stalls at this market site. The total area of the site at the airport will be 27 acres. It will have a car park for some 2,400 cars. Three acres of buildings will accommodate 650 stallholders. According to the brochure put out by Fairways Leisure Market—the company which has actually signed the lease, subject to some final arrangements with the airport—one stall will cost $100 per week; two stalls, $85 a week; and, if people take four or more stalls, $75 per week per stall. The brochure indicates that the market will be open for some four days a week at this stage. The specifics of that are not clear because it is something that will be done on an internal basis between the airport management and the people who are signing the lease.

On that basis, one needs only to look at the rental costs of a shop in the shopping centres and the access to traffic, particularly in some of the smaller shopping centres, to realise that many of the people who operate these stalls will take business away from the smaller shopping centres in the community. All of the chambers of commerce in the region, including the Cheltenham, Mentone, Mordialloc, Parkdale and south-eastern chambers of commerce, have indicated strong opposition. I guess what is concerning them the most is that not only will there be this development but also there is a substantial development proposed at the Southland shopping centre by Westfield. In fact, it is envisaging a $216 million expansion. Westfield, of course, is also upset. Part of the reason for it being upset, as one of the executives said, is:

SPEECH.PARA: It's hardly a level playing field when we go through complicated legal zoning procedures costing $3 million over the past three years and the Federal Airports Corporation can create a market with a simple announcement.

PARA.TAB: All the years of rezoning and legal submissions we have made through the proper channels have been blown out of the water.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a valid comment made by Westfield. It has had to go through rigorous planning procedures to get its approval for the shopping centre. It has had the opportunity of having the local municipality assessing the project in the planning processes. Westfield says that these approvals have cost it some $3 million—something that will not be a cost for the development of the site at the airport.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to see that the Victorian Minister for Planning, Mr Rob Maclellan, has threatened to cut road services to the Moorabbin airport if the airport proceeds to hold markets on the site. Mr Maclellan attacked the Federal Airports Corporation in state parliament this month for allowing the airport to build the $3.5 million leisure market without consideration for nearby commercial centres. He acknowledged that his threat was desperate but said it was unfair that airports could use their land for other purposes without having to apply for proper planning permits. Mr Maclellan said that the federal government should force the Federal Airports Corporation to adhere to state planning regulations when it developed some other use for its land. He said the FAC proposal at Moorabbin would compete with other commercial centres that had been forced to have the merits of their proposals judged by the full participatory planning system in Victoria.

It is also interesting to look in detail at the Moorabbin Council's comments in this area. After all, Moorabbin Council is the local government authority responsible for the airport. Moorabbin Council has indicated when writing about this issue that this is not only a problem for it but also a problem for the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council, of which the council is a member. Moorabbin Council indicates that at most of the annual conferences and meetings of the AMAC the issue of the Federal Airports Corporation and the shield of the Crown with respect to developments of this nature is discussed. It appears on their terms that there is little that council can do.

It is fascinating that there are no appeal mechanisms available to the local council for developments that will affect quite substantially some of the commercial operators and small businesses in the area, yet in reverse the FAC is quite happy to use the appeal process. The council actually highlights the fact that discussions with FAC management clearly indicate that the FAC will not submit for council planning or building approval, but at the same time it notes that the FAC has participated at length in appeals concerning land usage in areas in the vicinity of the airport.

By the FAC not submitting to the planning processes, the council indicates that it, the council, has an inability to participate actively in the process of the development affecting the businesses in its local community and to assess the development in the context of its commercial areas and the level of floor space proposed at the regional level and its impact on the locality. The council also says that the issue of extended trading hours and its impact from both the social and economic perspective of the community is affected, that it has an inability to ensure the design of the proposal is compatible with the area and—I guess one of the major concerns—that the proposal is not being tested in a public forum.

It concerns me that here we have traders in the community, local government and state ministers all concerned about the ability of the FAC to go ahead with these types of proposals regardless of approval. I believe that this government needs to look closely at this issue. I understand the intent of making airports self-funding and self-sufficient. I have no problems with that issue at all. But when we start allowing airports to establish these types of developments without the planning approval of the local authority, without the costs of planning that are placed on other businesses and without the requirements for trading hours that are placed on other businesses, recognising that they are not contributing to the rating base within that community, I think the process is grossly unfair.

I am not questioning what the airport manager is doing. He is working within the guidelines that are available to him. In fact, he is working within those to the letter of the law. When commercial and profitable operations are being put on to airport sites where the controls within the local community and other authorities are bypassed, the process that is being operated by the FAC needs to be strongly questioned. The government should take action to ensure that the planning approvals requested by these authorities to enable them to be assessed on a merits basis are actually provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today concerns the 400,000 unemployed who are under the age of 30 years and the 850,000 children who live in unemployed households. The 400,000 unemployed under the age of 30 represent 40 per cent of the unemployed in Australia. The 850,000 children who live in unemployed households represent 25 per cent of all children. Yet, faced with these stark figures, neo-classical economists continue to put forward arguments for the policy settings of the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: In January this year, the ANZ job vacancies totalled only 17,000 for a million unemployed. Although many economists acknowledge unemployment, they seldom suggest where jobs can be created. Neo-classical economists seem to believe that society should serve the economy rather than the reverse. They seem obsessed with monetarists concepts and dismiss numerous policies such as reduction in work time, the potential of labour-intensive environmental employment in renewable energy or recycling in waste management. They ignore employment opportunities in public infrastructure, particularly in public transport. They ignore employment opportunities in the service sector, particular in education and health. They ignore the social costs of unemployment, the increase in crime and suicide. They never mention an inefficient economy with high unemployment. They never refer to occupational health and safety. They ignore lost productivity caused by fatigue and boredom. They ignore increased compensation claims and redundancy payouts and they ignore taxation reform.

In fact, one of problems in their argument is that they only consider the impact of government policy on employers. They seem to ignore the economic consequences of having more people employed, which would mean some of the unemployed becoming wage earners instead of welfare recipients.

There is no doubt that support and prevention are the key to investment in social infrastructure. This is particularly true when policy options are considered for abused children, the mentally ill and the frail aged. Full employment is not about just including the unemployed; it is about sharing the future. Keynes showed that chronic and endemic unemployment could remain in equilibrium in the absence of government intervention.

Contemporary, natural rate economic theorists seem to prefer the constant pull of unemployment. They have a propensity to hide behind mystifications such as the non-accelerating rate of unemployment, that is, keeping inflation down justifies the unemployment rate. These same neo-classical economists were often scathing in their criticisms of labour market programs. Australia now has more program places than it did in the mid-1980s, which are at a lower cost and are better directed to long-term unemployed. However, in acknowledging that fact, it should also be said that in 1992 two-thirds of the long-term unemployed received no special assistance.

As the green paper on unemployment has pointed out, there is a need for boldness in trying new approaches to labour market programs. Labour market programs play a critical role in keeping unemployed people attached to the work force. However, unless certain basic skill requirements are met—literacy, numeracy, communication and social skills—meaningful training to improve job prospects is expensive and will be fraught with failure. Labour market programs cannot make up for deficiencies in general education. Hence the link for a skilled worker to the preparation of the work force is in fact education.

I said at the beginning of this speech that 400,000 of Australia's unemployed are under 30 years of age. They attended primary school in the 1970s. It is more than interesting to note that in the early 1970s many educationalists in this country were alarmed that up to 10 per cent of children in primary schools lacked basic skills in numeracy and literacy and were calling for urgent additional resources to be allocated to primary schools. Their pleas were largely ignored.

Last year, several studies in Australia indicated that that figure could be as high as 20 per cent and that up to 25 per cent of children leaving primary school do so with inadequate literacy and numeracy skills. In 10 years time that group will enter the work force and the implications will be in fact horrendous.

While federal attention during the last 10 years has focused on higher education, secondary retention rates and lately vocational training, little, if any, attention is paid to the foundation years of schooling, which are predominantly the responsibility of state governments. State governments by their inaction on primary education are putting the future of this nation at risk. The skill base of the Australian work force relies heavily on the quality of Australian schooling. A longitudinal study by the Inner London Education Authority in 1986 strongly suggested that successful schooling for children between the ages of 7 and 11 is the most significant determinant of future success and is more important than gender or socioeconomic background.

There is evidence that the schooling system is failing to meet the needs of young people. Nowhere is that more evident than in our primary schools. It is a pointless exercise just to blame teachers. They simply do not have the resources available to do what they know can and ought to be done.

Too many children leave primary school unprepared and face often a purely academic curriculum in secondary school, which is not appropriate for the diverse mixture of abilities and interests. Many of these younger people then drop out of school into unemployment and long-term disadvantage. However, I make the point that I made earlier: it is cheaper and more effective to prevent educational problems and subsequent problems with young children than it is to cure those problems when the child is a young man or a young woman. It seems to me that 15- to 19-year-olds should not be in the labour force other than in part-time work unless they are in a training employment scheme.

The green paper on unemployment basically ignores schooling. It also says that a major expansion of post-compulsory education and training would be at a considerable cost and considers that the provision of jobs is a higher immediate priority. But it ignores schemes where jobs could in fact be created.

There is no single solution to unemployment. Economic growth by itself will not solve the problem and, if there is little change to the school system, then continued large numbers of unprepared young people will feed into a very unsympathetic labour market. One million adult Australians, including 650,000 of English-speaking background, have difficulty in relatively everyday reading and writing tasks. Adults with difficulties in everyday reading and writing tasks were once children with everyday reading and writing difficulties. If we were driving along in our motor vehicle and the oil light came on, we would not wait until the engine seized to replenish the oil. That is commonsense. So it is with literacy problems, we can prevent problems cheaply. It is much harder and more expensive to cure literacy, numeracy and social problems of adolescents and young adults.

The unemployment debate in this nation will not be complete unless a wide array of solutions is canvassed. There will be little sustained change to unemployment levels if there is no change to our school system. There will be little sustained change to unemployment if there is no serious debate on the potential for jobs in environmental management and technology. Perhaps we need to take heed of the Japanese. They are spending $1 billion a year to achieve world leadership in environmental management and technology by the year 2000.

There will be little sustained change in unemployment if there is no serious debate on the reduction of working hours and job sharing. There will be little sustained change to unemployment if public infrastructure, particularly public transport, falls off the national agenda. There will be little sustained change if there is no further taxation reform. There will be little sustained change if we do not seriously consider re-engineering social security and employment benefits from the current passive mode to a more active one. There will be little change if we continue to allow neo-classical economists to dominate the unemployment debate. They appear to have a wanton disregard for the unemployed, with their obsessiveness in maintaining the status quo of policy settings of the 1980s.

Australia led the world in the introduction of social benefits and it can lead the developed world in breaking the cycle of unemployment. The economic orthodoxies of the past 10 years have had both positive and negative effects. Australia is much more competitive, that is acknowledged. But those same economic orthodoxies have led to significant job losses. Economic orthodoxies by themselves will not solve the unemployment problem; single solutions will not solve the unemployment problem. However, an array of solutions tempered with a degree of federal government intervention can and must solve the problem of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to grieve about the dismissal of two women from the staff of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I refer to Ms Bridget Mullin and Ms Gail Gray, who had previously served on the staff of the Lodge for some time and who were advised on 3 October 1993 that they should not report to work. On 5 October, the housekeepers' contracts were terminated. No notice period was given and they were effectively locked out. This matter subsequently received considerable media attention and was also referred to the Ombudsman by the legal representative of these two women.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that on 19 January 1994 the Ombudsman said that she would investigate statements made about the sackings at the November estimates, but not the circumstances of dismissal. On 4 February 1994, the Ombudsman advised that she was reconsidering her decision not to investigate circumstances surrounding the termination of the housekeepers. It is significant that this whole matter is, to this day, still surrounded in some controversy and considerable doubt.

The important point, which this parliament must always be aware of, is that we are essentially here to represent all citizens, especially the underdogs. In this case, these two housekeepers continue to be extremely distressed because the decision of the Ombudsman effectively means that their complaints will not be investigated. These two women can best be described as low income earners and at present have no income at all. They are unemployed and they may remain unemployable. Why? Because over their names now hangs the stench of the allegations made in the media and Senate estimates committees, all of which have not been tested and about which public servants have not had the opportunity to explain the facts; nor have these two women been given the opportunity to express their points of view.

The most extraordinary thing I find in all of this is that the Ombudsman claimed that she cannot carry through a further investigation because this involves a ministerial decision. Yet I noticed in her annual report that the point is made very clearly that she claims the right to investigate `pre-employment and post-employment matters'. She also goes on to mention `access and equity as a high priority' as part of her objectives. Certainly she should be `accessible to those who need us most', as she claims.

The `promotion of the office's services to low income and disadvantaged groups', as stated in her 1993 annual report, is part of the objective of the Ombudsman's office—one would have to say that in both these cases that has certainly not been met. Therefore, the question that has to be referred to this parliament is: what can be done to support Ms Mullin and Ms Gray in their case against what they claim to be wrongful dismissal? Ultimately, responsibility must reside with the person who employed them, which in this case is the Prime Minister, because they were employees of the Lodge.

The Prime Minister's rights in terms of the administration of his staff were transferred to officers of the Prime Minister's department. It is claimed by the Ombudsman that, because of that transfer of responsibility, that is therefore seen as a ministerial decision. It is only fair to say that even the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), when this matter was given an airing at the Senate estimates, made it quite clear that he could not understand how that formula could possibly be applied in this case. It is also worth noting that under section 5(3) of the Ombudsman Act it is patently obvious that staff would be subject to scrutiny by the Ombudsman if she so wished. In this case, however, she has chosen not to do so.

I am concerned at the Ombudsman's reversal of her decision to investigate these statements made about the housekeepers' dismissal for the following reasons. Firstly, the decision was advised the same day as Senate Estimates Committee E was inquiring into the manner of the housekeepers' dismissal and also on the same day as the Prime Minister went on The Midday Show to say that it was an issue between the women and the department—not, presumably, between him and his employees. Secondly, Estimates Committee E met at 4.32 p.m. on 22 February. Senator Evans and Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet officials at that hearing were aware of the Ombudsman's decision not to investigate the statements made about the housekeepers at a previous estimates committee hearing. Yet the Ombudsman did not notify the housekeepers' lawyer of her decision until 4.40 p.m. the same day.

Thirdly, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet advised the Ombudsman of its concerns about investigating statements made under privilege—advice the Ombudsman obviously heeded in reversing her original decision to investigate the statements made about the housekeepers. Perhaps one of the questions which has not been answered is: did she take advice from the Attorney-General? Did she only take advice from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet? As I pointed out, section 5(3) of her own act would on the face of it give her considerable rights to carry through this investigation, as well as the principles I noted earlier in terms of the fundamental responsibilities of the Ombudsman under the act.

That grievances be noted.

That the bill be now read second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the appropriation bills has changed somewhat, given that the Treasurer who was responsible for the introduction of these bills is no longer here. However, we should not be too surprised by that. There has been quite an exodus of members of the government from this place during this financial year. The events of today have seen yet another minister resign her place on the front bench. I wonder what the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has planned for the future?

PARA.TAB: Debate on this package of appropriation bills gives me the opportunity to canvass a number of issues which affect the constituents of Cook. It is essential that members of parliament remember one central point: the No. 1 priority of all members should be to act first and foremost as representatives of the people of their electorates. Grandstanding in Canberra has never been high on my list of priorities in my long time as a member of this House. I therefore think it is always a timely reminder that this is the people's place. It is the forum in which the people are represented. That is what we, as members of this House, are paid to do.

So it will come as no surprise that I must make some comments in relation to the sports rorts affair. This is an issue of grave concern to the people of my electorate. As I do the rounds of my electorate, I am always receiving the same message: how could the minister for the environment keep her place on the frontbench? This is recurrent comment from the people who pay—or paid—the minister's wages. The public simply cannot believe that a senior cabinet minister could not be brought to account for the most blatant abuse of administrative responsibility. Is it any wonder that the public holds a pessimistic view of the parliamentary process when the sports rorts affair has dragged on for so long? And what of the saga of the whiteboard? Surely, there has never been such a lame excuse for ineptitude as that paltry effort from the then minister.

Did this minister really expect the general public to believe that $30 million of taxpayers' money was allocated by scribbling on a whiteboard? That just shows the degree of contempt in which this government holds the parliamentary process and the Australian people. I do not wish to dwell on this issue too much, given the numerous commentaries throughout the media which have called for the minister to be sacked and which led to her resignation this afternoon. I want to add another dimension to the issue in regard to the announcement of successful grants. I raised this issue in the House on 22 November 1993. In the light of this afternoon's events, I think it is important to raise it once again.

The lead-up to the last election saw a flurry of funds emanating from the minister's office. She simply could not spend the money quickly enough. I am sure that she was given a directive that the massive pork-barrelling exercise had to be rushed so that organisations would receive word of their successful applications prior to polling day. In cases where the sitting member was from the Labor Party, it was evident that the publicity machine went into overdrive to ensure that the local Labor member received as much kudos for the grant as was possible. Who can forget the picture of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) wielding his baseball bat as a testament to that?

However, in the case where the local member was not from the government, the former minister found herself in a bind. Her brief must have been to ensure that the organisation in receipt of the money must not be fooled into thinking that the local coalition member had anything to do with the grant; it was purely the benevolence of the Labor government and the Labor candidate, not the local member in that particular seat, which made the grant possible.

This was exactly the case in my electorate. Worse still, the Labor candidate just happened to be on the staff of one of the former minister's ministerial colleagues. I do not place any blame at all on that minister whom I hold in the highest regard. However, the organisation involved with the grant, which provides an excellent service to the community, was not fooled, as the former minister had hoped. The Labor candidate contacted the president of the organisation to inform him of the success of its application for funding. This was her first contact with the organisation. This was in contrast to my long association with this organisation and also the fact that I had obtained the necessary application forms and supported its application directly.

Honourable members will understand my amazement some five months later, just prior to polling day, when the president of the organisation contacted me to say that he had just been informed by the local Labor candidate that the organisation's grant had been approved. I repeat that at that time the candidate was on the staff of the former federal minister.

Perhaps even more amazing still is the fact that the former minister for sport has still not contacted me to inform me as to whether or not this particular grant has been approved. In this case, the work has already been carried out. I still have not received any correspondence from the former minister regarding any of the applications which came from my electorate. Realistically, I do not expect to hear now.

This is another aspect of the shameful and despicable funding program which will always be remembered as the sports rorts affair. For the Labor candidate to receive information regarding funding applications while the sitting member is totally ignored smacks of political bias of the worst kind and also illustrates the contempt with which the government holds the parliamentary process.

I first raised this issue when the former minister refused to allow the Parliamentary Library to answer queries regarding the sports rorts affair. Instead, the former minister insisted that all queries be referred to her office. I would say that, even at that time, in late November last year, the writing was on the wall for the former minister. She must have reached a desperate state of affairs when she did not possess sufficient confidence in the impartiality and expertise of the Parliamentary Library. We have seen her go down since then, dragging her ministerial colleagues, notably the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), into this smelly affair.

What an absolute disgrace this former minister proved to be and what a shambles has been the performance of the Prime Minister himself. The resignation this afternoon is long overdue. However, the issue of the sports rorts does not finish there. It is clear that the former minister was not acting alone and, in time, I am sure more facts will come to light regarding the whole sordid issue.

The appropriation debate also affords me the opportunity to yet again place on record my appreciation for the sterling efforts of the volunteer bushfire brigades in the recent fire tragedy in Sydney. As it happens, I was fortunate enough to have attended yesterday a community day for the Jannali-Como area. I am pleased to report to the House that the New South Wales Premier, John Fahey, was also in attendance at this important ceremony of some 10,000 people.

In January, 104 houses were destroyed in the Sutherland Shire by the bushfires which also tragically claimed the life of Mrs Paula O'Neil. As I said in this House on an earlier occasion, Sutherland Shire has a history of bushfires, but nothing could have prepared the residents of Jannali-Como for what happened in January. The disaster was immediate and devastating. The exact cost of the destruction may never be fully known, although the remarkable spirit shown by the residents of this area serves as an example to us all of the triumph of human spirit in times of adversity. That was what the commemoration yesterday was all about.

I place on record my appreciation to Tony Jackson and others associated with the organisation of the community day. It was an enjoyable, yet memorable, occasion in spite of the reason for the gathering. Countless articles have been written about the courage and dedication of the volunteer firefighters; however, it is only when one sees first-hand the devastation of the Sutherland district that one can truly gain an appreciation of the forces of nature with which the volunteers had to contend. Over 95 per cent of the famous Royal National Park in southern Sydney was destroyed in the fires.

The communities of Bundeena and Maianbar, which used to form part of my electorate, were evacuated to nearby Cronulla. Understandably, a state of nervousness permeated throughout the Sutherland Shire and, with each wind of change, a new concern arose. It is a credit to the volunteers of the bushfire brigade that the list of damages was not much greater. The professionalism and dedication shown by all these brave men and women must be commended in the highest possible terms, and that is what yesterday's community parade was all about.

Many of us have much to thank these people for. Their selfless attitude and strength in the most trying of circumstances will long be remembered by all of us. The mobility of all the bushfire men and women—those who lived locally, those from other areas of New South Wales and those from interstate, particularly Victoria—was nothing short of miraculous. I again extend my condolences to the family of Mrs O'Neil and wish her two daughters the very best of health as they recover from their ordeal.

In this wide ranging debate, I also want to take the opportunity to make some comments about the Commonwealth car fleet and, in particular, Commonwealth drivers. In all my years as a member of this place, I cannot recall a time when the mood of the Commonwealth car drivers has been so sombre. I have never seen morale among the drivers so incredibly low. That is amongst the drivers who are left. I am told there are 39, compared with a previous fleet number of 89.

What a shambles the ministerial directions have been for the past five to eight years. Drivers have not been told the truth of future plans in all of this period. It has been one administrative nightmare after another. I plan to talk on this subject more fully at a later date.

In the last few minutes of my time remaining, I merely point out the problems that are now being created with the Badgerys Creek airport. I have in my hands a paper called Flight arrivals, which is concerned with the issues and developments affecting Badgerys Creek international airport. Here we see a Labor run council, the Penrith Council, strongly demanding that we need a 2,900-metre runway—not the 1,800-metre runway that is presently being planned.

It is remarkable that such a Labor council should make such a strong criticism of the government directions that have been coming its way in this matter. It criticises the federal government in this paper for the direction it has taken. Despite the recommendation of all expert bodies to create and build a longer runway that can accommodate jets, the policy is still that the runway should be only 1,800 metres, which is not sufficiently long for jet aircraft participation.

Mr Speaker, with your taking the chair, I gather something is about to happen in the House. So I shall not go on with this Badgerys Creek business, except to say that it is yet another example of shocking and bad administration by certain ministers of this government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Allan Morris) adjourned.
