DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1993-94Cognate bills:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1993-94APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be the first of my colleagues to offer our appreciation for the work the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) has done, as minister, for seven years. I deeply regret the circumstances that have led to her today offering her resignation. It is the first time, as far as I can recall, that a minister has resigned without there being some suggestion of impropriety—or some potential for impropriety—or inappropriate behaviour. Apparently she did not mislead parliament, to the extent that the scheme apparently did not incorporate in the eligible categories organisations wishing to purchase brass band equipment. Clearly, that was wrong. It should never have been the case. Perhaps it was not thought of by the bureaucracy at the time, but the fact that sporting equipment and artistic or cultural equipment could be bought with the funds but equipment for a youth band could not was clearly an oversight that the former minister corrected, and apparently in correcting it she inadvertently misled parliament.

PARA.TAB: My major concern is that the judgment passed by some is both unjust and undeserved. I am sure that history will recognise the honourable member's contribution to this government as being a substantial one and one which is worthy of much better treatment than she has received in recent months. The slanderous and despicable behaviour that I have seen in this House week after week for some months now has not just appalled myself but I am sure has dragged down the standards of behaviour of parliamentarians throughout the nation.

Equally important as the treatment of the former sports minister is the scheme itself. The scheme was enormously important to regional Australia. The fact is that, until the scheme was introduced, the Commonwealth government contributed nothing to sporting facilities for people outside capital cities. If one lived in Sydney or Melbourne then the state provided facilities of a national or international standard but if one lived in regional Australia then basically there was no such support. Because of this scheme, regional areas now have world-class facilities, such as Newcastle's hockey facility. It would be an absolute tragedy if the very despicable actions of those opposite lead not just to the minister's resignation but to the total termination of the program. It would be a tragedy for sport and it would be a tragedy for regional Australia.

I want to make sure that the opposition knows that in the months and years ahead we will be reminding sporting bodies around the country of how anti sport opposition members have been and how, in their attempt to belittle and tear down one person, they have in fact done enormous damage to the potential and the capacity of Australian taxpayers to support the national contribution to sporting facilities.

I see the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) shaking his head. Let me tell him that in the last three months the coalition has done enormous damage to the potential of sporting facilities all over Australia to be funded by the Commonwealth. We would go back to the days where the Commonwealth basically said that sport and sporting facilities were matters for state and local governments and the Commonwealth was not involved. That is the likely outcome, by association, because the implication has been there was some lack of accounting, which clearly is not true. The acquittal of funds was always properly conducted and, financially, the audit trail was always there. I have never before heard of an audit trail for ministerial discretion. I have never before heard of an audit trail for how people make up their minds or make subjective judgments, but I will be interested to hear in the months ahead the kind of justification opposition members will use as they try to do a backflip and justify their actions to sporting bodies.

Nobody is going to justify to people who wrote to ministers year after year seeking more and more funding for sporting facilities in their electorates why the scheme has been terminated. I think that is a great tragedy. It is not just a personal tragedy for the honourable member for Canberra to be brought down in such an unscrupulous way; it is a national tragedy for regional Australia and its sporting capacities. Not one person opposite was prepared to defend and support the need for regional Australia to get access to national revenue for these facilities.

Appropriation bills Nos 3 and 4 arise from the budget brought down in August last year. While that is only six months ago, the change in the economy in that six months has been quite dramatic. Look at where the national and international economies were back in August last year. In the middle of last year Japan introduced even further measures to recover its economy; the American economy was still sluggish, although apparently recovering; and Europe had been through some major crises in terms of internal currencies.

At a national level the Australian recovery was still not recognised as such by the community. However, between then and now we have seen quite substantial indications of recovery coming through, firstly in the national economy, with low interest rates and CPI, with the inflation rate now being below two per cent—which is well below budget projections—and of course with our growth rate well above budget projections. So the appropriations in this legislation come from a budget which has now been shown, following stronger economic results than were anticipated, to have been a very cautious budget. As well as that, the government took action two years ago through the One Nation statement. These measures, combined with the wage and productivity changes and the restructuring of our internal economy both within enterprises and within government, mean that we have, perhaps for the first time in 30 or more years, a conjunction of capacity in terms of interest rates, profitability and productivity that will allow this recovery to be one that has both long-term benefits and can be maintained in the long term.

If one had said a year or two ago, or even six months ago, that the Australian economy could recover—and recover strongly—with low inflation while, at the same time, Japan and Germany were in recession, one's judgment would have been thought to have been suspect because, historically, if either Japan or Germany was in recession then automatically Australia would be. The fact that we are recovering so well despite what is happening in Japan is cause for great encouragement.

However, there also must be cause for concern in relation to the current American-Japanese negotiations. Clearly a trade war between those two countries does not help anybody but, equally clearly, one cannot go wrong arguing for more open trade when one observes some of the non-tariff barriers that some countries apply. Australia in some ways has cause to complain about both Japan and America because both offer resistance to Australian products and both are fairly selective in how they interpret the words `free' and `fair'. Despite that, the fact is that the GATT round has now been agreed to, albeit in a modified form, so clearly there is a shift in world trends and in the way the world is approaching trade.

In the short term the effects of that will be marginal but what is important is that in the longer term this will be of enormous benefit to Australia. At that same time, we are watching the Asian nations find a new sense of maturity and a new sense of purpose in their own economic developments. For the first time in our history, Australia is tapping into a growth in manufactured exports. The fact that in the last financial year we exported more products we made than products we grew stands as a quite remarkable record. The fact that we exported more manufactured goods than primary industry products must leave many of our critics somewhat confused.

Quite frankly, the history of the Australian manufacturing industry shows that the policy was essentially a diversion. Behind high protection, high tariffs and artificial currencies was the idea that our manufacturing was basically to keep people out of mischief while the real trade went on in primary industries and resources. Now that manufacturing has established itself as a viable export, we are looking towards a much more skilled and capable work force in the future.

Australia does have a highly capable and a highly competitive engineering capacity. That has been recognised by many people for a long time, but as a country we have only started to market that capacity in recent years. I am confident that in the years ahead we will maintain our manufacturing potential and competitive capacity to export not just our manufactured products but also our design skills. Australian engineers are of a very high calibre in world terms and they are recognised as being innovative and very competitive.

We are approaching the 11th anniversary of the election of a Labor government in 1983 and the first anniversary of the current government. That is why it is important that we start to take a broader perspective of this budget and its appropriations. Clearly, we have a problem with long-term unemployment. It is of fundamental importance that our sense of fairness and justice is not forgotten amongst the economic data. There is a danger that a number of people will be left standing on the sidelines as the economy continues to recover unless we take overt action, unless we consciously and quite deliberately put programs in place that will assist not just the economy and the community but individuals and that people perceive it as such.

At the moment, a number of programs such as jobstart, jobskills, LEAP and a variety of others target particularly the long-term unemployed. In many cases, they are aimed at work experience, work support or some form of training. We hear much criticism, understandably, about the purpose of training schemes when there is a shortage of employment, but if we do not train those people who have been out of work for some time as employment appears they will miss out—the chicken and egg situation—because they will not be able to compete in the labour market.

The fact that unemployment is high seems to imply somehow that the economy has actually shrunk. As mentioned again today in question time, in the last 11 years our work force has grown by something like 1.2 million people. There are 1.2 million more people working now than there were when we came into government. So the work force has grown virtually every year in net terms. Despite that, the number of those available for work has grown faster. That is what we are talking about. The actual growth in the participation rate, which is the size of the work force as a part of the total community, has grown as has the population overall.

It is important that we understand that, unlike New Zealand for example—a model which is often used against us—our work force has grown as our economy has grown. In response to those circumstances, the government is taking serious action and we are looking towards a statement on both employment and industry by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other ministers in the next six weeks or so.

That is in fairly stark contrast to what has been happening in the parliament itself in recent months. The opposition has been preoccupied not with the unemployed, not with ways of generating skills. I think the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) put it very clearly today. We are getting letters from so many people in the community—church organisations, community groups and individuals—with ideas, suggestions and proposals on what we as a government should be doing to help support those without work in our community, yet the opposition is not contributing one bit. We are not seeing any real care. We are seeing crocodile tears when it suits.

Basically, for many months now the opposition has ignored the potential to contribute to question time and parliamentary debate. In the 11 years that I have been here, I cannot recall a time when an opposition has been so bereft of ideas. I cannot recall a time when an opposition has made a conscious decision to have no policies. Previously, opposition policies were always under way or at least had been announced somewhere. For almost a year now, the opposition has almost been making having no policies a virtue.

The community and those who support that side of politics—that is a substantial number of Australians—must be greatly discouraged to recognise that those who represent them have no ideas to put forward and no solutions or proposals. Simply, all they have done is attack people's characters. The opposition has attacked the honourable member for Canberra and the Prime Minister and I do not doubt that there will be attacks on other ministers. I think the articles in the weekend papers on that topic are revealing. The opposition demonstrates a paucity of morality but, more importantly, a paucity of ideas and principle.

In the months ahead we will see more of the same—no policies, personal attacks and attempts at vilification and to drag people down. I think Mr Fraser's comments on that were fairly pertinent. If the opposition thinks that today's resignation by the honourable member for Canberra as Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories is a victory, I am afraid it is wrong. If there is any glee from those opposite about that, I think in the months ahead they will find that Australians will judge them harshly for the kind of behaviour that the former minister has responded to.

We are entering or going through a fairly strong recovery. It is important that both the government and the nation focus on the depth and structure of that recovery so that it is sustainable and that we do not go back to our boom-bust cycles. If one goes into factories nowadays compared with, say, 11 years ago, whilst the buildings look the same on the outside, the interiors are totally different in that we have seen a whole new approach from the work force and management.

The idea that management and workers can actually work together is no longer some wild scheme; it is now a reality in factories throughout the country. Because of that, we are seeing productivity and profitability in companies like never before. I can recall being told by some managers of companies in my area years ago that it was very difficult for them to get investment from their boards when the best a company could make was 10 or 12 per cent profit and that they could invest in the money market and make more. I know that in my first year Telecom bonds were paying 14 per cent. Why would one invest in production and hope to make 10 or 12 per cent if one can passively invest and make more?

Industry is now more profitable than almost any other investment. I see a shift happening right now—and I am sure that it will continue—from passive investment to active investment. Between dividend imputation, the corporate tax rate and the R&D tax write-off and internal wage restructuring, productivity and enterprise bargaining, the best investment people can make nowadays is in production. It is the best short-term investment and I am sure that it will be the best long-term investment.

As I indicated earlier, our performance in exports of manufactured goods is now established. It is not a one-off, a flash in the pan and not some fluke. It is part of a long-term process by our businesses to learn and cope with marketing in the international context, particularly into Asia. Those achievements are there. The task for the government and those on this side of the House is to make those changes work more effectively, to finetune them and to keep them going.

It is rather unfortunate that we are constantly being diverted from focusing on that objective by the kind of trivia and demeaning politics that we have seen in recent months. Eventually, vilification, politics of personality and personal attacks are no answer to policy or constructive process. I have no doubt that, with the change of opposition leadership which will occur in the next few months, those opposite will suddenly have a rush of blood to the head and they will find that policy is important after all. This wide ranging debate is important because it allows us to look at the bigger picture and the important picture. The tragedy is that the opposition seems to be using it for personal grandstanding rather than as a constructive process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in speaking to these appropriation bills to look at a number of areas of regional development. I am pleased that the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) said that there is no-one on this side who is particularly interested in what the sporting grants might have done for regional Australia. I for one am very interested. I have a continuing interest and I think parts of regional Australia, especially those that were represented by the National Party, were very badly treated. It is pleasing to see my colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) sitting here beside me because his electorate was graced with one such grant, announced by the Labor candidate for his seat, not by the sitting member.

PARA.TAB: Although ostensibly a borderline Labor electorate and therefore very well treated, there are parts of the regional aspect of my electorate, places such as the developing areas of Agnes Water and the town of 1770, that scream out to heaven for development and where well-structured grants were not even considered, yet those of lower grading were.

The honourable member for Newcastle also talked about paucity of morality and paucity of ideas. I was subjected to a vitriolic attack by my predecessor over the Bundaberg Netball Association, claiming that I had bagged it. In fact, his state colleague the member for Bundaberg, Mr Campbell, claimed that I had tainted it. As honourable members would know, not one member of the National Party or the Liberal Party at any stage bagged that organisation, which is a particularly well-run and well-focused organisation which carries out activities that give thousands of young people a year a chance to play one of Australia's most popular sports. I understand that netball is Australia's second most popular sport. Our particular beef was not with that association, but with the fact that the guidelines were not adhered to.

What I find even more interesting is that my predecessor at no time briefed that organisation. Even though he was able to lend his name in support of the application, he never at any stage warned the association that its application was not within the guidelines. It is equally strange that the former minister did not give that organisation the opportunity, as she did in many other electorates in which applications did not qualify, to modify the application. Let it be put clearly on the record today that neither I, my party or for that matter the Liberal Party cast any aspersions against the Bundaberg Netball Association.

As the honourable member for Newcastle said, we need to be focusing on regional Australia. Returning to the subject of finance, I would like to touch on the matter of sales tax. Sales tax, as one member described it this morning, is one of the most insidious forms of taxation. It is never seen, yet every trolley that goes through every checkout in every supermarket in Australia is just alive with sales tax. Despite its great moral indignation over the GST and its distortion of the facts at the time of the last election and since, to say nothing of its promise that there would be no new taxes, the government has beset the Australian public with a one per cent sales tax levy on everything.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your 15 per cent?

—Our 15 per cent would have been offset by the removal of all sales tax. The parliamentary secretary knows full well that the 30 per cent, 20 per cent and 10 per cent would have come off to be replaced by the 15 per cent. But it is convenient to put that to one side and let that distortion of the truth continue ad nauseam.

PARA.TAB: There was a promise of no new taxes yet we are beset with this one per cent increase in the level of sales tax. I find it extraordinarily interesting that this government should talk about a GST. Is a blanket one per cent increase across the board—I am not talking about restructuring sales tax itself—not a consumption tax? Is that not just another name for a hidden consumption tax? Indeed, that is what it is.

I am not here today to bag the government unnecessarily. In fact, I am here to appeal to its better instincts. The honourable member for Newcastle was appealing for new ideas. I am just about to throw a few out, so the parliamentary secretary should get his notebook out and jot them down because I am going to be creative. These are the areas I want to touch on. I accept that the government has the right to raise taxes and, reluctantly, we all have to pay them. But, even within the framework, the government could exercise its prerogatives with a great deal more focus and sensitivity.

I would like to talk first about school buses. School buses are a very important part of the life of rural Australia. They bring children from all sorts of country and outlying areas to schools that are not all that great themselves in terms of size, but they are the fabric of education for people who do not enjoy the pleasures of living in the capital and provincial cities. I think we could also say that these school buses could hardly be described as lavish instruments of travel, nor could we say that those who run these buses make a great deal of money out of them. They are very marginal activities at the best of times, but they are a basic community service and a vital one at that.

It is not surprising that the matter of safety comes up from time to time. I think we are all mindful of the two tragic bus crashes at Kempsey and Grafton of recent times and the tremendous toll of human life that those two crashes took. I suppose we have been pretty fortunate with school buses, although, sadly, there have been deaths on school buses. School buses have rolled over and things like that. We have been mercifully spared great tragedies on that front. Nevertheless, we should not go on with the belief, as we did with the interstate coaches, that this cannot happen because it happened once and it happened all too quickly on a second occasion, with horrendous loss of life.

Recently in Queensland the state authorities brought in a system of auditing steep grades on school bus runs. The idea of that is that school buses for those in mountainous or undulating areas need to be fitted with special safety equipment; namely, brake retarders. These will cost the operators of these buses up to $11,000. One operator in my area, Peter Wilson of Gin Gin, operates a Nissan civilian omnibus in the Kalpowar area, which is a timber growing area near Monto in the north west of my electorate. He will be required to fit these drive line retarders to his braking system and that will set him back $11,000. I believe that is an unacceptable burden for small bus operators to carry when the focus of that activity is safety. Equally, if the state authorities, or indeed school bus operators, on a voluntary basis want to fit their school buses with seat belts, I think that should be exempt from sales tax, too. This would be a very simple and practical way for us to get fair dinkum. Mr Deputy Speaker, that is my creative thought to you today about safety and safety for children.

While I am on the theme of safety, I would like to mention an exchange I have had—friendly enough, I might admit—with the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) regarding EPIRBs, which is, for those who are not familiar with that term, emergency position indicating radio beacons. An EPIRB is fitted to any form of naval craft—military, civilian, private or commercial—and will very readily identify the location of a ship or vessel in distress. One of the sad ironies of this is that, if a vessel by its very nature is exempt from sales tax—for example, if a trawler were being built to go fishing in the components would be exempt from sales tax—then these EPIRBS would also be exempt from sales tax. But if they are fitted to a pleasure vessel—a pleasure vessel is a very broad definition; it might even apply to the tinny in which we go out and throw out a line on a weekend's fishing—then sales tax applies.

The Queensland state government is looking at making these safety beacons compulsory, and I commend it for that. But I think it will impose an unnecessary constraint on safety equipment. It will make it much harder for people to put them on. I suppose there will always be the odd character who runs the risk of his tinny getting into trouble, his motor cutting out, and drifting out to sea.

I would like to draw to the attention of the House the difference between this rather small exemption and what we pay when someone is lost at sea. Sometimes four or five people on a small vessel go out to sea. If their outboard motor cuts out and they drift away from the safety of land, there is an absolutely massive rescue operation. Aircraft, helicopters, air sea rescue and all sorts of people are involved in finding that vessel. At times we hear of the expenditure involved.

Quite apart from the fact that people need to be protected at sea, we often forget about the pilots who go out in appalling conditions and the air sea rescue people who similarly go out in times of distress—on many occasions without any consideration for their own safety. It often puts these voluntary workers at unnecessary risk and, as I said before, the state and Commonwealth authorities are involved in inordinate costs. If these beacons were fitted to all craft in such circumstances, there would be great savings to the nation. If we could pinpoint a vessel in distress in a matter of minutes, just think how simple it would be to save life and expense. Again, it comes back to a simple sales tax matter.

In the last five or six minutes I have available, I want to talk about sales tax in regional development. I will be creative. There is a lot of talk going on at present about regional development. It will be the flavour of the month, I suspect, between now and the next election. Regional development is most misunderstood in Australia. More sins are committed in the name of regional development than anything else I know of. There is a feeling that some nebulous white knight is going to charge out into the regional and rural areas of Australia and provide a framework under which we will be able to fix up all the nation's ills. The Kelty—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Joh, you mean?

—He got closer than most. I would like to touch briefly on regional tourist authorities and industry development authorities. In some states they are controlled totally by the state government: two examples are New South Wales with its new tourist authorities and Western Australia with its regional development authorities. Where the organisation is totally funded by local authorities, a state government, or a combination of both, it is exempt from sales tax. However, the states that have a combination of state government, local authority and private subscribers' money—as is the case in Queensland, for example—are sales tax exempt, except in the tourist industry for regional brochuring.

PARA.TAB: The bodies that are driving the government dollar further have to pay sales tax on the computer database that might store information on the hotels, motels, caravan parks and the tourist attractions of the area. It is a legitimate form of modern communications and promotion, yet sales tax has to be paid. Sales tax is paid on the photocopier that does all the internal printing, such as accommodation guides and the sorts of things which people travelling through provincial and regional areas require and demand. The regional practitioner, the guy who has to go around and keep the whole show together, has to get around in a vehicle. But that too is not exempt from sales tax.

The government should be fair dinkum about regional development. I have just given three examples, but there are countless other items that regional tourist authorities need to use that are not exempt from sales tax and could be. As I said, the irony is that, where an organisation is run by the state government or a local authority, the whole thing is sales tax free. Yet, when business gets in behind the government, throws its weight in and drives the government dollar further, it has the added penalty of having to pay sales tax. It is just illogical.

Let us move to the regional development organisations, which are sometimes tourism and sometimes just industry and regional development. They are the white knights that government departments come out to when there is a new government program, an OLMA program on the go—`Can you run with this or can you run that?'. I do not criticise that in any way; I think it is quite appropriate that they should. However, they have to source the projects and the opportunities. They have to form the prima facie case to put to government, prepare the submissions, run the study or the project, frequently providing all the resource backup—the computers, photocopies and vehicles which we spoke about—provide skilled staff, report on the study or the project and have to account with audited statements. We know how important that is from what has gone on with the sports rorts affair over the last few weeks. Most importantly, when the study or project is finished, an organisation needs to run with that idea or that project and take it on into the next phase. It should not be another study that gets pidgeonholed and put away.

If the regional organisation is a state or local authority instrumentality, sales tax exemption applies and there are no problems at all. But, where private industry gets in with government or local government to do the same job, sales tax is levied. The computer that holds the data on the region—its resources, its skills and local authority zoning data—the photocopier that puts out all the information and the vehicle that the practitioner has to drive around in to keep the region together are all subject to the levying of sales tax.

I intend to speak about this matter a lot more when we see the Kelty report and the final documents from the IC inquiry into regional industry adjustment. For the meantime, perhaps the parliamentary secretary might take on board those five areas of sales tax exemption as creative and sensible ways to create a lot of safety—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to and read with great interest the many excellent speeches made to date on these appropriation bills from honourable members on both sides of the House. As one honourable member noted in his speech, the appropriation bills give members an opportunity to air their views on ideas of major economic and social concern to the nation. Having listened to and read these debates, I have come to two very valid conclusions: firstly, members on both sides of the House have the interests of their constituents and indeed the interests of the nation at heart; and, secondly, nobody in this House, I guess on either side, has a monopoly on the truth.

PARA.TAB: There is an eerie commonality of agreement about the problems which we consider need to be urgently tackled if the nation is to progress in an economic and social sense and if living standards are to be maintained and improved. The great divergence of view in this House centres more on the means than on the ends. Having said that, I do not underrate the deep and real differences that exist between those on this side of the House and those opposite.

In 1993 the Australian people had a democratic opportunity to assess the respective visions for this nation and it is now a fact of Australian political history that, in the midst of global change and domestic uncertainty, the Australian people chose the Labor Party's vision for Australia. One reason why the people of this nation warmed to our vision is the Australian Labor Party's deep and abiding concern for the disadvantaged and the dispossessed in our society and our willingness to commit the resources of government to provide all Australians with an expanded opportunity to feed and clothe their families, to be housed, to work, and to contribute to the life of their local and national communities.

It is the opportunity to work that I wish to focus my attention on in this debate. Many words have been spoken in this parliament on economic policy and on the problems of the unemployed. No-one on either side of this House seeks to dismiss the dreadful human cost to those who seek to obtain work but cannot find it. For Labor members in government there can be no greater concern than unemployment. We all seek an appropriate policy framework that allows enterprises to grow and to create employment.

The Labor Party acknowledges the historical reality of Australia's mixed economy and sees as its primary economic task to encourage greater economic efficiency and productivity in both the public and the private sectors. We acknowledge the role of the market as a primary allocator of scarce resources in this economy, but we also appreciate and understand the capacity of the market to fail. We do not hesitate to bring the resources of government or the influence of government to bear on the market in pursuit of the larger social and economic goals that this great social democratic party has determined.

Before we can look down the time tunnel as to where the economy ought to be going, we ought to appreciate and make a realistic assessment of where the economy is at this point in time. The snapshot that I intend to draw for the House will be as clinical as I can make it. I acknowledge the problems that exist in the Australian economy, but I wish also to acknowledge the great strides that have been made over the past decade in the area of economic policy and to acknowledge the contribution of the economic ministers who have formed the backbone of the Labor government in power from 1983 to this point.

Australia's international competitiveness is the best that it has been for some 30 years. We have seen improvements over the last decade of some 30 per cent in Australia's competitive position. Our inflation rate is now running at about two per cent, which is the lowest it has been for some 30 years. Although interest rates reached a peak throughout the 1980s, we see now that they are the lowest that they have been for some 20 years. As far as the profitability of Australian enterprises is concerned, today we observed record profit levels being experienced in the business sector. We have ushered in a cooperative industrial relations system that is seeing the lowest level of disputation since the 1960s.

In relation to the taxation regime for individuals and businesses, we have moved Australia from being a high tax country compared with its OECD competitors to a low tax country. That is a proposition that some in our community really do not want to acknowledge, but it is a fact of our commercial life. We have seen positive economic growth for the last nine quarters and the expectation is that the economy will grow faster than the official predictions that were made in the last budget. Since August we have seen the economy generate some 145,000 jobs and, in the year to September 1993, productivity has grown by 2.5 per cent.

More importantly, over the 1980s we have seen a change in business culture. We have seen business focus itself more on exporting. We have seen a greater emphasis on quality management at all levels in enterprises. We have seen a greater emphasis on training, on research and development and on best practice. These are encouraging developments. We will not see the sustained growth in the Australian economy unless the changes in the business culture permeate down especially to our small and medium enterprises.

The improved competitiveness in the Australian economy today is due to the low level of inflation that is currently being experienced, the depreciation of the Australian dollar, reductions that we have engineered in our relative unit labour costs throughout the 1980s, the gains that we have achieved in the area of micro-economic reform, and the productivity growth that I just mentioned. All these factors position the Australian economy to take advantage of the growth that is now taking place and that will take place in the international economy over the years to the end of this decade.

I highlight the important improvements that we have made to our export performance. In 1983, exports comprised some 13 per cent of our GDP and in 1993 they comprised some 20 per cent of our GDP. There has been a dramatic shift within exports. We are not just exporting raw materials; we have seen a significant and massive shift to elaborately transformed manufactures. Also we have seen a dramatic growth in the export of services. In the period from 1986 to 1992, Australian exports of elaborately transformed manufactures grew in the order of 19 per cent compared with an average of some 11 per cent for our trading partners. That is a very important achievement. In the micro-economic reform area, this government has undertaken the task of transforming the economy from an inefficient, in the main uncompetitive, inward looking industrial structure to an internationally competitive one.

Our past achievements in the areas of the waterfront, industrial relations, transport and telecommunications are milestone achievements for any government in power throughout the world in the 1980s. The present focus of micro-economic reform was articulated at the COAG meeting held last week, where major agreement was reached between the Commonwealth and state governments on the micro-economic reform agenda that will take us through to the year 2000.

I sound a note of caution about the thrust to competition policy. I do not think anybody disagrees substantially with the notion that competition brings out the best in enterprises and that it ought to be an objective for any industrial structure. An unbridled competitive policy has the potential to generate significant unemployment. That is something that we ought to keep our minds on as we move into this new phase of the micro-economic reform agenda.

Business investment has lagged the general recovery, and capacity utilisation has been low in recent years. However, as growth continues, there will be a greater inducement for firms to invest. Coming on the back of the incentives that the government has already put in place over the 1980s and in the One Nation statement in the recent budget, that will certainly give a stimulus to investment over the next two years of the life of this government. In 1992, in the One Nation statement we saw accelerated depreciation allowances. We have seen reductions in company tax to 33 per cent, a 10 per cent general investment allowance and development allowances. The total cost of those measures to government revenue has been in the order of $800 million. It is not an unsubstantial incentive to the business community to invest in Australian enterprises.

There are other factors in the economy at present that are conducive to this impetus for greater investment. I mentioned high profitability levels. The interest rate regime is low, inflation is low, and inflationary expectations are also low. The consumer outlook is positive, and we have seen the general improvement in competitiveness. All those factors will improve business investment in the Australian economy.

As far as the export orientation of the Australian economy is concerned, there has been a deliberate government policy to foster a closer engagement in the Asia-Pacific region on a political, cultural and economic level. Our participation in APEC is central to those efforts. Our efforts over the 1980s have been rewarded. Exports to this dynamic growth region of the world—the east Asia region, including Japan—now account for some 60 per cent of all our exports. This focus does not necessarily mean that we have to abandon other global regions throughout the world. As we progress to the year 2000, I am sure that we will see the export gun sights turn on other regions of the world to stimulate our export performance. As a government, we have not been afraid to enter the zone of policy development in the industry area, nor to enter the zone of devising policies to overcome unemployment and to take up the regional policy development debate.

Amidst the positive news on the economy, there are two major persistent problems. I refer to the high level of unemployment, which is now around 10.6 per cent, and the external deficit on the current account. The solutions that we devise ought to aim, where possible, at overcoming those two problems. The strategy ought to be to lower the demand for imports and to generate demand for locally produced goods and services. It is naive and foolhardy to suggest that any one set of measures has all the answers.

The government's contribution to a solution falls in two areas. It falls in getting the macro settings right and devising a specific set of measures that will stimulate investment and consumption in the domestic economy. I suggest that there is a range of such measures that the government, within its existing resources, can bring to bear on the problem. In a recent forum within my own parliamentary party, I outlined a set of initiatives that, in addition to the growth generated by the recovery already under way, would further stimulate domestic demand and assist the creation of over 200,000 jobs. Most of the proposals are based on the fundamental premise that employment can be stimulated in the private sector by stimulating demand, and they really do obviate the need for any jobs levy. I am not convinced that a jobs levy is necessary in the current economic environment.

A study undertaken by Professor Jensen on the impact of new and retained manufacturing activity on general economic activity was submitted in evidence to the parliamentary inquiry on government purchasing. That evidence was given by the Industrial Supplies Office. It indicated that each $1 million of new or retained manufacturing activity in Australia could be expected to produce approximately 29 new jobs, some $28,000 in taxes and charges at all levels of government, $255,000 in direct consumer expenditure, and $231,000 in welfare savings to government.

The five points that I proposed and outlined have the capacity, as I stated, to generate some 200,000 jobs. The first point, which I think the government will give consideration to in its budget deliberations, is a stimulus to infrastructure spending, which will be related closely to labour market programs and targeted to the long-term unemployed. The government is entering a fiscal position where it will be able to undertake additional expenditures. As the economy recovers and gathers pace, and as employment grows, the government will reap expenditure savings and revenue gains from that situation.

Various program vehicles have been oiled through the One Nation process, in partnership with state and local government, which can be brought to bear as vehicles on this particular problem. I refer to the better cities program, the local capital works program, general road funding, the LEAP, and the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program, which ought to be reinstated in the budget.

Our aim in this infrastructure spending should be to generate some 40,000 to 50,000 jobs. If honourable members do have some concerns about the fiscal capacity of the Commonwealth to undertake this infrastructure expenditure, I refer them to the rather innovative taxation proposals that were tabled by the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and outlined in the Australian Financial Review today.

Another initiative that I think can be taken up is to strengthen the Industrial Supplies Office network. For firms to take on additional units of labour, they need access to more business. Some of that business will come from the effects of general recovery, but they need access to import replacement business, which will build solidly on that normal growth. I think the Industrial Supplies Office has a greater role to play here. It can be expanded in providing for regional firms to be included in regional databases and developing a more sophisticated national database.

I have an interesting example of the involvement of the ISO in my electorate. It was founded and trialled first in my electorate, and I am hoping that in the next budget the ISO can be brought home to Geelong. I have put forward a proposal. Our target ought to be to divert consumption from some half a billion dollars worth of expenditure on imports to domestic manufacturing. That has the capacity to produce some 15,000 to 20,000 jobs.

The area which I think offers some great opportunities for stimulating employment growth is a reorientation of government purchasing policy. The current inquiry into the government's purchasing policy indicates that there is much more that we can do to link this purchasing policy to industry development and employment creation. Local, state and federal expenditures total some $30 billion. Our aim ought to be to divert $3 billion of that to local manufacturing over the next three years, with a net gain to employment of some 90,000. What is required is the political will. By comparison with other countries in this area, we are very poor indeed. Much more can be done in that particular area to stimulate job growth. I think there ought to be a massive expansion of the buy Australian campaign to tackle the culture of consumption in the country, which is inherently biased against Australian manufacturers. It is an issue that I will take up in a later speech to the parliament. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will commence by making an apology to the House. Last Thursday was a black day for the institution of parliament. Each and every one of us should, as representatives of the Australian people, be ashamed for what happened here last week. It was a performance inappropriate for members of parliament. I think we all owe the people of Australia an apology.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, in apologising I will explain the circumstances behind the uproar during last Thursday's sitting. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) moved a motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and, in so doing, forfeited our right to ask questions. Of course, it is our right as the opposition, with the role of keeping the government accountable, to move a motion of censure against the Prime Minister for his faithful protection of an incompetent minister who is both morally and politically corrupt.

We were abused for abandoning question time. But this was a most important motion and one which we had a responsibility to move. We decided to abandon question time and bring the motion straight on in light of the repeated failure of the then Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), to answer any questions and given the fact that the Prime Minister had prepared seven dorothy dixers in which he would have launched a tirade of abuse at us.

The coalition had an obligation to bring the Prime Minister to account for his loyalty to a most incompetent, corrupt and dishonest minister, the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. When speaking to the motion, the speech of the Leader of the Opposition was continually interrupted by members opposite. There was constant and unending rowdiness coming from those opposite. The Leader of the Opposition had to shout his speech. Even then, it was extremely difficult to hear.

Throughout his speech, the Leader of the Opposition was afforded little, if any, protection by the Speaker, despite the actions of the members opposite being contrary to the standing orders. Of course, the reason for members opposite behaving like unruly school children is that the former Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr McLeay), a man who of all people should have the utmost respect for the standing orders, went around telling government members to be as rowdy as possible so that the Leader of the Opposition's speech would be unheard.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should know better.

—As the honourable member for Forrest has said, he should know better. He did this to protect his mates in the New South Wales Right—the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories. As is typical of this man, whom I described earlier today as a thug, he ignored all standards of procedure in this place, which he knows and understands, having had the—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! I believe the honourable member should be more careful with his wording. It is unparliamentary to reflect on a person as you have been doing. The shadow minister need not comment either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about the honourable member for Watson. He knows the standards and understands them, having had to uphold them for a time. He ensured that the motion—a very important and rarely used motion—was not given the seriousness it deserved. If anyone should have been thrown out last Thursday, it should have been the honourable member for Watson.

PARA.TAB: When the Leader of the Opposition completed his speech, the coalition had two choices, as far as I can see: firstly, to allow the Prime Minister, in silence and in respect of standing orders, to launch a tirade of abuse at the coalition for the press gallery to lap up; or, secondly, to do unto the Prime Minister as the Labor Party did to the Leader of the Opposition. With reluctance, we took the second option. We decided to give the Prime Minister and the Labor Party a taste of their own medicine. As we all know now, they absolutely hated it. They can dish it out, but, boy oh boy, when it came time to take it, they could not take it at all.

The first interjection was met by retaliation from the Speaker. Similar protection was not afforded to the Leader of the Opposition. The fact that the public gallery erupted into spontaneous applause when the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) pleaded for fairer play from the Speaker is indicative of the way this debate was perceived by the people of Australia. They acknowledged that the then minister was morally and politically corrupt, that the Prime Minister deserved to be censured, that the government's tactics in stymieing the debate were blatantly unfair and that the Speaker's failure to discipline government members was a sad indictment of the falling standards we are seeing in this place.

I can well understand why the public would be dismayed about last Thursday's performance. We should all hang our heads in shame, for it was a black day for this fine institution of democracy. Nevertheless, while I apologise to the people of Australia, and the people of Stirling in particular, for our behaviour, I say that the coalition had no other choice than to give the Labor Party a taste of its own medicine.

Thursday also showed us that the Labor Party shows continuing utter contempt for the institution of the parliament and has little regard for its procedures and rules and for the way it should operate. The people of Australia would quite rightly be very dismayed about the way that the Labor Party is subverting the parliament—the people's house and such a fine institution of democracy. It tells us quite a lot about the Labor Party.

I would also like to comment further on the sports rorts affair, which today saw, quite rightly, the resignation of a most unaccountable, incompetent and inept minister. I spoke briefly on the majority and dissenting reports earlier today, but time prohibited me from commenting on other issues to do with that report.

In particular, I was most concerned at the thuggery tactics of certain government members, particularly those of the New South Wales right, whom I have already mentioned, led by leaping, leaking Leo, the honourable member for Watson. Those government members had a prearranged agenda to harass opposition members and audit office staff. They attempted to protect the minister in their various ways, even trying to answer questions asked of her when she appeared at a public hearing of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Fortunately, that was open for all and sundry to see, so they could see exactly what was going on.

These people also succeeded in prohibiting the calling of certain and very necessary witnesses and evidence. They disrupted proceedings, and their overall conduct was unbecoming of committee members. In essence, their actions shirked the responsibilities they should have displayed as members of this committee. Their agenda was not to seek to find the truth about this program; rather, their agenda was merely to protect a discredited, inept minister. They should hang their heads in shame for their appalling conduct.

When the minister came to the committee hearing, these same members—with the exception of the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), whom I must commend for not attempting to pervert the proceedings of the committee—abused members of the public gallery. They interjected questions as a form of protecting the minister, and they even attempted to answer questions asked of the minister, showing that she did not know many answers and thus required protection. Finally, they again heckled and abused coalition members for questions which we had the temerity to ask.

I would also like to comment on the conduct of the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who accused coalition members of leaking the draft report of the committee to various journalists. These were unfounded, unsubstantiated, spurious allegations. The chairman, who has repeatedly accused opposition members of leaking information, made such allegations without substance or evidence. His partisan comments make him unfit to be chairman when his position demands that he be impartial. In view of the chairman's having expressed his biased ideas, I believe that he has no course other than to resign. I shall be pursuing that further.

This affair has also shown that the government has no standards for ministers to abide by. It is now necessary for the Prime Minister to establish a code of conduct which ministers must follow to ensure that they remain accountable to parliament and, in particular, the people of Australia, whom we represent here. The code should be a strict guideline detailing the standards of accountability which must be met by a minister. If these standards are not met, that minister should be met with strict discipline by the Prime Minister.

I hope that the Prime Minister adopts such a code, which should be very specific as to the detail of accountability required of ministers. Failure to require any such standards would be an admission that the Prime Minister cares little for accountability in government, which is anathema to the principles of democracy which we hold so dear in our proud nation.

Finally, on this issue, which I assure honourable members will not be laid to rest for quite a while, I suggest to the relevant minister's office that it seeks to acquire better technological mechanisms by which to operate. The former minister's use of a whiteboard is now well known, even though none of us were able to get to see it—but we do not bother about that now. It was improper, to say the least, for the former minister to dish out $30 million in grants using a whiteboard as the major instrument of recording data.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —In almost 11 years as a member of the House of Representatives, I do not think I have heard such a grubby contribution to debate. It was venomous and it was full of caustic invective against a person unable to defend herself in this chamber. I believe that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) has set a standard for himself which will not be the envy of any member on both sides of this House. He has done himself a great disservice today in delivering that speech.
