PARA.TAB: The appropriation bills provide funding for the activities of the Commonwealth government. It is a fact that government in Australia is neither high taxing nor high spending. Government taxes and expenditures as a proportion of gross domestic product are among the lowest in the OECD. Thankfully, now the Australian people have rejected the burden of a ruinous goods and services tax urged by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), Australia will remain a low tax country.

This government wishes to preserve and enhance the institutions that have served the Australian people well. It is a government that seeks to uphold the values of the Australian people. In contrast to the members of the opposition, we on this side of the House know that sound and vigorous leadership is the essence of good government. Nowhere is this more important than in developing the economy of this nation. When they were in government, the Liberal and National parties left Australia with a high cost, grossly inefficient and protected industry, double-digit inflation, double-digit interest rates, double-digit unemployment and chronic balance of payment problems.

This government has shown the leadership to reverse the insular, inward looking culture of Australia developed over years of Liberal-National rule. Australians are now major participants in the growth opportunities emerging in Asia. Australians now have embraced the challenge of building an open and internationally competitive economy. Our industry is becoming proud to talk about its successes in innovation, worker relations and profitability. Ten years ago industry policy was governed by the handout mentality of the agrarian socialists in the coalition, and industry was only rewarded for failure.

Under this government the Australian economy has grown in real terms at a rate of 3.1 per cent annually. This performance exceeded average growth across all OECD countries of 2.7 per cent over the same period. Currently the Australian economy is moving forward at 3.4 per cent per annum—one of the highest rates of expansion in the OECD. In addition, the OECD forecasts that economic growth in Australia will be well above the average for all member countries over the next two years.

As a direct result of increased emphasis on micro-economic reform and government efforts to instil an export culture within industry, the Australian economy has become more international in outlook. Exports of goods and services rose by close to 70 per cent in real terms between 1984-85 and 1992-93. Manufactured exports were the star performers which more than doubled in real terms over the same eight-year period. Imports of goods and services in real terms grew by a more modest 42 per cent.

The 1980s and the early 1990s have been a period of major structural change for the manufacturing and service sectors of the Australian economy, as firms in the manufacturing, and more recently, the service sector have made an increased commitment to improving productivity. Strong employment growth in manufacturing and services suggests that the restructuring process may be complete in many industries. Optimism for sustained employment growth may therefore be warranted. Evidence of improving competitiveness is found in the continuing strong growth in manufactured and services exports. Manufactured exports have grown at an annual average of 9.2 per cent in the period 1985-86 to 1992-93, while services exports have recorded 8.6 per cent annual growth over the same period. Furthermore, the strong export growth of these sectors has continued despite a weak world economy, and a recession in Australia's largest overseas customer—Japan.

Now that even those purveyors of doom in the coalition recognise that Australia has entered a new period of growth, the issue that faces government is the management of that growth. The government recognises that, despite an improvement of 20 per cent in Australia's international competitiveness compared with 1989-90, there is still much to be done. Australia needs to maintain and increase its improved level of competitiveness to ensure that the balance of payments does not constrain growth. Australia has to continue to maintain the pace of micro-economic reform, and this means that the states must start to pull their weight. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is to be congratulated on his historic achievement last Friday in Hobart in gaining the support of the state premiers to establish the Australian Competitive Commission. State governments will no longer have unfettered power to protect their state monopolies in areas such as transport, electricity, gas and water from competition from the private sector.

Australia has also to raise its savings so that as investment grows we do not need to increasingly depend on the savings of other nations to fund our growth. The Commonwealth has set out its program of deficit reduction to reduce its impact on public dissaving, and this discipline needs to apply across the public sector. The private sector, too, needs to raise its level of savings to fund a new era of investment stimulated by stable asset values. The government is determined to maintain Australia's hard won low inflation status. As the Treasurer (Mr Willis) reported earlier this month the consumer price index was forecast to grow by 3.5 per cent in the budget, but as a result of a 0.2 per cent figure for the December quarter, the Treasurer is anticipating an inflation figure for the year of 2 per cent.

This government is not resting on its laurels. Honourable members will be aware of the government's announced intentions to set new standards in lowering costs of business and government through micro-economic reform, regulatory reform, and innovation and competition policy. In 1994 we all understand that industry policy is not about detailed prescriptions for industry where the government directs the flow of resources to inefficient industries. Nor is it about further tariff and quota protection and sheltering industry from international market signals. Nor is it about subsidies to prop up uncompetitive firms.

Government policy is set to create the environment for the development of innovative, flexible firms able to compete successfully in the international marketplace. The agreement reached on world trade through the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has greatly increased the potential for firms who can dynamically respond to new opportunities. While the agreement reached on world trade is a major breakthrough, much remains to ensure that the outcomes are translated into tangible benefits, particularly in our region. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) has indicated the high priority he places, together with the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), on breaking down impediments to the sale of Australian services and manufactured goods in our region.

As markets open, success in the 1990s will increasingly be as a result of innovation, including productivity improvement and technological change. President Clinton in his February 1993 statement Technology for America's economic growth: a new direction to build economic strength stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Technology is the engine of economic growth. In the United States, technological advance has been responsible for as much as two-thirds of productivity growth since the Depression. Breakthroughs such as the transistor, computers, recombinant DNA and synthetic materials have created entire new industries and millions of high paying jobs.

International competitiveness depends less and less on traditional factors such as access to natural resources and cheap labour. Instead, the new growth industries are knowledge based. They depend on the continuous generation of new technological innovations and the rapid transformation of these innovations into commercial products the world wants to buy. That requires a talented and adaptive work force capable of using the latest technologies and reaching ever-higher levels of productivity.

While technology is important to innovation and science, technology and invention are only part of innovation. Equally important are people and enterprises in translating technology into economic outcomes of benefit to the community as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Australia's new open, competitive business environment is building enterprises that are establishing a world reputation for Australian innovativeness. As our economy becomes more and more open and competitive, continued innovative performance will become essential for business survival in the 1990s. The rise in innovative performance of Australian enterprises of all sizes—small, medium and large—is the best indicator of our improved economic prospects not only for economic growth but also for employment growth. Never again will we let the dead hand of regulation, protectionism and fear of change stifle the innovative spirit of this nation.

I wish to make a few remarks about regional development. This government has recognised the critical need for a fresh and reinvigorated look at regional Australia and the contribution every region can make to national development. As the Prime Minister said in June 1993, this government wants to pull the regions of Australia into the national grid. It is not about parochialism, it is about partnership.

To this end, the government established the task force on regional development. It had the Industry Commission conduct an inquiry into impediments to regional industry adjustment and has engaged McKinsey and Co. to conduct a major study on business investment in regional Australia. Each one of these will provide a valuable input into the government's policy making process and provide a basis for establishing a framework to further advance the government's commitment. The report of the task force on regional development, called `Developing Australia', outlines a vision for this nation over a 30-year time frame and illustrates Australia's enormous and still relatively untapped economic potential. The report contains a check list of major infrastructure projects that would be of enormous benefit to the nation.

In my consultations with regional communities—this was also the experience of the regional task force—I have found that in the many and diverse parts of Australia there are many people who have a strong desire to make their community fully participate in Australia's development. A key role of this government will be to tap into that desire and harness it, not only for the benefit of the regions but for the benefit of the country as a whole.

Nowhere will the government's increased emphasis on regional development be more important than for northern Australia. While encompassing almost 50 per cent of Australia's land mass, but with only 5.4 per cent of the population, northern Australia nevertheless accounts for about 28 per cent of our exports. The growth prospects for minerals and hydrocarbon, tourism and agriculture are very promising, but the rapid growth has placed pressure on the provision of infrastructure and has also led to social problems. In this context, I was pleased to be able to announce last week the grant of $250,000 of Commonwealth funds to establish a northern Australia social research institute, which is a collaborative effort between the James Cook University of North Queensland, the University of the Northern Territory and Hedland College in Western Australia.

There is much misunderstanding of the development potential of the north. It is worth while to reflect just for a moment on the development of Ord River, for it illustrates many lessons of northern development. The development of irrigated pastures for the Ord and Fitzroy rivers was a dream of the Durack family dating back to the turn of the century. Honourable members will recall Mary Durack's book Kings in Grass Houses, about life on a cattle station in the Kimberleys. In 1940 a Western Australian royal commission recommended the establishment of a research station in the Ord Valley. In 1941 a small experimental irrigation research farm was established. In 1945 CSIRO joined with the Western Australian department of agriculture in establishing a Kimberley research station. In 1967 a decision was made to proceed with the construction of the main Ord River dam, which resulted in the establishment of Lake Argyle, a reservoir with nine times the water of Sydney Harbour. The recent ASTEC report on research and technology in tropical Australia is most critical of the research and development undertaken at the Ord. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Even when the dam was opened in 1972 research data on suitable crop regimes was unavailable or incomplete, and pest problems were unresolved.

The main focus of research at the Ord had been directed at cotton and, despite the incomplete research base, commercial production was attempted. The result was a disaster that is so well cited in fashionable southern circles, government and academic. What is not so well known is that, following the abandonment of cotton in 1974, the growers slowly and with much effort and hard work began to develop new crops, many of which were not considered seriously at all in previous decades. As a result, the value of agricultural production from the Ord has steadily climbed from approximately $9 million in 1985-86 to about $32 million in 1991-92. Subsidies for production ceased in the mid-1980s and commercial agriculture is sufficiently progressed now for the Western Australian government to move to full cost recovery.

PARA.TAB: The heritage of 50 years of research effort into the crop production in the Ord Valley has resulted in the development of a sophisticated and well educated grower community, many of whom are ex-research staff with higher degrees. Their skills enable a wide range of crops to be grown, including bananas, rockmelons, watermelons, hybrid seeds, maize, sorghum and beans. Despite the hopes, the aspirations and the plans for the Ord over 100 years and the substantial progress in recent years, development of the region remains well short of its potential. Presently, less than 10 per cent of a possible 75,000 hectares is under irrigation in the Ord River irrigation area.

The value of agricultural production at the Ord is now on the brink of major expansion. For a number of years the Ord River District Cooperative, in conjunction with the engineering design firm Schultz, Tait and Greig, have undertaken considerable original research on the milling of sugar on the appropriate scale for establishing the industry at the Ord. This research has been extensively evaluated by the Sugar Research Institute and CSR Ltd. I am pleased to be able to announce that the tax concession committee of the Industrial Research and Development Board decided on 3 February 1994 that development work undertaken was innovative research, eligible for the 150 per cent R&D tax concession.

The Ord River District Cooperative has developed a proposal to build a sugar mill to process 560,000 tonnes of cane per annum. At current market prices the value of this production would be about $25 million—a small fraction of the total Australian production of $1.4 billion, but nevertheless very significant to the economic prosperity of this region. Honourable members will be aware of the importance of the sugar industry in establishing the thriving cities and towns of coastal North Queensland. I understand that CSR has had initial discussions with the Ord River Development Commission regarding the possibility of establishing a sugar industry in the Ord and that those discussions are continuing under a memorandum of understanding between the parties. These developments represent more progress on the establishment of a sugar industry in the Ord than has ever occurred in the past.

As well as sugar, intensive cattle fattening on leucaena pastures holds much promise for further development. The cattle fattening industry is critically dependent on the growth of the live cattle trade with South-East Asia, which is booming through the port of Darwin. The prospects are very favourable.

The Ord River development is an important case study of the development of the north. I would like to provide honourable members very quickly with an impression of the magnitude of the developments occurring in the north. Oil and particularly gas have been a major area of investment in the North West Shelf of Western Australia. All Australians would be aware of the massive capital investment of close to $10 billion in infrastructure to establish the Woodside liquid natural gas

SPEECH.PARA: facility and associated gas pipelines. From 1995, when additional production comes on line, LNG and condensate sales from Woodside's facility will be worth an estimated $2 billion per year.

PARA.TAB: Iron ore production in the Pilbara is worth in excess of $2.7 billion annually. Western Australian governments have been interested in encouraging its further processing. The availability of gas and the development of new iron ore processing technology, such as the direct reduced iron, offer new hopes for further processing. Such developments are best fostered not by governments establishing special plans and programs but by ensuring the free and open operation of markets.

The development of Darwin also would be considerably enhanced through the availability of a long-term supply of gas and low cost power. The area around Darwin has long been held to be prospective for oil and gas but drilling, unfortunately, to date has been very disappointing.

There has been a lot of talk from some high profile members of the mining community about Mabo and the supposed impediment it poses to mining development. Let me say it simply: Mabo is not anti mining development in Australia. But, equally, Mabo does not permit any mining company to ride roughshod over the rights of any Australians, whatever colour they may be. On 11 April this year I will be attending the opening of the Mount Todd goldmine just east of Katherine in the Northern Territory. This mine will cost over $140 million to establish. It will produce over 150,000 ounces of gold per year, worth $80 million in current gold prices. There are sufficient reserves there for 25 years.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that not only in northern Australia but all over Australia the evidence is clear: Australia is entering a new and historically important era of growth. The agreement the Prime Minister has achieved with the states at the Council of Australian Governments meeting will provide a major stimulus for sustained growth. Government business monopolies produce only 10 per cent of the nation's output from 19 per cent of the nation's capital stock. Competition will bring about lower prices, better service and increased product and service innovation. This government has tackled the legacy of an uncompetitive traded goods sector left to it by the Liberal and National parties. It has now set course for an efficient non-traded goods sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay). The honourable member is obviously a great optimist, and I am sure his knowledge of northern Australia is very important knowledge to impart to all of us. I found myself agreeing with a lot of what he said in the sense that regional development is now on the agenda, thank goodness. It is on the agenda for all political parties in this federal parliament, as it should have been many years ago but, regrettably, was not.

PARA.TAB: The appropriation bills about which I am speaking, Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), are a lead-up to the full formal budget, which is to be delivered by the government before 30 June and which will be an historic occasion. The point is that in this debate we can signal in a broad way some of the areas that we believe need addressing and some of the areas that need to be given great priority.

From my point of view, regional development is absolutely fundamental to the future of Australia. If we do it properly, we can expect to reap a very good harvest. If we just pay it lip-service and do not make the decisions that we should with respect to strategic policies, then regional development will not prosper as it should and Australia will not fulfil its full identity as a robust nation, based on a federation which maximises the contribution of city and country people and which recognises that city and country people are a partnership and cannot exist independently of each other; they rely on each other. My view of the future of Australia is that we will increasingly rely on each other as we go into the next century.

Bodies such as the Association of Development Executives Victoria, which is a professional association of personnel involved in economic development in Victoria, often speak to me. They have recently made a submission to the federal government in response to the task force recommendations. I recommend that any members who are interested in regional development should spend as much time as possible talking to the practitioners and the people out in the regions, such as the members of the Association of Development Executives Victoria, before they make a final decision as to the model that will be adopted to deliver regional coordination, management and policies.

Many of us, and I think it is fair to include the Association of Development Executives Victoria, fear that there may be another bureaucracy established by the present government with respect to its proposed regional development policies. We already have far too much bureaucracy. We have different spheres of local, state and federal government and we have associations of regional bodies throughout Australia. I understand that the broad proposals of the federal government are looking at some model of regional management and coordination. So it will be a great challenge to determine how to sort that out and how to deliver a model that will not create another bureaucracy and that will not use the strengths of existing bureaucratic structures.

The other point I would like to make is that we are not achieving the full potential of regions in Australia because of the regressive tax system that we have. I give one example of how tax is adversely affecting Australia's future and retarding regional development. I refer to the states payroll tax, the infamous tax on employment. We are a nation which, unfortunately, has one million unemployed people, and most of those are young Australians. We also have an ever increasing number of unemployed Australians who are 40 years and over. We allow each state in Australia to provide an ever increasing amount of its annual revenue requirements by taxing jobs; that is, by allowing payroll tax to be levied on companies and small businesses. Each job that is created faces an increase in payout of payroll tax. Victoria receives in the vicinity of $7 billion a year from payroll tax.

The history of payroll tax is fairly well known. It arose during the time of the Second World War. It was regarded as a temporary measure and, unfortunately, it has become enshrined in the system. It is true to say that, if we waved a magic wand and took away the payroll tax revenue from each state in Australia overnight, they would be in severe financial crisis. They rely on this money now. They cannot do away with it, unless the funds are replaced by some other measure. I regard that as one of the major strategic policies that has to be addressed with respect to Australia's future and particularly with respect to regional development.

When I was a member of the Victorian government and the Victorian parliament, we had policies that gave exemptions from payroll tax for new, approved industries established in decentralised locations in the state. That model worked for a long while and certainly helped to create new investment and jobs in regional Victoria. But, after a while, because it was a blank cheque, so to speak, it was not as effective as it should have been because once granted it continued. It was not seen so much as an incentive.

Recently, there have been proposals that payroll tax exemptions should be reintroduced in Victoria, but for fixed periods, such as five or seven years. This is so the companies and businesses that are set up know where they stand. They are given relief from payroll tax for a period of years and then, after that, they go back to being normal taxpayers, paying the same rates of payroll tax as every other unfortunate victim. Somewhere between those two poles is the area we ought to go to. But I would certainly prefer to see the federal government, in conjunction with the states and local government and with business and industry, examining the ways and means—and there are ways and means, which I will not spell out here now—to eliminate payroll tax totally. If the most regressive tax on employment were done away with, we would be a far better nation and we would be able to get on and create more jobs, particularly to help the unfortunate unemployed people.

As a member from regional Australia in north-east Victoria, I know that the tyranny of distance is always a problem. I get increasingly disappointed with the fact that almost every budget, state and federal, takes a greater bite out of people's revenue, investments, capital and personal income in the form of fuel excise and fuel tax. For country people, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, would know, the tyranny of distance is a great problem. If we want to attract industry and small business or increase farming activity, which we must do on this continent, how can we continue to ask people to take the risks to invest and to work harder than they do now? Goodness me, most of them work pretty hard now. Why should we ask them to do this when we will penalise them in the area that hurts them most; that is, in the transport area? We have to get our products to the seaboard. We have to get our products to the factories for value adding. We have to deliver them to the major markets. People living in regional Australia spend almost every minute of the day looking around and seeing that they are being penalised through the fuel excise and fuel taxes.

I was particularly disappointed to see in the first budget that I witnessed in this place since I was elected that fuel excise increase by 2c a litre for leaded and 1c a litre for unleaded, with another 1c to come in August this year. It is true to say that the petrol pump in Australia is an active and very hungry branch of the Australian Taxation Office. I fear that, unless something drastic is done, it will get worse and not better. If the fuel excise were being used to pay for roads, then we could perhaps argue that it is a form of toll and therefore that it is worth maintaining in some form or other.

I will give the House some figures. In 1983-84, 10 years ago, the fuel excise revenue of the Commonwealth was $1.8 billion, which is equal to four per cent of the total tax revenue at that time. Ten years later, in 1993-94, fuel excise is estimated to reap $8.3 billion, 800 per cent more, which is equal to 8.9 per cent of total tax revenue. So the total tax revenue for the Commonwealth has more than doubled in 10 years.

Federal government spending on roads, of course, has not kept up with that dramatic increase in the revenue take for fuel tax. For example, 10 years ago in the 1983-84 budget, federal spending on roads amounted to $1.2 billion while the fuel tax generated $1.8 million. So, out of each dollar collected in fuel excise 10 years ago, 66c was being spent on roads. In 1993-94, 10 years later, $1 billion is allocated by the federal government to be spent on roads in Australia, while the fuel tax collected will be $8.3 billion. Therefore, out of every dollar collected in fuel excise in 1993-94 only 12c is spent on roads. So in 10 years we have reduced the spending from 66c in the dollar to 12c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what happened to personal taxation.

—Personal taxation of course has changed and the rates are now lower with respect to certain sections of the community. That is to be welcomed, and I do that. But the problem is that the indirect taxes and charges such as the fuel tax, the payroll tax and the wholesale sales tax are taking an ever increasing bite and adding to the costs for everybody, particularly those that we are trying to encourage to make investments in business, in industry and, particularly from my point of view, in regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have got a big problem and it is made worse because we now find in regional parts of Australia such as in my home territory, north-east Victoria, the actual cost of fuel at the retail petrol pump is many cents per litre more than in metropolitan Melbourne. In some cases, we have variations of 15c per litre. We all know that there has to be a variation because of the costs of transport. That is fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not 15c a litre.

—But not 15c a litre. It is well known and accepted that the approximate cost of transportation is about 1.2c per litre from Melbourne to Albury-Wodonga. So we have this incredible retail difference of 13c to 15c per litre for country people compared with metropolitan people. When companies are confronted with this they say that they are allowed to do their own marketing and discounting to handle competition in the major metropolitan areas and that is all it is. But there is clear evidence that this difference is being subsidised and paid for by people living in regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: In my view, the oil companies have not revealed the full facts and are hiding behind the fact that the wholesale prices are fixed by the rather antiquated system of the South Australian Prices Surveillance Authority and that retail prices are allowed to fluctuate in the free market. But it is not a free, open, fair market when we have consistently such a large difference in price for the same quantity of fuel, less the cost of freight, being sold 300 kilometres away, for example, in Melbourne compared with Wangaratta, Benalla or Wodonga.

It is scandalous and the government needs to look urgently at the Trade Practices Act, which I believe is one of the reasons for our problem. There ought to be a more vigorous public inquiry—I know there is an inquiry going on—and examination into this unfair imposition, which is causing a lot of resentment among country people and is costing us jobs.
Another area that I am particularly interested in is health. I see Medicare, which we all support—there have been debates over the years between the parties—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's news; you'd better tell the other blokes.

—There is no doubt that Medicare is supported by the coalition, let me put that quite plainly and unqualifiedly, despite attempts in the last federal election for our position to be misrepresented. But the problem with Medicare is that it needs surgery urgently and if it does not get that surgery we will find more people missing out on the treatment that all taxpayers want everyone to get. That is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The waiting list for pain relieving surgery in Australia is enormous. Some honourable members would know this as they may have family and friends suffering pain because they cannot get an operation which is regarded as so-called elective surgery, not trauma surgery. Take the case of a child who has suffered trauma in a motor accident and needs surgery on the face followed by cosmetic surgery. I can tell honourable members that the initial surgery is available immediately, as it should be, following the accident but the cosmetic surgery—the skin grafts, et cetera—is delayed. Sometimes the operations are cancelled after the child has been admitted the night before the operation for the ongoing skin grafts. The operations are cancelled because of the problems with funding and the pressures on public hospitals. These are very real, serious problems. Elderly people needing hip replacements or other orthopaedic operations suffer similarly. I do not believe it is acceptable for us to allow this to continue.

I particularly note the public conflict between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Senator Richardson, the current Minister for Health, with respect to the ways in which we can help overcome this problem. One of the reasons for the problem, we all know, is that more and more people are dropping out of private health insurance for various reasons, mainly cost, and saying, `We are paying our Medicare levy, we may as well go to the public hospital to seek our treatment'. So we are finding that low income people, pensioners, aged and unemployed people, are in the same queues waiting for treatment at public hospitals as people—I call them, somewhat irreverently, those with the Toorak gall bladder—that have dropped out of private health insurance but are still able to take out insurance if given some form of incentive. That means that there is less money for the public hospitals to provide the treatment.

It does not matter what our philosophical view is, commonsense should prevail. The Prime Minister, in my view, should pick up broadly Senator Richardson's recommendations that would restore some incentive to people to take out private health insurance or to maintain it, which of course has been a coalition policy for some years. That is an unresolved urgent issue. Whereas eight or 10 years ago something like 70 per cent of Australians took out some form of private health insurance as well as paying Medicare levies, that number is now down to 40 per cent. I predict that, unless something is done urgently, the number of people with private health insurance in Australia by next year will be less than 30 per cent.

That means we will have more people looking for services in public hospitals. To provide the service we have to put huge amounts of extra money in. Where is that money going to come from? Is the government going to increase the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent, a further imposition on families, business and everyone else? Or is it going to use its nous and do what it should, maximise the use of the private and public health systems of Australia so that they complement each other and achieve the reforms that we need?
There are a lot of other issues that I would like to raise, but in view of the time I will terminate now. I look forward to a spirited debate on the budget when it is delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to follow on from some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) in the close of his address on the appropriation bills with regard to proposed health care reforms of the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson. My electorate has one of Australia's leading orthopaedic surgeons Dr Bill Cumberland. I recently received some correspondence from him with regard to the proposed reforms that have been put out for discussion by the health minister. Dr Cumberland's letter to me states:

SPEECH.PARA: As I explained you, the problems which exist in the Private Sector of the Health Care System in Australia and are trying to be addressed by Senator Richardson are analogous to a malady of a patients limb and the treatment prescribed by "Dr Richardson" is an unnecessary amputation. The further danger in his prescribed treatment is that more proximal amputations may subsequently be required, where as to cure this malady the patient really only needs medication rather than radical surgery.

Managed Care will put the dollar ahead of the patient in the Private Health System and it is this certainly to a large part which has ruined the Public Health System. Private Corporations are bound by their Shareholders to seek profits and under Managed Care it will be the quantity and quality of Health Care of the Private Patient which is sacrificed in order to maximise this profit.

I have had the pleasure of discussing Senator Richardson's proposed health care reforms with Dr Cumberland and it is pleasing to hear such an informed voice on the topic. I would therefore like to put on record some of the criticisms Dr Cumberland, the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons and I have found in this discussion paper. First—this is highlighted in the Australian Medical Association's issues paper entitled Right problem, wrong answer!—the discussion paper released by Senator Richardson is far too general. It is only a vague outline and gives little explanation as to how the reforms might work in practice. In contradiction of its name, this discussion paper has actually acted in many cases as an impediment to effective dialogue.

PARA.TAB: A very strong argument is also raised by the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons concerning the universality of Medicare. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has played this issue for all it is worth by arguing that Medicare is for everyone, whenever they need it—rich and poor, sick and well. However, if the Medicare system is so universal, then why is this principle contradicted within the discussion paper which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare was always intended to coexist with the private health system, not to replace it.

Surely this is an admission by the government, in its very own discussion paper, that Medicare is only partly universal, which is a contradiction in itself. The Prime Minister might take note of this because Senator Richardson's discussion paper continues on the same subject by saying:
Initial estimates of the cost of Medicare assumed that at least 40% of Australians would maintain their private cover.

Not only does this further break down this government's myth that Medicare is universal, but where on earth did this figure of 40 per cent come from? When Medicare was originally introduced, 60 per cent of people had private health cover, so why did the government estimate that 40 per cent of the population would maintain cover? Why not 50 per cent? Why not 30 per cent? Without explanation in the report, this figure certainly does appear to be an out of the hat figure.

PARA.TAB: Further confusions and anomalies arise in this discussion when we see the document say that capping of insurance rebates to a 25 per cent insurable gap, enforced by government regulation, has created an incentive to overservice. Such a statement is an admission that capped fees, with or without an insurable gap, is an incentive to overproduce. To try to logically follow this, I therefore cannot understand why these proposals advocate fee capping after previously admitting that this will lead to overservicing. Surely the logical conclusion is that co-payment by the patient is essential to prevent overservicing.

The obvious reason Senator Richardson has rejected this is that it is a political football. But the minister must do the right thing by the whole department and by the whole health industry and not fiddle the figures simply to buy votes. He must examine the co-payment principle as a viable alternative. He has done it with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, he has rejected it with bulkbilling and he looks likely to reject it here as well. The minister must be consistent but also true to the genuine needs of the health industry and the general health of the population. The discussion paper put forward by Senator Richardson must not be treated too harshly because it is an area of reform that must take place. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The family has been quite a topic of conversation in this House recently. People from all parties are coming forward with suggestions as to the reasons why families throughout Australia are in crisis and offering their solutions to the problem. As a teacher in another life, one who taught in disadvantaged schools in several states, it is apparent to me that in order for society to maximise the future potential of all its children all government agencies must collectively respond to address the problem of resourcing programs for the development of our children.

PARA.TAB: Education is not the sole responsibility of the education departments, state or federal. There must be an interagency approach taken to ensure that the parents of children up to the age of eight and the children themselves are resourced properly and fully supported so that, as they enter the critical transition period in their education, from primary to secondary school, few of them are at risk.

Currently, we have close on 20 per cent in this risk category and little is being done to solve this problem. The federal intervention strategy is to be commended, but unless it is supported more effectively by the states, we will not succeed. State education departments are still operating on a fiscal rather than a pastoral basis. The thought of another state department operating in an interagency cooperative spirit rarely occurs anywhere throughout Australia.

Some schools throughout the state system have developed excellent programs which attempt to establish the strong foundation upon which the future of their community can be based. One such school is the Herdsmans Cove Primary School in Gagebrook in my electorate. Its innovative and visionary early intervention program, run superbly by Doreen Lutjens, a teacher at the school, and ably supported by the principal, Col Breward, and his great staff, is going a long way to ensuring that both parents and children are receiving a wide range of activities which will enable the children in this area to receive the best foundation possible for their future lives at school and beyond.

The state Liberal government in its wisdom and under the cloak of fiscal responsibility has now cut back moneys allocated to this innovative program. I call on the federal ministers responsible for education, health and children's services to assist in funding this and other such valuable programs if the states are to abrogate their responsibilities in this area.

For the third time, I wish to address the topic of the successful abduction from Australia of two Australian citizens, Iddin and Shah Gillespie, son and daughter respectively of Mrs Jacqueline Gillespie of Melbourne, by their natural father, Raja Bahrin Shah, a Malaysian prince. Wickham was subsequently convicted and sentenced to a term of 18 months in prison, to serve no less than nine months, by Judge Duggan of the Melbourne County Court on 6 May last year.

In this course of events, it became obvious that the prince had paid out a large amount of money to Wickham in order to facilitate the abduction. Details had been presented in court papers filed by US federal prosecutor Thomas O'Malley in Florida, together with amounts cashed for gold bullion to pay the Indonesian authorities. The total operation was estimated to cost $170,000; however, the lion's share definitely went to Wickham.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to inform the House of a very special celebration that has just been held: the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia is 30 years old. That association, which was started by Mary Paten with a small group of women friends in her garage in Victoria some 30 years ago, has expanded, grown and spread throughout Australia, offering enormous support and encouragement to women and their young children. It is perhaps fitting that the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia celebrates its birthday in the International Year of the Family because it too is focusing on the whole issue of nurturing, the bonding and the relationship between mother and child, family and children, and the development of that positive environment.

PARA.TAB: The Nursing Mothers Association over time has fought a number of battles enabling women giving birth to have more knowledge, to be more independent and to be able to pursue less medically intrusive procedures, as well as pursuing the issue of breastfeeding for the health of the child and the mother. As an association it has made its mark on Australia, it has enriched the lives of the women it has touched, it has enabled all of us to be part of a more caring environment and community and has enabled children to be bonded over a longer period.

I am delighted to send the best wishes of this parliament to Wendy Broderick, who is currently the President of the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia in Brisbane, along with the best wishes of many other people who have supported nursing mothers over a long period. My whole weekend was taken up with a whole range of carers conferences and issues which women need to take up.

The other group I would like to talk about is the National Council of Women of Australia, which represents over one million women and their organisations. That organisation looks to future strategies for the care of the carers. It has a very dynamic national president, Mrs Yvonne Bane. It brought from Sydney Major Elizabeth Johnson, who has received the Order of Australia and who works for the Salvation Army, to look at the future in caring for our families.

The burden of caring is usually taken by women. We would assess the number of people in our community giving care as anywhere between 350,000 to one million people and ranging from ages 23 to 80. The whole question of dependency, of the role of the government and the family and the whole issue as to the kind of support packages that currently exist also needs to be taken up. Along with that is the government's response to Burdekin, the issues of psychiatric and schizophrenic concerns, lifestyle, the economic impact which caring has on families when it denies people access to superannuation, full-time employment and, of course, other benefits that come from being in full-time employment.

I commend the National Council of Women of Australia for having the foresight to look at the issue of caring, which is of great concern to the community and to their women members, and indeed pursue a response to that and develop strategies which we, as the government, may address later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a document which recently crossed my desk entitled Challenge Bank Economic Update of 20 January 1994. This document took my attention because of its front cover which read `Job Compact plan could reduce unemployment'. This is a topic of vital concern to me, having in my own electorate one of the highest areas of unemployment in Victoria. I was interested to look at the research undertaken by the Challenge Bank in conjunction with the Curtin University of Technology's economic and financial research unit in Perth, Western Australia. The Challenge Bank made a response to the green paper entitled Restoring full employment in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee on Employment Opportunities offered a number of scenarios.

We recall the tabling of the green paper by the government, but I was interested in the Challenge Bank's comments because it had what I believe was a very strong case to put forward. Reference was made to the committee believing that:

. . . it could alleviate long-term unemployment more quickly by introducing Job Compact, an agreement or contract between the long-term unemployed and the Federal Government. Job Compact emphasised reciprocal obligation for both parties to the agreement.

My concern in this article is that the job compact proposed by the federal government was to provide jobs for between six and nine months only to those who had been unemployed for at least 18 months. I regret to say that I have many people in my electorate who have been unemployed for a long period. They read with dismay that the government was providing a job under the job compact for only between six and nine months. Their response to me was, `What happens after that six or nine months period?'. That is a very reasonable question to ask of the government.

PARA.TAB: The Challenge Bank article referred to the research which was conducted into the cost of the scheme. It was believed that the annual cost was estimated at between $1 billion and $1.4 billion and that it could decrease the number of long-term unemployed. But one of the things of great concern—and I want to add my strong support for this—is the possible sources of funding in a number of areas. The bank vigorously opposed a jobs levy, as do I. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The jobs levy is simply an increase in income tax which would reduce consumer confidence and spending just as the recovery was gaining momentum.
I concur most strongly with the comments made in the Challenge Bank document. The article continues:
The key to a growing and prosperous economy and lower unemployment is the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many persons conveyed by (a) motor vehicles, (b) motorcycles and (c) bicycles died from (i) head injuries and (ii) injuries other than head injuries in (A) 1991 and (B) 1992.

(2) What was the ratio of deaths per thousand persons conveyed by (a) motor vehicles, (b) motorcycles and (c) bicycles from (i) head injuries and (ii) injuries other than head injuries in (A) 1991 and (B) 1992.
(3) What was the ratio of deaths by head injury to deaths from other injuries of children under 13 years of age in (a) 1991 and (b) 1992.
(4) What is the breakdown by causal factor, such as motorist, cyclist or environment, of all bicycle fatalities in (a) 1991 and (b) 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The question relates to the years in which compulsory bicycle helmet wearing was being introduced by each State and Territory government. The detailed data needed to assess bicyclist injury patterns has not yet been assembled for either of those years. It is known, however, that nationally the total number of bicyclists seriously injured or killed has decreased dramatically since bicycle helmets were made compulsory. For example there were 80 bicyclists killed in 1990, but this figure was 58 in 1991, 41 in 1992 and 44 in 1993.

The only nationally consistent source of information on the injuries received by those killed in road crashes is the Federal Office of Road Safety's `Fatality File' database which is collected every two years. This database incorporates data from a number of sources, including State Coroners, and as a result there is a considerable lag before the source data can be accessed. While the 1992 database is currently being collected, the most recent data available at present relates to 1990. The 1990 data provides a general guide to the potential benefits to be obtained from subsequent legislation for compulsory helmet wearing.
(1) In 1990, there were 1895 operator fatalities: 1554 vehicle occupant fatalities, 261 motorcyclist fatalities and 80 bicyclist fatalities.
(i) serious head injury alone was responsible for death of 23% of vehicle occupants, 26% of motorcyclists and 39% of bicyclists
(ii) serious head and other injuries were together responsible for death of 32% of vehicle occupants, 36% of motorcyclists and 22% of bicyclists, and
(iii) injuries other than head injury were responsible for death of 45% of vehicle occupants, 38% of motorcyclists and 39% of bicyclists.
(2) The number of persons conveyed by vehicles is not known. Ratios of deaths expressed per thousand of total population in 1990 are as follows;
(i) for deaths from serious head injury alone: 0.021 for vehicle occupants, 0.004 for motorcyclists and 0.002 for bicyclists,
(ii) for deaths from serious head and other injuries together: 0.029 for vehicle occupants, 0.006 for motorcyclists and 0.001 for bicyclists, and
(iii) for deaths from injuries other than head injury: 0.041 for vehicle occupants, 0.006 for motorcyclists and 0.002 for bicyclists.
(3) The ratio of deaths by head injury to deaths from other injuries of children under 13 years of age in 1990 was:
(i) 1.50: 1 for vehicle and motorcycle passengers and
(ii) 1.42: 1 for bicyclists.
(4) Of the 80 cyclist fatalities in 1990, 47 were caused by the cyclist, 17 by a motorist, 4 by cyclist and motorist and 12 by environment.

Some evidence for the effect of the compulsory helmet wearing legislation comes from a recent study that looked at the changes in the number of bicycle riders sustaining head injuries in Victoria, the first State to introduce compulsory bicycle helmet wearing legislation.

This study shows that since the introduction of the mandatory helmet wearing law in Victoria on 1 July 1990 the reduction in the number of bicyclists sustaining head injuries has been much greater than the reduction for those suffering non-head injury related injuries. In 1990/91, claims to Victoria's Transport Accident Commission from bicyclist casualties with head injuries decreased by 48% compared with a 23% reduction in claims from bicyclists with non-head injuries. In 1991/92, reductions related to head and non-head injuries were 70% versus 28% respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Government's position on the indexing of pensions with the UK.
(2) Will the position be reviewed in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The UK Government has a position of non-indexation of pension outside the UK except where the indexation is covered specifically in an agreement. The Australian Agreement does not include this provision.

The Australian Government believes non-indexation of British pensions in Australia is unjust. As British pensions are contribution based, a lower rate of pension should not be paid to some pensioners just because they choose to live in a particular country.
(2) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, without notice, on 22 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Can the Minister explain why a woman who is scanned for suspected breast malignancy is eligible for a Medicare rebate but another woman, advised by her doctor to have a mammogram before undergoing hormone replacement therapy for osteoporosis, is denied a Medicare rebate for the screening?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: It is not clear whether the question was meant to cover bone densitometry testing rather than mammography as the latter is used to detect breast cancer and not osteoporosis.

The only potential link between osteoporosis and mammography is if a woman being treated for osteoporosis by Hormone Replacement Therapy is considered to have an increased risk of developing breast cancer.
The Government's funding arrangements for mammography recognise the dual use of mammography in screening and in diagnosis of breast cancer.

For mammography screening, special purpose grants have been made to the States and Territories which aim to ensure the provision on a national basis of a network of accredited screening and assessment facilities. These services are provided at no cost to the patient.
The structure of the screening program was based on the recommendations of the Screening Evaluation Co-Ordination unit established to evaluate the effectiveness of mammography screening.
For diagnostic mammography, Medicare benefits are available where a woman presents to her doctor with symptoms or indications of malignancy in the breast, or with a family history of breast cancer.
Therefore, if a doctor considers that a patient has symptoms, indications or a family history of breast cancer, Medicare benefits are available for mammography.
In relation to the potential link between osteoporosis and mammography HRT is only one of a number of therapies used in the treatment of osteoporosis and its associated fractures.
Evidence of the effectiveness of long-term HRT in preventing fractures is inconclusive.
Also, the issue of an increased risk of breast cancer associated with HRT is the subject of considerable controversy among the scientific and medical community.
No clear consensus has been reached concerning the existence or magnitude of any increased risk of developing breast cancer in women receiving HRT.
The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is to convene a consensus conference on the use of HRT. This should enable consensus to be reached on the implications of HRT for breast cancer risk.

In the interim it is a matter for the individual clinician to determine whether he or she believes his patient is at risk of breast cancer based on clinical indications, and if so to order a mammogram.

Mammography is, however, unable to indicate osteoporosis per se and it is of no use in monitoring that condition. Rather bone densitometry which measures bone density is considered to have a place in dealing with osteoporosis.
From 1 March 1994, Medicare benefits at a schedule fee of $75 per service will be available bone densitometry testing in certain specified circumstances.
Expert advice on specification and implementation of Medicare Benefits for bone densitometry was sought last year from the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC).

The Minister has accepted all of the recommendations of MBAC on the provision of Medicare Benefits for certain bone densitometry tests including a series of measures to promote quality and appropriate use of the technology.

MBAC recommended that payment of benefits should be confined to two clinical applications, based on a review of current scientific knowledge and clinical practice. These are, firstly, in the confirmation and monitoring of established osteoporosis and secondly, in the diagnosis and monitoring of bone loss associated with a specific set of clinical conditions. These include chronic liver disease, chronic renal disease, rheumatoid arthritis and proven malapsorptive disorders.

On the issue of the use of bone densitometry as a screening tool to detect developing osteoporosis amongst menopausal women, MBAC concluded that there was insufficient scientific evidence to warrant the payment of Medicare benefits for this purpose.

However, women who are receiving hormone replacement therapy (HRT), or other treatments, for osteoporosis will be eligible for Medicare benefits for bone densitometry as part of the monitoring of their condition.
